number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												Quick Summary: Third person action shooter very similar to Resident Evil 5, but at times noticeably lower graphics and some actual downgrades in gameplay mechanics. This is likely due to the fact that Revelations is a port of a Nintendo hand held game, later upgraded with HD graphics, and was never meant to be the next “great” Resident Evil game. Still, it’s fun and time consuming so you’ll get your money’s worth even if you didn’t buy the various DLCs. Despite the fact that Revelations was released a few years after Resident Evil 5, the story of Revelations actually takes place earlier, as a kind of prequel (though unrelated plot-wise). You play BSAA agent Jill Valentine for the most part, but in each chapter you’ll regularly control different people such as Chris Redfield or other BSAA agents.  You know Jill is the main character though since she’s the only one who can mod her weapons with upgrade kits, and swap guns at the various loadout crates scattered around the area. Jill and her partner Parker are on a mission exploring an abandoned cruise ship related to terrorist activity from years before. As usual in Resident Evil games, “terrorist” means bio-weapons that create monsters to be unleashed on the world. This time around the weapon in question is the T-Abyss virus, that doesn’t make traditional zombies, but instead makes “oozes” which look kind of like humanoid tubeworms with claws and spiky teeth. Of course, that’s just the weak stuff. There are a bunch of giant bosses and super creepy monsters wandering the cruise ship as well. If you’ve played Resident Evil 5, the gameplay should be very familiar to you, except that now you can just press the mouse button for a quick jab attack. Just like in RE 5 though, regular melee isn’t much use except for breaking boxes in the campaign (it’s more useful in Raid mode). You still have special contextual power hits that do a lot of damage to stunned enemies, but it’s a lot harder to set up stuns in Revelations. To kill most enemies you’ll have to rely on your guns. Various guns are found throughout the game (you can’t buy them in campaign) and they can only be upgraded with weapon “parts” that you find lying around. For example, your basic pistol may have 3 upgrade slots so you can add up to 3 weapon upgrades like + damage, faster shooting, and larger magazine, and swap for better ones that you find later. There’s no “money” used in the campaign for buying upgrades. Also note that even though you are usually with a partner throughout the campaign, this is not a co-op game. You cannot go through the story with a friend. Another new feature for Revelations is the Genesis device, which is just a scanner despite its fancy name. You can quickly switch to the scanner at almost any time to scan enemies (alive or dead) and it adds a % to your “data.” For example scanning an ooze could give you 10% and scanning a tougher enemy might give you 20%. Every time you reach 100%, you get a healing herb added to your inventory, and the % resets to 0. It’s a slow but steady way to gain herbs at various points in the game. The Genesis can also be used to locate hidden items (like ammo or herbs) lying invisible on the ground.Pros:+A spooky Resident Evil game with enemies more gruesome than zombies, and no “human” enemies so you don’t need to hide from enemy gunfire (though there are some ranged oozes). There is a lot of backtracking in this game, and you’re going to go through most areas of the cruise ship several times. This means you have opportunities to pick up things that you missed the previous times through. +The story is compelling, but it’s episodic which means every chapter starts with a “previously on Resident Evil Revelations” cutscene to catch you up in case you didn’t buy every episode. +The Raid mode is the highlight of the game and allows you and a partner to level up by playing through areas from the game’s campaign. You also acquire BP (kind of like money) that you can use to buy weapons and weapon upgrade parts. You’ll need to get new gear when you level up because weapons have fixed levels. For example you start at level 1 with a level 1 gun, but when you’ve advanced, you may want to buy a level 2 gun, etc.Cons:-Since this is a mobile game port, the graphics and handling isn’t quite up to snuff compared to Resident Evil 5 or 6. There’s some frame rate stuttering on my computer (which ran RE 5 smoothly), and like Resident Evil 6, every time you start the game there are half a dozen little load screens to wait through. -The game’s co-op Raid mode doesn’t have that many people playing anymore apparently. This may be because you can’t “drop in” to someone’s game. The host has to set up a game and wait for people to join, sometimes for a long time if nobody is searching for a match that very second. Most people probably don’t have the patience for that. This means if you want to play co-op, you need to set it up with a friend beforehand. Also, like RE 5, there’s no text or voice chat in the co-op.Overall, the game is a fun continuation of the action shooter style of Resident Evil games, and the creepy deserted cruise ship has a nice atmosphere for horror. Raid mode will occupy a lot of your time after you’ve finished the story. Once you’ve mastered Raid mode’s Abyss tier of levels, the campaign’s Infernal difficulty (hard mode) will seem like a walk in the park.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												The days of the old gritty mysterious Resident Evil are over and I will miss them...BUT as much as I do, I thinkthe franchise took a step forward in the right direction with Revelations at least for the meantime. Storytelling is episodic and gameplay is what you would expect from any other resident evil game with a twist of action, you get to play as many different characters on many different missions folding into eachother to tell this decent and very interesting Resident Evil story. Theres even a "Raid Mode" that you can unlock by playing the entire 8 to 10 hour campaign. Raid Mode will have you run through familiar terrain killing water zombies with large health bars for rank, bonuses, enemy spoils, BP and EXP. You can play with a friend or test yourself. I would say this is the equivelant of Zombies in COD.I give this game a 7/10 for its decent story and familiar gameplay with the addition of Raid Mode and New Game+. Hopefully in the very near future the franchise will start making newer Resident Evils with the originals in complete thought.

												pros+ Great horror atmoshpere! Something that had been lost to the series since RE4, IMHO.+ Action-packed gameplay. + A pretty decent storyline with legitimately exciting and thrilling scenes.+ Interesting weapon customization system.+  Raid mode is quite fun. And New Game+ also adds a lot of replay value, IMHO.+ Jill is really sexy. ^^neutral> It's considerably harder to stun enemies compared to other RE4, 5 and 6. It adds to the challenge and makes the game scarier, but at the same time, it reduces one of the most fun aspects of modern RE games.cons- No campaign multiplayer. :(- Enemy design is somewhat uninspired and repetitive. Only bosses look somewhat creative.CONCLUSION:Resident Evil Revelations is my favorite game of the franchise. No other installment mixed so well the horror atmosphere of the classic games with the action-based gameplay ofthe newer ones. Overall, a great experience, and a must-have for all fans of the series, in my humble opinion.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
Product received for free
【NOTE】 I did my first playthrough on Infernal difficulty, meaning I can only review the game on the hardest difficulty.Rating: Super Positive <3Game Progress: Completed the campaign on Infernal difficulty with 20-ish collectibles out of 30, Raid Mode is untouched.Actual Campaign Playtime: 09:30:'21" (HH:MM:SS)Campaign Total: 80% Accuracy (A) 35 Deaths (A)Game Knowledge: In-game manual, keyboard settings, basics and infernal difficulty.【Instructions for first timers】 Okay right off the bat, not even the game wants you to pick the highest difficulty on your first run because you get a warning. Which is understandable. But if you play Infernal despite the warning that the game gives you then the game simply expects that you know what you're doing. The game has a manual in your inventory that you can read to understand some basics. You also get right into enemy action which is great so that you can do some practice to understand how the game works. I think the game does a great job for first timers. It warns them about the highest difficulty, it offers a game manual and you get in-game tips when you need them the most. Even for bosses!【Unique Resident Evil Stuff】Now this game is special. Never have I ever seen anything in Resident Evil like Revelations. Revelations has a unique mechanic in the form of a scanner which you can use to scan a area for ammo, herbs, custom parts or just secrets in general. You can even scan the enemies you face, either dead or alive. The scanner is a very useful and cool item that adds a nice touch to the atmosphere and you feel alot more like you're inside the game when you carefully scan each area with caution to find all the hidden stuff. It's a great touch! It makes back tracking way more fun and finding those super cool secrets just makes it extra thrilling. Not to mention that you get a herb (Healing item) everytime your scanner reaches 100%. It's an useful mechanic and I love the fact that they went from traditional items in plain sight to completely hidden items that required you to use an optional yet highly useful item to find the items. It adds to the 'sea' atmosphere. Where divers have to scan for treasures, if you feel me. The Resident Evil series does have sea creatures, plenty of sea creatures to say the least. BUT, I've never seen a Resident Evil with this much focus on sea creatures ever before! The game has a great style in creatures. The creatures really gives a deep sea feeling. They look wet from water and they look very 'sea crispy' - Very strong looks that resembels already existing creatures of the sea. From my own Resident Evil experience have I never seen a 'partner-swap' before. In a story-related moment in the game, the characters swap partners with each other which will obviously add a more interesting twist in story where you get to see new character interactions! Revelations is different, well I'll tell you that the game has no store in the campaign. There are weapon boxes scattered around but that was only to upgrade your weapons or swap weapons but that was upgrades and weapons that YOU HAVE FOUND YOURSELF. Revelations was a straight up exploration game above all and I think it's an excellent move to turn a game with such mystery and atmosphere into a exploration game. That was a thing I highly liked. Obviously the game can be fun with buying your way through but I think it added a bit more of a nicer touch that you HAD to explore in order to get anywhere. Top-notch, full glass for Capcom here!【Combat】Similar to Resident Evil 6 you can quickly melee your enemies with a quick click on the left mouse button though it's alot more risky in Revelations since you move slower, you are vulnerable and you don't really stun your enemy when you use your melee attack. I barely used melee at all, only on THE MOST SAFE MOMENTS POSSIBLE. You can also hit F when the enemies are stunned to perform a takedown (Won't always kill) which can save you about 3 bullets or so. The guns were very well played-out. You could use each firearm without ever feeling like picking a side. Handguns were just fine with decent damage and lots of ammo, machine guns were really great if you went into trouble of a crowded hallway if you have fire rate upgrades, Shotguns was used when I felt bullied by the enemies to knock them back to save me some time and ammo so I could get past them. Sniper rifles were used when I got to those sneaky moments where the enemy hasn't detected me yet so I could sneak a headshot on them. Magnums were used for those big fellas that I just wanted to murder away, such as bosses. But I love the fact that each weapon felt useful and that there wasn't a single weapon that just screamed MEH. Ammo wasn't ever an issue. You used your scanner "Genesis" to find ammo until you were filled. And during bosses you could use your surroundings in order to save your ammo. Combat was really fine and fun!【Locations】 The game is not just on a ship. You get backstories set before the ship and you get to play different sides throughout the story. Keith, Parker, Chris and Jill is all there for you to play as!【Conclusion】 I'd highly recommend this for Resident Evil fans! Combat is really well done, game runs super smooth and ost is 100% <3(Text limit) Ask me if you wanna know more :)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												Now that I unlocked all achievements I can finally put the game aside and never play it again in the near future. The only reason might be to S rank the remaining campaign chapters I haven’t done yet or to unlock even more achievments in the free online portal found on residentevil.net. So here we begin this in two sections separated review. First we sink into the campaign mode before we head on to the action packed Raid Mode.CampaignPeople will tell you that Revelations was the first step of Capcom to bring the series back to its survival horror roots but I can’t completely agree with that. The campaign is split into 12 chapters. The majority of chapters take place on a cruise ship while others are more of the typical action shooter the series is known for today with various changing locations and time periods. The cruise ship chapters feature narrow corridors, somewhat creepy atmosphere and are surprising the best chapters of the game while the action oriented chapters are mediocre at best compared to other action shooter games out there.The storyline is one gigantic puzzle jumping back & forth between events and can be very confusing the first time around. But it’s not as convoluted as they say. It’s easy to differentiate who are the bad guys & good guys in this soap opera. To put the pieces together can be a very entertaining & is a motivator to continue playing until the end.You run around mostly solo and if a partner is on your toes then it’s only an AI controlled partner. Unlike other entries the AI partner in Revelations doesn’t need to be instructed because he/she is basically invincible, got infinite ammo and shoots or doges when the need to shoot or dodge is required. The player is the true source of power in the roughly 11hour campaign here. He/she is is the one to deal the damage & the one that needs to heal himself.Gameplay mechanics are very simple. This is after all a 3DS game ported & remastered for PC. Healing, throwing grenades, using the knife are bound to only a button and can be executed quick without much time of preparation which is a good thing compared to the clunky, overloaded mechanics used in other entries of the series. The only game mechanic that is poorly implemented is the Dodging-System. You basically have to push the action button & the analog stick short before an enemy hits you. But this button is bound to other actions like opening doors, shooting with the gun & picking up items and doesn’t work most of the time and requires lots of practice to be used to its fully extend.Raid ModeFirst introduced in Revelations 1 is the so called Raid Mode. This mode spawns three difficulties with 20 stages that must be unlocked as you play along. Raid is basically an Arcade Shooter in which you will be throw in all the locations of campaign mode and to solve tasks like killing all enemies or reaching the goal. Enemy spawns are fixed so they can be learned easily. You either play it alone or you invite one of your Steam Friends or search for strangers to play it in Co-Op. After each stage you will be rated on accuracy, enemies routed & damage taken and earns you XP that level up your characters. Perfect players will be awarded with bonuses for no damage taken, elimination of all enemies and completing a stage at the recommended level. This results in higher currency which then can be used to buy new weapons and weapon upgrades in the in game shop.Leveling up will raise the level of all characters. Characters are mere avatars with different skill sets. Some are good with SMGs, while others are better in using Shotguns, to take less damage or to dodge easier.The only negative I have to write about Raid Mode is the lack of stages & the sheer amount of time investment to reach a new player level. Leveling up is so freaking slow that you replay some stages 10 or more times before you are able to survive in the next. Playing stages below recommented level & with an online partner is the key for faster level up, but it is a tedious process that gets you bored very quickly.ConclusionRevelations 1 is a fun little action shooter with horror elements that got so much to offer that you will be entertained for hours. Fans of the series should buy it without giving it a second thought. Achievement Hunters as well as casual gamers should think twice before they hit the purchase button, unless they are willing to spend time on the good but not perfect Raid Mode.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												This game is a port from a handheld console and it shows. While it's still fun to play theres a few things people should know before buying. The overall gameplay is not as deep as recent RE games.The "coop" is not like other RE games you cannot play the campaign coop. This was a major disapointment for me as I bought 2 copies to play with the missus. The coop they advertise is only the minigame you can play on the side and even then it's nothing like the Fight for your life maps in mercenaries mod like re 4 5 and 6. It's more of a small mission to get from point A to point B collecting xp and leveling up. I didn't like it anywhere near as much as it just seems like a grind rather then the frantic carnage that is mercenaries.I'm going to say no to recommending this game, Not because its bad like operation racoon city was but just because I can't imagine any of my friends enjoying it. It's good for a DS/vita game. Unfortunately it just can't compete with the big boy RE games.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												In short, it feels like a streamlined hybrid of the earlier Resident Evil games mixed with Resident Evil 4, yet without all the shortcomings of Resident Evil 5 and 6. Revelations, at it's core, is a solo adventure with strong survival horror elements (lack of ammo/health). However, CO-OP elements return in a seperate mode from the main campaign called RAID mode, which is essentially RE4's mercenaries with RPG elements. Revelations ditches the open environments for tighter corridors in vein of the original Resident Evil's Spencer mansion. Puzzles return and new elements to the series such as swimming are introduced. Also, the chest box makes a welcome return, but it is only used for switching and customizing weapons. The storyline is good, but not quite as strong or dark as Resident Evil 4. At times, it feels more intune with Code: Veronica's wackiness, complete with cheesy B movie dialog and outragoues characters. However, that is all part of why most of us love Resident Evil...and this entry actually feels like a Resident Evil title for once. Just like Resident Evil 4, Revelations provides a good balance of action and survival horror, however, Revelations puts more emphasize on backtracking and conserving ammo. It's not as scary or polished as RE4, but introduces some great new features to the formula. This is the survival horror you've been craving for from Capcom.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												Now that I unlocked all achievements I can finally put the game aside and never play it again in the near future. The only reason might be to S rank the remaining campaign chapters I haven’t done yet or to unlock even more achievments in the free online portal found on residentevil.net. So here we begin this in two sections separated review. First we sink into the campaign mode before we head on to the action packed Raid Mode.CampaignPeople will tell you that Revelations was the first step of Capcom to bring the series back to its survival horror roots but I can’t completely agree with that. The campaign is split into 12 chapters. The majority of chapters take place on a cruise ship while others are more of the typical action shooter the series is known for today with various changing locations and time periods. The cruise ship chapters feature narrow corridors, somewhat creepy atmosphere and are surprising the best chapters of the game while the action oriented chapters are mediocre at best compared to other action shooter games out there.The storyline is one gigantic puzzle jumping back & forth between events and can be very confusing the first time around. But it’s not as convoluted as they say. It’s easy to differentiate who are the bad guys & good guys in this soap opera. To put the pieces together can be a very entertaining & is a motivator to continue playing until the end.You run around mostly solo and if a partner is on your toes then it’s only an AI controlled partner. Unlike other entries the AI partner in Revelations doesn’t need to be instructed because he/she is basically invincible, got infinite ammo and shoots or doges when the need to shoot or dodge is required. The player is the true source of power in the roughly 11hour campaign here. He/she is is the one to deal the damage & the one that needs to heal himself.Gameplay mechanics are very simple. This is after all a 3DS game ported & remastered for PC. Healing, throwing grenades, using the knife are bound to only a button and can be executed quick without much time of preparation which is a good thing compared to the clunky, overloaded mechanics used in other entries of the series. The only game mechanic that is poorly implemented is the Dodging-System. You basically have to push the action button & the analog stick short before an enemy hits you. But this button is bound to other actions like opening doors, shooting with the gun & picking up items and doesn’t work most of the time and requires lots of practice to be used to its fully extend.Raid ModeFirst introduced in Revelations 1 is the so called Raid Mode. This mode spawns three difficulties with 20 stages that must be unlocked as you play along. Raid is basically an Arcade Shooter in which you will be throw in all the locations of campaign mode and to solve tasks like killing all enemies or reaching the goal. Enemy spawns are fixed so they can be learned easily. You either play it alone or you invite one of your Steam Friends or search for strangers to play it in Co-Op. After each stage you will be rated on accuracy, enemies routed & damage taken and earns you XP that level up your characters. Perfect players will be awarded with bonuses for no damage taken, elimination of all enemies and completing a stage at the recommended level. This results in higher currency which then can be used to buy new weapons and weapon upgrades in the in game shop.Leveling up will raise the level of all characters. Characters are mere avatars with different skill sets. Some are good with SMGs, while others are better in using Shotguns, to take less damage or to dodge easier.The only negative I have to write about Raid Mode is the lack of stages & the sheer amount of time investment to reach a new player level. Leveling up is so freaking slow that you replay some stages 10 or more times before you are able to survive in the next. Playing stages below recommented level & with an online partner is the key for faster level up, but it is a tedious process that gets you bored very quickly.ConclusionRevelations 1 is a fun little action shooter with horror elements that got so much to offer that you will be entertained for hours. Fans of the series should buy it without giving it a second thought. Achievement Hunters as well as casual gamers should think twice before they hit the purchase button, unless they are willing to spend time on the good but not perfect Raid Mode.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
Product received for free
												Is it the perfect Resident Evil game?No.But is it a fun Resident Evil game...?Heck yeah, and here's why:Nice story, good atmosphere, fluid action, a good voice cast, and Raid mode (go through the different stages and shoot through different difficulties of enemies, unlocking weapons, parts, etc through beating them). Though, of course, this game isn't without problems:The graphics are ok at best, though that's likely because it was originally on the 3DS. Also, while certain new characters like Parker and Raymond are great, others like Jessica, Quint, and Keith are... not so much. Playing the game on Normal, ammo is abundant, so a harder difficulty is recommended if you want to feel more of an actual challenge.  Lastly, the final boss is about 50/50 when it comes to enjoyability. To me, it was frustrating until I figured out its pattern, which didn't take too long. Overall, not my favorite Resident Evil, but still an enjoyable one for sure. If you get it discounted (or in my case, gifted), it's well worth your time.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												Resident Evil Revelations is a nice addition to the Franchise.  Although the fact that it was originally a 3ds game both surprises and disappoints me - it's a game much more deserving of a higher budget.Pros:+Multiple sides of the Story to see, reminds me of Resident Evil 6 without multiple campaigns.+I actually felt scared at a few points.  They successfully did horror.  Woohoo!+Game is pretty long for one that was handheld.Cons:-In my Opinion, the ending of the story isn't as satisfying as the buildup presents it to be.-The puzzles in the game are of very small variety.  Although they do bring back that Resident Evil 1 searching around the Mansion feel, I wish there were many different types of puzzles.  There is one type where you unscrew the panel next to a locked door and move some glowing circles around to unlock the circutry.  This got so tedious, so fast.  Not fun.-You can tell the controls aren't really perfected to pc, or even joystick for that matter.  They're just not that great.-No local or online coop campaign support.  Strange, considering you're with a partner 90% of the time.  I suppose this makes sense, because sometimes your partner is in a different place than you.  But, they could've gotten creative with that.-I'm going to be straight up with this one: the character models' faces in the game world outside of cutscenes are poor, to say the least.  Jessica looks like a Bratz Doll who's constantly smelling flatulence.  -No laser sights, which were present on the 3ds version.  That's right, they removed them for no reason whatsoever.  Overall, I enjoyed Revelations.  I believe it deserved the budget Resident Evil 5 got, which would've allowed co-op, better animation, and probably better voice actors (the current ones are pretty meh). due to it's return to its roots with pretty much everything but the fixed camera angles, making it a more enjoyable game.  I'd say get it on sale, because it very much looks and feels like a 3ds game regardless of it's "HD" qualities.  7.5/10

												If this game had a maybe button,I would press itThis game felt like it was trying to do what RE4 did (no one can replicate that),but it wasn't bad.It just still has that aspect of a shooter,and little survival horror,I felt like I was prepared for a fight all the time.I don't wanna feel like that all the time,I wanna feel like im on the verge of death or I don't have enough ammo to fight this boss.The Scanner,oh my god.What a good feature...to an extent.I love how you can scan bodies to get a herb to use,but you can find derelict items in the world,like ammo and herbs or custom parts,IT'S LITERALLY SCATTERED ALL OVER THE MAP....and I can't get them all! Because,I'm filled up with too much rifle or smg ammo...Raid Mode,I tried out and it felt so much like Mercenaries...just call it Mercenaries,damnit!Graphics are very good,byfar one of the best i've seen in a RE Game(Have no clue how this ran on PS Vita) Optimization is good,supurb acutally.Now for the meat...The Plot.The plot is good,few twists here and there,kind of adds little more confusion to the RE universe with all these diffrent viruses.No zombies sadly,Just these mutants and sort of buff two-foot walking lizards (Can't remember the name).New characters,and the old ones! You'll see through Jill and Chris,and newbies,Parker and "Grinder".Parker being my favorite of them because of his sweet Italian accent and bad♥♥♥♥♥ego.Jill's♥♥♥♥♥is big as usual,Chris is buff as ♥♥♥♥,so no diffrence with the oldies.Though someones tries to interfere with Chris and Jill's psuedo-relationship,she's hot but not as hot as Jill.(No Spoliers)All in all,This game is Meh,but Meh on the Verge of Great!TL;DRPros-RE4 Style Gameplay(to an extent)-Story is okay...-Modification on guns-Graphics are great!-Optimization is goodCons-No Inventory system-Still feels like a shooter-The 3-weapon system-Little more confusion to the RE Universe-The Raid Mode/or Mercenaries6.5/10 -Not a bad game,just needs little more of some good old RE :)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												This game is awesome. Stuck on a ship (great claustrophobic environment checked) after being misled, Jill Valentine and her partner Parker has to survive the horror that awaits them, and uncover a greater conspiracy.The story is great with everyone's favourite Jill Valentine returning as the lead cast, comedic moments with the other supporting BSAA members, and a twist in the story. However, it is pretty straight forward, and gets boring by my 3rd play through, more notes could be left around to explain the backgrounds and motivations of the other characters.Gameplay is not much different from Resident Evil 5 and 6, with the 3rd person shooting angles. However, no more confusing inventory system! Instead your weapons and upgrades will be stored in the classic storage box, and you can only take 3 weapons at a time. Key items does not take up inventory space, so there is no 'inventory puzzles' to solve.The previous 2 Resident Evil games brough more action than horror to the storyline, which is expected as Chris and Leon are now part of anti-bioterriorism forces (who still expects them to be afraid of zombies?). However, the slower pace of RE: Revelations. limited ammo, narrow pathways filled with 'zombies' blocking your exit, and a 'stalker' type monster that refuse to die, managed to create the perfect creepy environment on board a ship. At times Jill will have to wander off alone and makes you wonder why her partner is such a wuss despite being a big man (not that he's of much use anyways). Decisions have to be made over fight or flight, especially on your first play through on normal or insane mode, although for those gamers who have to kill everything, the genesis scanner will help to uncover additional bullets. Do note that flash back and side missions which helps explain the story are more action oriented. Overall, i find the game having a good balance of horror and action done through great graphics, environmental sounds, back ground music, and dialogues. Afterall, as our favourite characters matures and become adapt at handling such situations, it is impossible for Resident Evil to have a pure horror storyline that makes logical sense. Lastly, there is the raid mode which can be insanely difficult especially if you're an achievement hunter. This mode allows you to play RE: Revelations like a classic arcade shooter with weapons, trophies and high score to collect, and add on countless hours of fun for those up to the challenge.In conclusion, RE: Revelations is worth spending time on. However, the steam sales ranging from 50-75% would be worth waiting for as the full retail price of S$62 is slightly costly. Whether you are a Resident Evil fan or not this game will surely not disappoint.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Not bad. It's not as scary as dead space or resident evil 2 but it makes up for it with great gameplay mechanics. It's an incredibly well done console port - both movement and mouse aiming are tight and responsive. My only complaints are that the coop mode isn't fully integrated (no campaign coop mode), it's a separate arcade style series of missions. Disappointing because you have an AI partner with you for a large portion of the campaign, woulndn't have been difficult to implement. I don't care much for the approach capcom took in trying to develop the story with this game. It basically creates a bunch of 'episode' segments, the majority of them you play as Jill but some of them toss you into alternate character side missions that really don't contribute much to the game.Also, the game is a little too easy. Even playing on infernal mode with a brand new game I didn't have to worry about ammo management after 2 or 3 chapters (Although the first chapter is pretty tricky). If you have good aim this won't be terribly challenging for you.TL;DR  - Pros: Great gameplay and controls; Jill has a nice♥♥♥♥♥br>             Cons: No campaign coop mode; Too many side character missions; Kinda easy on max difficulty

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10
												It's alright!Resident Evil: Revelations is a continuation of the action / survival horror hybrid that started in Resident Evil 4 and, in this case, was originally developed for the 3DS. As such, though the visuals have been brought up roughly to a Gamecube-era RE game, the environments are more limited and closed than its predecessor. While you can still leap off of high points, hurdle over some rare obstructions, and aim in first person, a lot of the environmental interactivity is relatively limited. In general it's "Resident Evil 4 Lite: Boat Edition".Similarly, weapon upgrades are just discovered in the course of the game. In general, the weapon layout isn't going to have many surprises for RE veterans, though there are some nice new improvements in the latter half of the game. The emphasis is largely on action this time - though there's keys to find and some pointedly simple puzzles, for the most part the focus is on aiming and shooting baddies. Shooting enemies remains satisfying, though sometimes feedback on the enemies part is lacking - it wasn't until late in the game I realized you could tell if an enemy was dead or not by whether or not the crosshair is lit. I probably wasted a decent chunk of ammo firing at slowly-slumping, melting enemies where it just wasn't clear I'd already finished them off.Though it has some tension, the horror is generally absent this time around. While not as enjoyably schlocky as RE4, it does have some fairly ridiculous moments that stand out. The new fish-hybrid enemies aren't particularly frightening, and mostly it just feels you're fighting pale piles of goo without much personality. The bosses are solid, but fall more than a bit into frustration due to their ability to soak damage even on normal.The big change is Genesis, a first-person scanner akin to Batman's detective vision (in Arkham Asylum) or Eagle Vision in the Assassin's Creed series. This lets you find hidden items (and a set of collectibles), and scanning enemies regards you with extra health kits. It's a bit of a misfire, because though the extra health kits come in handy and it can increase tension early on when you're scanning just to get that extra kit, it doesn't do anything interesting like reveal new weak points or at least give you a library of scanned monsters.The boat environment is kind of a mix of neat ocean liner nods and boring grey hallways, and the forward motion of the game keeps it from ever developing too much personality. Though there's backtracking, it's relatively mild. Having Jill return (along with her prominently featured third-person butt) as the main character is welcome,  given the treatment she had in Resident Evil 5. You'll regularly swap out to a few other characters for different chapters, including series mainstay meathead Chris. The plot is pretty much just interesting enough to keep you going but its twists and turns are generally predictable for a series veteran like myself.In general, it's a decent little side game for the series, nowhere near the best but also nowhere near the worst. It does just well enough to hold together on its own and to earn a recommendation, but not a ringing one. If you've already experienced Resident Evil 4 and would like a little more in that vein, this is probably worth your time more than Resident Evil 5 or 6.Played through on normal difficulty to story completion, didn't mess around with raid mode.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Excellent as I heard, I always wanted to buy this game but I was on low money, until my close friend (though far from location) gifted me with this game on steam, so thank you (AliceDBC/DarknessBunny!)This game promises just like all the praise you heard, its really a great return to horror, finally and now Revelations 2 is coming, I can't wait, I love you CAPCOM for doing this game and porting it, I knew a port will come, though im saddened the cutscenes are still pre-rendered and Jill's face was not fixed, and the fact that Mercenaries 3D wasn't made HD and bundeled with this, Jill's front hair doesnt animate, but who cares ! xDGraphically its excellent for a remaster of a "3DS" game, which would look terrible if CAPCOM didn't decently improve it for HD platforms. But this game really has no physics, you break boxes and its like an explosion, no realistic breaking physic mechanic from RE5 and doors are basically bulletproof (which wasn't the case in the beta).The door opening sequence is also annoying, its basically LIN style without the camera "focus on door" zoom. And it's very annoying (which again, wasn't the case in the beta / Pilot Demo).This game was intended to have coop but it was taken out thanks to the extremist "we are the True Fans" group and no, you're not true fans, you don't even read the mangas, drama albums, watch the plays, play all the games, but you complain instead of buying and claim to be "True Fans"The AI in this game, you can't command it like RE5, you can't give or take items from it (him or her), they don't damage enemies at all but shoot basically nothing; they also don't get damage, this is MUCH worse than Sheva, yes she kept dying on Pro in RE5/BIO5 but this Partner AI here is terrible and this game should've Had COOP. Raid Mode in this game is fun, but to be honest its still a dwongrade in terms of verbal commands, no animations when commanding not even lip sync, not much variety (RE5 had MANY unused lines which were usable by hacking them) and finally, Revelations 2 Raid Mode is another downgrade, yes it has new features but CAPCOM has a habit of cutting down features. But it's still a great game and a very good port. That's all I'm gonna say.To keep it short...Jill undergoes a plastic surgery and faces the terrors of veltro as they vulture from the past, Terragrigia is suddenly the first public disclosure of bio organic weapons. P.S. this game manages to freak you out multiple times. Great storyline, good preqeul to RE5, Jill looks ugly, Chris looks okay but somehow plain, Jessica is annoying, good music and very hollywood-ish and orchestral, good horror, good gameplay, not the quality I expect of remaster but its defenitely a very good remaster, I expect physics to get added back though among other things.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												Well it was fun. Right up until the underwater missions. Checkpoint system combined with the cliched timed underwater escape with no way to fight back is a real failure, in any game. Survival horror should be about monsters (human or not), not choosing between boredom and suffocation. Not to say that its difficult, just time consuming. And any time a game producer chooses to throw me in a maze with no scenery and no monsters for an hour, I'm done with them and their product.

It's a bit of a misfire, because though the extra health kits come in handy and it can increase tension early on when you're scanning just to get that extra kit, it doesn't do anything interesting like reveal new weak points or at least give you a library of scanned monsters.The boat environment is kind of a mix of neat ocean liner nods and boring grey hallways, and the forward motion of the game keeps it from ever developing too much personality. Though there's backtracking, it's relatively mild. Having Jill return (along with her prominently featured third-person butt) as the main character is welcome,  given the treatment she had in Resident Evil 5. You'll regularly swap out to a few other characters for different chapters, including series mainstay meathead Chris. The plot is pretty much just interesting enough to keep you going but its twists and turns are generally predictable for a series veteran like myself.In general, it's a decent little side game for the series, nowhere near the best but also nowhere near the worst. It does just well enough to hold together on its own and to earn a recommendation, but not a ringing one. If you've already experienced Resident Evil 4 and would like a little more in that vein, this is probably worth your time more than Resident Evil 5 or 6.Played through on normal difficulty to story completion, didn't mess around with raid mode.

												"A return to classic Resident Evil! Much better than all the other terrible recent ones! Awesome!"♥♥♥♥ you. Every single one of you.This is a BAD game. As bad as ORC or 6? Well, no, pretty hard to be. But don't let the people desperate for a "throwback" lie to you, this is a very bad game in all aspects. First off...it's an HD remake of a DS. So, the graphics suck. The new characters introduced are all horrible and unlikable, the enemies are generic and boring (yes...compared to IDENTICAL LOOKING ZOMBIES THEY'RE STILL GENERIC AND BORING. wut?), the story is completely uninteresting, the whole "scan every room you walk in with this rad scanner to find secret hidden items right in front of you you can't see without it" is terrible, a 3DS touch screen minigame was left in, only now it's an annoying mini-cutscene to watch (fast paced screw driver/panel action!), bosses are just as boring as the regular enemies and no challenge whatsoever...It's just a bad game. Completely. Pretty much the only positive thing I can say about it is at least it's not Operation Raccoon City.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												I am not sure if me and the other reviewers have played the same game. I have to say that I was incredibly dissapointed in it (though I suppose no more than in say, RE6), and I honestly cannot recommend this game to anyone, not even fans of the franchise. I know this is a port from a handheld, so I suppose there is no point in complaining about graphics, however, the game is really really short (the entire campaign takes under 6 hours), you are being thrown from character to character, from location to location and it is disorienting, makes it difficult to manage your items or anticipate what you might need, and some of the characters you have to control are absolutely atrociously written. Speaking of writing, it is rather convoluted, even for a Resident Evil game. The fact that you will play through flashback sequences presented without much rhyme or reason is not helping. The voice - acting is almost as bad as RE 1 times, but this time there is no excuse of being a pioneering game. Overall it is tedious, often boring, unrewarding awful game with clunky controls. Do yourself a favour and buy the RE 1 HD Remaster or RE 4 HD instead.Bonus: There are two characters supposedly provided as comic relief that boils down to saying "THIS BLOWS". All. The. Time.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
												Dear Capcom,I have been passionately in love with you since age 3, and I will continue to cherish you and sing your praises until the day I die. And because I care so much about you and your future (...our future), I have no problem letting you know that this game is♥♥♥♥♥♥and has no business being branded as a Resident Evil title.What am I even playing? Like, seriously?  1. "here, have a control scheme / camera that feels like a sloppy mix of RE4 and Max Payne"    - movement / strafing is really tacky, and looking around feels super awkward  2. "here, have a ub3r 1337 scan gun and scan every single square inch of the map for bonus pointz!"    - are we playing Metroid Prime now???  3. "here, run around with a useless buddy character who does nothing except add corny dialogue"    - ok.. he/she *occasionally* shoots Hunters, buy only after I've dumped an entire magazine into them  4. "here, have a bunch of sequenced, linear missions as opposed to exploring the map and solving puzzles"    - RE4 was a game changer and many games copied its style. But it's time to rethink the formula again.  5. "here, have a bunch of awkward, poorly written cutscenes that could have been straight out of a Michael Bay film"    - ......no words  etc. etc. etc.Overall, this game feels like the outcome of a summer project, thrown together by interns who were too high for their own good. I know what you're capable of, Capcom. With a passionate team and a proper budget, you can create an absolute masterpiece. But this ain't one of them. Not even close.P.S. I realize I'm ~5 years late playing this. I'm really looking forward to RE7, which so far looks to be about 10000x better than this heap. All my <3

												This is a game about a loser guy named Cristopher trying to find his wife, but then it turns out she's actually on a boat full of monsters. Ring any ♥♥♥♥ing bells yet? It should, because that exact same thing was done years ago, and it was called Silent Hill 2 and was actually good. Too bad Crapcom can't make good games without ripping off people who know what they're doing. Anyway, Cris gets a letter from Jane Valentine (Is she supposed to be related to Vincent Valentine from Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children? Get REAL, Crapcock.) and has to find her on a boat. But he can't ♥♥♥♥ing find her. How hard is it to find a boat, Cris? IT'S AN OCEAN. THERE IS LITERALLY NOTHING IN IT BUT BOATS. So you have to play as Jane, and you have to spend all your ♥♥♥♥ing time looking at people with your Fisher Price Monster Scanner kit, to figure out if they're monsters or not. Meanwhile Cris is suddenly on a ♥♥♥♥ing MOUNTAIN? What. There are no ♥♥♥♥ing boats on a mountain, you prick. Crap♥♥♥♥ is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ developer who can not even REMEMBER what it happening IN THEIR OWN GAMES. It just gets worse from there. Really, it would be a lot better if this wasn't such a HUGE Silent Hill ripoff, except set on a boat. And don't even get me started on the Raid Mode, which is pretty much all the worst elements from World of Warcraft, slapped into a half-baked retard grind marathon.SCORES:Graphics: 6/10. This used to be a Game Boy Advance game, and you can tell. However, one chick gets horribly and painfully turned into a terrible monster and begs you to kill her, except she has her♥♥♥♥♥♥out the entire time, and it's pretty clear that the devs were literally masturbating while designing their ♥♥♥♥♥ Zombie. So it gets points for zombie♥♥♥♥♥♥Music: 3/10. The game does not have music.Gameplay: 7/10. You point the Scan Man 3000 at a zombie, and a little bar fills up and you get a herb. Then I guess you smoke that herb or something. Since the game is 420 friendly it gets bonus points.Story: 5/10. Again, Silent Hill did it better.FINAL SCORE: B-YOU MIGHT ENJOY THIS GAME IF...You get crazy boners from bloody zombie ♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												I've played this game for a little over an hour. I couldn't stand to play it for any longer. I watched DansGaming play it a bit during his Halloween Horror Game Marathon.____I had a choice. Spend my funds on RE4 or on RE Revelations. For the sake of going with something new, I chose the latter and now I deeply regret my decision. I should have done a bit more research. Like another reviewer pointed out, RE Revelations plays like a boring and stripped down version of RE4. And it adds a new, super annoying feature whose purpose I do not understand. A bioscanner. After you kill monsters you can scan their bodies and if you scan enough of their bodies you get some sort of bonus (I think it was a life bonus or something like that). That doesn't sound too bad, does it? Well, it's not bad. The part that infuriates me is that you need the scanner to find ALL ITEMS. Walk into a room, it's empty. Wait, use your bioscanner scanner to look around the room, and aha! There's that apparently organic ammo you needed. Or that keycard you need to open that door. What an absolutley silly, timewasting, and nonsensical feature.Unfortunately, this game has bigger problems than just a silly loot finding system. The graphics are bad, the atmosphere is mediocre, the characters and dialogue are terribly written, and the combat is unrefined, depthless, and above-all, boring.  I don't understand the positive reviews for the game. If I could return this game, I would in a heartbeat.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Don't let the hours on this game fool you, I've played it before (this was gifted to me). Trying to give this another go after failing to peak my interest the first time, I couldn't do it. I have problems sleeping, unless I play this game. This game is so mind numbingly boring that it makes me sleepy. Running from room to room gunning down the same types of monsters gets obviously repetitive and the game has absolutely no scare factor. I've played every single Resident Evil game I can think of, and I even like the terrible first person Resident Evil more than this back in the day of the first Playstation. The only thing horrific about this game is that it is an abomination to the Resident Evil classic feel. Those that claim it has that feeling must be delusional, or they don't remember the older games. I've played it on the hardest difficulty and rarely ran out of ammo, there was absolutely nothing that made me jump or think "Oh man, I can't believe that one guy I don't remember died". I honestly think I'm only going to play this until I get the maximum amount of trading cards possible from this.If you're itching for that Resident Evil feeling, don't play this. If you wan't to play it for the story, just watch the sequences on youtube or something. Or read the wiki. I'd slap the person who gifted this to me, as I think it was more of an insult to me.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												This game is a mobile game turned PC/ console without any major changes to it whatsoever.     The gameplay is the same, so for a PC, it is extemely limited. You'd have a hard time squeezing more than 30 hours out of this title for what little there is to do in the game.     The sheer quality of the game is lackluster at best. They didn't add or improve any textures at all to fit a larger screen than a 3DS. The enemies and enviroment are bland in the best case scenario, and most of the enviroments are repeated in the game. It feels like a lot of pointless running around because of the lack of fresh content.     The story was pretty terrible if you never read the Divine Comedy, because you just have nothing to relate to the plot's only allusion. The story lacks any form of symbolism, and frankly the character line up is worse than ever (ANY other title). It looks like they turned from even moderately paced action shooters like 4 or 5 and tried to tie the experience to a survival horror. The problem is that it lacks any of the puzzles that a survival horror should have, and without a story, it has nothing to offer the player motivation to complete the title.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												I wish I could write two reviews seriously. One for campaign and one for RaidCampaign:While flawed the campgain is decent enough given if you remember its 3ds roots. Story is pretty typical of modern RE so theres no real serious surprises, the enemies are over all fun to fight and weapons are solid.overall 7/10Raid: oh man.... what the hell were they thinking? I've played Free to play mmos with less grind than this, horribly slow level system that serves purely as a gate, a grind you must get through just to be "this tall to ride" the next grind which is grinding to get weapons and custom parts.  Unless someone boosts you raid will take stupidly long to get anywhere, and still terribly long even with a boost. On top of this fact that the two early teirs; Chasm and Trench, may as well not even exist as you get nothing substantial from it. Raid doesn't even "begin" till abyss cause thats when you start to get your more perfect weapons and custom parts that actually can change gameplay styles. so imagine suffering through 30 levels or so and roughly around 50 hours to even get to abyss and thats if you got a partner and think if that sounds fun.overall 2/10I still recommend the game for the campaign only really. I have not gotten to play raid in RE:RE:2 but I can only hope they improved on the formula cause alot of bad gameplay choices here.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I haven't played most of the RE series so it's hard for me to be a fair judge of this. Basically, from what I've read and watched on the internet, this goes more back to its roots in the first RE series, where it's supposed to be survival horror. The thing is, is that the survial element is in, but not the horror; I've played games like Slender, Dead Space, and Alan Wake, and sorry to those who like RE, there is NO horror element found here. Just the frustrating survival element that's more irrate than survival.Pros: The game looks really nice; graphics, textures, modles, the works. Everything looks nextgen.Cons: Aside from what I've listed at the top, that's pretty much it. There is nothing good here. The story is dry, and boring (seriously, first 5 minutes in the game I was watching a cutscene, I was like "I don't give a flying ♥♥♥♥, SKIP".), the characters are as planned as the story, and the voice acting was subpar at most.Gameplay: Now like I said, I never played the first RE titles, just RE5, which I loved. But in accordance to that, it feels like I'm not some bad♥♥♥♥♥agent, but more like someone saving every single bullet I come accross, which is what most combat is like; you're not killing the zeds, you're running from them. Because heaven forbid you come accross a hallway blocked by zeds, and you can't shoot your way out, you have to ♥♥♥♥ing knife them. If not, you have to run and dodge them. The dodge system is simlar to Alan Wake's in that you have to time you're enemies attack to get out of the way. This would be good, except that it's the same button as the 180 degree turn. If you don't time it perfectly, which I suck btw at stuff like this, you'll turn and face the wrong way and eat♥♥♥♥♥♥ The enemies vary their attacks to a quick jab, to a haymaker type punch; hard to time this♥♥♥♥♥♥ but then again, that's just me. They also done away with the life bar; basically, three hits and you're dead. I preferred more an action based game, not...what ever this is. Again, I've never played the originals, but if they were anything like this, I'd stay away.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												Resident Evil Revelations is kind of Capcoms apology about Resident Evil 5 & 6 being more about shooting zombies and less about horror gameplay, and it tries to be a bit like Resident Evil 4, but fails at it.Resident Evil Revelations's greatest shortcoming is that it's mostly just boring and average. The story is boring, the characters are boring, the gameplay is boring, the graphics are average. When this game originally released on the 3DS it looked very impressive on the small screen, but now it's not so impressive on a 1080p screen.If you are desperate for a horror game to play, RE Revelations is probably better than 90% of the indie horror games that are currently flooding Steam, but that isn't saying much.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												Revelations is Resident Evil done right. This game was AMAZING on the 3DS, and I'm currently re-downloading it for the PC for another playthru. The main campaign is decently lengthy, and the upgrade system is decent. I'm not one for extra modes or Mercenaries on the other games, but Raid Mode is a blast. Great for challenge-seekers. If you've never played this before, or are just curious about the series, this is a good place to start, provided youread a little about the story first. If not, you'll get to know the characters soon enough, but the background helps a little. Just buy it. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												In quality and overall fun, it far outstrips its status as a mere "gaiden" game!  Lightly textured but nicely modeled and animated, it exhibits an attractive "Hyper Dreamcast" style that doesn't overload the optic nerves with absurdly realistic textile weave.  Limited ammo and herbs make things a lot more survival horror-esque than 4, 5 and 6, but when you run out of something, you can scan your surroundings with a little viewfinder that identifies hidden items.  It's a great crutch to have if you find yourself in a sloppy gameplay session!  Viewfinder usage is never too onerous, and it's downright AWESOME if you've got an obsessive-compulsive inner beast that craves a massage.  The contextual dodge mechanic (you joggle the stick in a certain direction right before the blow falls) is a little weird at first, but it actually works beautifully in one-on-one encounters.  You're better off running from mobs, but let's face it; what game lets you duck an entire horde of misshapen gropers? Revelations has a perfect RE story, one that's even worthy of a mainline game.  You know what that means, RE fans:  it's a convoluted, monster-packed mess dripping with so much cheese sauce that it will give you gout, and it is positively glorious!  Let me explain something to the uninitiated; RE stories are good not just because they're cheesy fun, or just because they've got oodles of hideous monsters, but because they are leavened with real creativity and intelligence.  It's wonderfully dumb spectacle plus deep mythos.  Unkillable action heroes with one-liners striving against organizations with (sometimes insanely) complex motivations.  Ridiculously twisty plotting with expert pacing.  Not many AAA actioners (game or film) can suck you in like an RE can into its coincidence-laden universe of pustulant monsters!

												Returning to its roots as a survival horror franchise, Resident Evil Revelations is a top notch game with a storyline that will have you on the edge of your seat for the length of the game wondering just what the heck is going on. number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2013
												As a huge fan of RE4 and even RE5, I really enjoyed this 3DS port. What I enjoyed of the previous games was the over the shoulder camera and having to watch your ammo while you fight monsters. There are many differences of course, good but not necessarily better, though certainly not worse.GENERAL INFOIf you've played RE4/5 you'll know generally what to expect here, if not check out screenshots and videos for this game. The vast majority of the game takes place on a large cruise ship. During the course of the game you will explore it and find keys that unlock more of the ship to progress the story. Every once in a while the game will switch to a different duo and play as them for a little while with preset weapons. Not my favorite parts but they do help break up the monotony of the ship and explain more of the story.GUNSWhere the game shines are the weapons and upgrades. You can have any 3 weapons equipped, even 3 pistols if you wanted though that's stupid. There are pistols, shotguns, smgs/assault rifles, long range rifles, and magnums. For each weapon type there are different guns you will find with differing stats. When you find a gun and take it back to your storage box thing you will have it forever (the gun you dropped is returned too). This is how you switch out your guns and change their upgrades, you can't do it anywhere for obvious balance reasons. Upgrading guns is a lot of fun. Each gun has anywhere from 1 to 5 slots for upgrades, and you can apply upgrades and take them off at will. Upgrades include the standard fare of higher damage, higher bullet capacity, faster reload, etc. and many more unique ones.YOUR AI PARTNERBy far the biggest advantage this game has, especially over RE5, is that although you have an AI partner he can safely be ignored. In RE5 even if you were playing solo, you still had to manage your AI partners inventory and keep them alive, but thankfully they were generally fairly smart though still a hassle. Here your AI partner is invincible, the enemies pretty much always push past him to come after you, and while your partner can shoot they rarely seem to. Are they useless? Yes. Do they stay out of your way and present no hassle for you and let you enjoy the single player experience you want? Thank goodness yes! Of course you can play co-op if you wanted, but it's far from forced.PLAYTHROUGH INFOYour first playthrough on normal if you are reasonably thorough and don't try to rush it will take you about 8-10 hours. Like in RE4 there is a new game+ mode where you keep all your weapons and ammo from before and start over. That's already fun, but this game has an infernal difficulty which you can, and are probably expected to, play on a new game+. This mode features a lot more enemies, enemies in different places than normal, and even enemies early on you wouldn't normally see until later in the game. Furthermore, items are in different places and nothing at all like on normal. Infernal mode is practically a whole new game!RAID MODEAs if all this wasn't awesome enough there's this RPG-progression-like mode called Raid Mode. In it you do a quick mission where your goal is to find the exit. There are many of these missions, and as you do them you gain experience which allows you to level up. The higher level missions will let you find higher level weapons, of which you need to be the appropriate level to wield. The weapons will have increased stats and effects, very similar to Borderlands random gun drops. You can prepare for each mission using what you've earned/bought. Yes there is a store which resets every time you enter it. You can easily spend dozens of hours on this mode alone. This mode can also be played in co-op if you wish.CONCLUSIONIf you liked RE4/5 definitely check this game out, you aren't likely to be disappointed. If you've never played them before take a look at some lets plays for a good idea.P.S. Review was 1700 chars too long, had to shorten >.<.

Supposed to be some elite group but one of them is disty and falls making a loud noise very start of their chapter?Female hunk, bought that package because I was curious but dissapointed to find out it is hunk with no pants?If hunk is playable, why the hell is Tofu not!?!?!? (RE2 reference)A lot of the game characters look "greasy" especially this redhead tht remins me of Syndro from The Incredibles Movie! Right? 												The game has correctly scaled back to the idea of ammo conservation, claustraphopic atmospheres and suspense.However,It's shoddy music, cheap jump scares, beyond awful combat mechanics and insultingly easy fights and puzzles that are more irritating than tricky - make me concerned that this was made by an actual legit company. But youll soon forget that the second the horrific, stupid, pointless side characters turn up, with thier own mini missions and humourless jokes.An irritating 5/10 even if you love the old Resi's

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												The game started pretty promising, it had that feel of vulnerability, that focus on exploration. But there is ONE thing that stopped me from playing.Forget the crappy textures, the dumb story, the ridiculous enemies called B.O.Ws (they're more disturbing than scary), or the silly scanning system (at least in Metroid Prime we could actually read on the stuff we scan, here its just for getting health and finding invisible items). Nay, one thing, made me say NEVER AGAIN.That boss. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥that boss. Made me♥♥♥♥♥♥my pants man.There's a reason why survival horror is so distinct from other shooters : you don't want to fight. If you fight, its because you got backed in a corner, that you have no other choice. You use precious resources that you need to manage. You avoid areas with many monsters and use stealth to survive. Sometimes, like in Amnesia : the Dark Descent, you have no weapon at all and must avoid monsters at all costs.Not this game. This game broke my suspension of disbelief so hard I laughed. Don't be fooled, its a silly 3rd person action shooter just like the other "modern" Resident Evils.What happened is this : you arrive in this area. Theres a few monsters, so I pick them off with my pistol. Its a shopping mall. I secure the area (since you can't stealth), get some items, lift open a gate. I hear this weird voice. "Mayday, mayday, help us (...)". Its the comms officer I'm supposed to go find for the key to the communications room. Then i see something wrong : a door is being banged on and shaked and theres a lock on it. Let me ask you : what would any sane person do? Especially in a survival situation? You'd probably GTFO OF THERE RIGHT?But no, you're expected to shoot the lock and release teh creature within. Cuz you need the key. Nevermind that you could pick the lock, or smash the door down. No, its much easier to fight A FRIGGIN' ABOMINATION WITH A FLESHY CHAINSAW FOR AN ARM, THAT RUSHES AT YOU AND INSTA-KILLS YOU!!!Its a typical boss fight. It chases you around the area, enemies spawn EVERYWHERE, and you can only slow it down and damage it by blowing up conveniently placed gas tanks at every corner of the level. Only, theres a few problems.Number one : its the ugliest most disturbing thing ever.Number two : this is an insane difficulty spike compared to the things before.Number three : its dumb and ruined the atmosphere.I was like "NOPE!" I'm sorry but I am not going through that again for any more than a third time. Uninstall!You have been warned. You might like stuff like this, but you can't deny its ♥♥♥♥♥♥ design.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2013
												Been doing this, been satisfied. I'm unsure why people bash Revelations right and left. Granted, it's not the same as the old Resident Evil series on Playstation, for example machine puzzles etc, but it has its own good points. More action oriented for sure.Aside of some minor problems (regarding low sound volume but I've found the fix), RE: R is pretty much ok performance wise. In its early release it was stuttering right and left on my rig, now with the same graphic settings it is silky smooth - after several patches of course.AI wise, can be rather dumb at times and I'm sure it's an annoyance also for many people, but at least it is sufficient to beat Single Player part. As far as I can tell, of course.Story-line wise, well... I'd prefer with the continuation of the latest RE's storyline but can live with this one. Can't complain too much I guess but no spoiler written in this review, though.Coop mode is pretty fun if you can find workaround the lag. Granted my connection ain't da best but I find it a bit weird I can play coop RE6 and Dota 2 just fine when this one can't - after several sessions.And lastly, Jill. <3 What else is there to be said?

Posted: April 10
												This game is a really mixed bag. There is some fun to be had, but also a lot of frusteration and the ratio leans more towards frusteration. I say get it on sale if ur an RE fan but be ready for high highs and low lows.PROS:*Some sections look and feel like RE1*The 1st boss fight is epic*Decent enemy variety*Not too long or too short*Dat♥♥♥♥♥!!!!!Cons:*Horrible and stupid story (even for RE)*Every boss fight besides the 1st are boring and uninspired*Horrible swimming sequences with bad control*Half of the game takes place off of the cruise ship where the best parts of the game are, star boring characters, and are overly action focused spray and preys where no fun can be had*Map system is confusing and you often get lost*Annoying rail shooter sequences*Annoying scanning mechanic that is used too often*You can't ♥♥♥♥ Jill IRL no matter how much you want tooOverall 6/10TLDR: Some of it is really gud, but most of it sucks, but Jill's♥♥♥♥♥is God Tier

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												An obvious but enjoyable schlock side-story to the franchise with a new type enemy archetype and solid fundamental game play. The overall game is old-school resident evil but with over the shoulder controls and the usual silly plot. The game is as focused on over the shoulder combat as RE 4-5-6 but the plot, map, exploration and setting that remind me heavily of resident evil 2.The inventory system is a system of magic-boxes that holds your stored list of gear and weapons and equip-able buff labels that you can find, swap and equip on weapons (closest comparison is warframe F2P game but less confusing).The downside as I see it are that the weapon upgrade and storage system does not fit in will with the story led game-save focused, poorly chaptered game progression. The system has a strong hint of being only half-implemented or something added in mostly for new-game plus (or to allow for more weapon types) it's almost like a first attempt at a DLC platform for some cheeky "bonus" paid for content but with access being strictly limited to in-game storage crate use the save-game based inventory system feels an odd choice.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												This is a really good game for RE fans. The campaign is really entertaining, you can get many different weapons and customize them with many weapon modifcations you find as drop or hidden in the game. The Infernal Difficulty adds an additional challenge and a few further weapon modifications. The raid mode is okay, the idea with different stages, a leveling system and weapons in different variations with upgrades has a nice touch. But it's just a small extra.The only negative thing about this game is, that the coop mode is missing. The game would be even more fun with one.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												This game's story is absolute trash. The plot twists are predictable as ♥♥♥♥ or just plain stupid.If you're looking to shoot zombies, this game isn't for you either. Your main activity will consist of walking through empty hallways hoping to find a zombie to kill or tediously looting lockers for ammo. Killing a zombie never feels rewarding, since their death animation is total garbage, and for some reason there's close to no blood-splatter, regardless of your weapon. The boss fights are unoriginal, and barely require any skill or stratey, just a lot of ammo.  The worst part is that this game completely misses the mark when it comes to horror. Throughout the whole game, you have a literally useless follower tailing you, which completely breaks immersion, and the zombies have♥♥♥♥♥♥AI that allows you to kite them for days. The raid mode is equally disappointing; you get to shoot a few more zombies, but it's really similar to the campaign gameplay. And there's no one playing raid mode online, so don't even bother buying the DLC. The only good part of the game is Jill Valentine's rear. But even that gets dull after the first few chapters. DON'T BUY, NOT EVEN ON SALE! YOU'VE BEEN WARNED!

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Story mode is decent, creating a nice hybrid between modern and classic resident evil (right down to the story taking place pretty much all in one location), but choose your multiplayer partner wisely! Because the raid mode is extremly repetitive and RPG grindy, so you'll need a great partner or a hell of a lot of love for the series to play through it all. It's also worth noting that this is a port of a 3DS title, that's not a bad thing per say, but it is noticable in terms of the scale and variety in the game.The games at it's best the few times it manages to pull off even a half decent jump scare and how they've broken the story mode into chunks like episodes, but besides that? It's just capcom trying to reclaim the series' glory days and only somewhat succeeding.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												I'm a big RE fan, platinum on RE5 and a ridiculous game saves on past installments. RE6 originally rustled my jimmiesso badly that I skipped this game on the 3ds, and I don't think I really missed all that much on relase. You don't exactly have a big array of enamies, and instead of having things you can easily take out by being smart you have some enemies that are just there to soak up bullets if you can't run, wait, I mean merrily jog away. Where the heck is the run button??? Maybe the low speed adds some tension, but more often then not I found myself getting really frustrated with backtracking through enemyless segments with Jill having a happy jog through rooms that all look the freaking same! What son of a biscuit did the level design for this game? Aside from there being more than one ship that is EXACTLY THE SAME TO THE POINT WHERE ONLY THE CASINO IS OPEN ON BOTH OF THEM WHY. Even when you're grounded in that you're on the same ship, the game tends to have rooms that look so similar that you end up going in the opposite direction. Objective cursor is inconsistant.If you can't look past a lot of things and accept its flaws this game might not be for you.

Posted: October 23, 2015
												8/10It is true to it's original 3DS version. It still holds up as an excellent co-op game. Don't expect too much horror. The game itself is more action focused with a horror esthetic. The stages are fun to explore and there are so many ways to customize guns.My only real knock against this game has to do with the story mode. You'll have to switch up player characters frequently. Most of the characters are reasonably equipped, with the exception of one -who feels under-equipped for the game.Regardless, this game is good in single player and co-op. Raid Mode is the best!

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I'm not sure why this game was made, I would have rather they put their resources into making a PC/console Mercenaries game. The limitations of the 3DS hardware were more apparent when playing this PC port and overall I didn't like any of the new characters or the story. Mechanically it felt more rigid than RE5 as well due to hardware limitations. People claim it's better than RE6, but I find that hilarious when the whole game takes place on a ship or a snowy mountain and RE6 had BOTH those environments plus A COUPLE DOZEN MORE, and it was overall a way more ambitious and complex game than this. Mercenaries is also way cooler than Raid mode. I mean there's been worse RE games than Revelations, but I was really not impressed by it.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												Resident Evil Revelations is an amazing game. It goes back to what made the original games survival horror icons. It is much more for the fans of those types of games rather than something like Resident Evil 5 or 6. I highly recommend this game. If you love Resident Evil in all its forms, maybe excluding The Umbrella Chronicles, you will love this game. I myself haven't played that one but I don't hear great things. I love how it has some modern elements while also sticking more closely to its roots. No wonder the sequel is also doing so well. I highly recomment this to any Resident Evil fan especially fans of the old survival horror elements mixed with RE 4 over the shoulder and controls.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												This game's story is absolute trash. The plot twists are predictable as ♥♥♥♥ or just plain stupid.If you're looking to shoot zombies, this game isn't for you either. Your main activity will consist of walking through empty hallways hoping to find a zombie to kill or tediously looting lockers for ammo. Killing a zombie never feels rewarding, since their death animation is total garbage, and for some reason there's close to no blood-splatter, regardless of your weapon. The boss fights are unoriginal, and barely require any skill or stratey, just a lot of ammo.  The worst part is that this game completely misses the mark when it comes to horror. Throughout the whole game, you have a literally useless follower tailing you, which completely breaks immersion, and the zombies have♥♥♥♥♥♥AI that allows you to kite them for days. The raid mode is equally disappointing; you get to shoot a few more zombies, but it's really similar to the campaign gameplay. And there's no one playing raid mode online, so don't even bother buying the DLC. The only good part of the game is Jill Valentine's rear. But even that gets dull after the first few chapters. DON'T BUY, NOT EVEN ON SALE! YOU'VE BEEN WARNED!
