content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
 An overall huge improvement over Resident Evil 5. Revelations goes back to Resident Evil's roots, playing as series veteran Jill Valentine investigating an abandoned cruise ship in the middle of the ocean, while trying to survive the horrors lurking all over the ship. Revelations also adds a new mode called Raid mode, and it's very addicting. Raid mode lets you run through multiple sections for the main story facing leveled enemies in an arcade like mode. As you keep playing Raid mode, you will level up and unlock more weapons. The weapons also have a Borderlands like flair to them, with some of them having special effects and some being rarer than others. In short, Raid mode is a very fun, very addicting new addition to the Resi series.However, the main downsides of the game is every section that doesn't take place on the ship. The sections outside the ship feel more like Resi 6, where you fight wave of enemies with plenty of ammo to go around. The survival horror aspect is thrown out the window during these segments. The game would've been much better without these segments.Other than that, I'd give Resident Evil: Revelations a 6/10. Would've been a 7, but again the aforementioned action segments of the game aren't great, and there's a lot of them. If you like horror games but don't mind a bit of action on the side, then you'll enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												This may be a decent game on it's own, but I'm reviewing this game from a Resident Evil fan's perspective. This game was a nightmare for me, literally. I could not force myself to play more than 15 minutes each time I try. It just doesn't have the same Resident Evil feeling that I get from previous RE 1-5. The style of the game is much different, the gameplay is weird, the monsters are weird, the story is weak, and they resort to a lot of 'jump scares' instead of the normal tension building or suspense scares. The only thing I like about this game is the graphics. This will be the first RE game I will not complete and I will go back to play RE 1-5 again. They're straying a bit too far away from the normal formula that makes the game what it is. Now it's becoming something else that we don't need, a first person shooter. This is what happens when RE meets Call of Duty or Battlefield. What next? Zombies/Monsters will know Kung Fu and have weapons as well so it'll become Tekken or Halo?Pros:- Good graphics.Cons:- Mainly jump scares. No tension building or suspense from previous titles.- Weak story.- Too much weapon and ammo. It's like Call of Duty meets Resident Evil.- No zombies. At least add some. Monsters are weird and some invisible... really.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												This is a very interesting video game, there are plenty of points to address, and I have not come to the conclusion, as of this review.  The points  First and foremost, the writing is simply atrocious, the relationships between the characters were composed by someone who had only heard about the concept of 'partnership' from an acquaintance telling them about an episode of 'Desperate Housewives' The combat, thus far, is extremely simplistic and one could master the controls with little contrivence, I am quite fond of the aspect of left clicking to attack with a melee weapon and holding right to aim your firearm and left clicking to fire, it allows for as-smooth-as-this-game-can-be combat. Unfortunately from what I have played thus far, the map is linear, which I have come to expect from 'Resident Evil' games, but the area in which you are allowed to frolic free, is less than a corridor, which in turn reveals how un-coordinated the 'Artificial Intelligence' (AI) is.  'Un-coordinated'  is an understatement, this AI wouldn't so much as  fail  the 'Turing Test' it would be banised from the facility where the test is held.  Conclusion But aside from the abhorrent writing and (Lack thereof) AI I will recommend  Resident Evil: (Most Generic Subtitle Award Nominee) Revelations  for the time being, for it is mindless entertainment, and if, for whatever reason you have several hours to spare, this is a brilliant 'Time-Waster' so to speak.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												One of the latest Resident Evil titles to come out at the time of this review, June 2014, Revelations is a new entry in the franchise that originally came out for the Nintendo 3DS in 2012. The title was generally very well-received and, not a full year later, Capcom annouced that the title would be released to household consoles and PC. The story behind this title presents a difficult reality that I feel must be tackled right off the bat: this is a handheld game being ported to a household console, so it features a limited budget. The implications behind this statement are huge. Every single aspect of this game will (most likely) not be on par with every other game being released alongside this title. However, that doesn't mean this game is bad. A game is a system that's worth far more than the sum of its individual parts. Resident Evil 6, the other recent release at the time of writing, was a competent triple-A game with impressive visuals and full-fledged controls that allowed you to roll out of the way, lay on the floor, place explosives, take cover behind objects and other actions necessary for that game's core loop. However, it is very easy to see how one might not consider that a standard Resident Evil experience. Luckily, Revelations is the most classic-like Resident Evil game to be released since the mid 2000's, when the final remakes of the original Resident Evil and the last Outbreak entry were released.Do keep in mind, though, that this game strikes a balance: it is not the return of old-school survival horror that every hardcore fan of the series seems to be crying out for. The controls closely resembles an updated version of what was initially set established by Resident Evil 4 and barely modified in Resident Evil 5. Your camera is placed above your shoulder and always face what your avatar is looking at, you can strafe, aim and shoot. Perhaps the biggest addition to the controls is the fact that you can, finally, shoot and move at the same time. Overall, the gameplay works well and feels really tight. With a core set of mechanics being matched by well designed enemies.In most chapters you'll play as Jill Valentine aboard a derelict cruise ship, those are the chapters that feature the classic horror atmosphere and feeling. But in other chapters, that can be quite numerous, you'll play as different characters like Chris Redfield, Keith "Grinder" Lumley and Parker Luciani. It is during these chapters that the gameplay is changed to something that closely resembles the more modern Resident Evil gameplay experience: you get plenty of ammunition and level challenges usually boil down to surviving enemy waves or fighting through enemies to get to safety. Though, as in most games of the franchise, the general gameplay will naturally shift its focus towards something very similar to what is presented in these secondary chapters as the narrative reaches its climax and approaches the ending.The game's narrative is an interesting beast. While I personally loved the narrative and the plot twist in it, it is undeniable that Revelations makes use of some really exaggerated characters that draw a lot from the, sometimes ridiculous, world of Japanese animation. They're not many, but they are key personalities in the narrative that end up getting their fair share of screen time. The story segments featured in the secondary chapters are used to explain or advance the plot without having to rely on the magical convenience that every single answer to the game's mystery is aboard the Queen Zenobia.The narrative always pairs you up with a partner, but the game features no cooperative play in the campaign, being only available in RAID mode. The partner is controlled by an AI that does its best to stay out of your way: it deals almost no damage to enemies and, in turn, is mostly ignored by them. This results in a gameplay that feels more like the original games, when there were no partners around, even though there is someone there with you to be used by the narrative to advance the plot.In terms of additional information, I could list that the game's campaign features three difficulty modes (Casual, Normal and Inferno) and the highest difficulty features scrambled puzzles and new enemy placement that is supposed to breath some life into the game even after you've beaten it once and feel like the story mode has nothing else for you. Item boxes are back, but with a twist. Puzzle items like keys, cards and other miscellaneous items are stored in their own separate inventory that never runs out of space. Ammunition is stored separately as well, with each type having a maximum amount the character may carry. These quantities can be expanded by finding particular items, but the extra ammo you find must be left in place since you cannot store it in the box. You can carry up to three weapons at any time and that's where the item boxes come in play: you use them to swap weapons and parts. Parts are upgrades that you may find for your weapons throughout the journey, they exist in the campaign but have no significant impact in your performance. They are, however, a big deal in RAID mode.RAID mode is an alternate game mode that is unlocked as you beat the game for the first time. In it you get to choose an environment from the single-player campaign and play it with any character and weapons you choose. Enemies feature a life bar in this mode that help you make tactical decisions and there are special enemy types. These special enemies, sadly, are only enlarged or shrinked versions of the standard enemies with a distinguishable symbol that indicates how their behavior has been modified. You have strong enemies that deal extra damage, agile enemies that are smaller and move faster and many others. This mode's objective is to navigate the environment, dealing with any enemies along the way, and destroy the symbol that is at the end of the level. You usually don't have to kill every enemy to proceed, but some levels make use of chained doors and segments to force you to face a large enemy force, when you finish off the last enemy in the wave you'll get a padlock key that unlocks the way forward. The levels implement this mechanic in a wide range of success: some are really memorable, some are really annoying. There are no NPC's in this mode, it is a straight-up fight up until the very end.However, as has been mentioned before, enemies have health bars and they help you make tactical decisions. But that's not all they do, they also help you gauge your character's efficiency. Unlike the single-player campaign, RAID mode features a heavy RPG influence, something akin to what's seen in Monster Hunter and other action RPG's. Players have a RAID level, any characters they use deal and take damage based that level and the level of the monster they're interacting with. As you face more advanced environments, the enemy level increases. As a result, you'll deal less damage while taking more damage. The RPG influence on RAID mode goes even further: weapons have levels too and you'll need to grind for more levels and better weapons (you can't level up your weapons) as you progress through the different environments. You'll also have to buy items and ammo to supply your runs on each map. The whole mode provides an action RPG experience that, in my opinion, is overall superior to the usual Mercenaries mode. But I'm not a fan of being bound to stats, since the rest of the game is really about resource management and reaction time.If you like Resident Evil, then you probably won't mind paying full price for this game. Othewise, you might want to get it at a discount. Finally, I'd say that Resident Evil Revelations is not the game fans claim they want, not yet. But if future installments take inspiration from Revelations and continue to place horror first, then at least we're headed in the right direction.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2013
												I remember reading somewhere that this game is supposed to be a remake of the older Resident Evil games like 4 and 5, showing what happened "before" and such. After playing the game myself, I can say with confidence that they went over the top with the remake, it feels like a game from 2000s, outdated graphics, clunky controls, messy video settings and a cheesy arcade storyline with almost nothing interesting happening {at least in the first couple of chapters}You get to play as Jill and Chris, you can walk/jog around with WASD, turn 180 degrees, aim/fire with mouse, that's about all you get to do. No jumping, dodging, sprinting, combos or any depth to the melee system, no QTEs either. There's absolutely nothing special about the game mechanics, it's the bare basics.The thing that bugged me most was the letterbox {if you don't own a widescreen monitor}, meaning you'll be seeing black blocks on top and bottom of the screen which you can't disable.This game is inferior to Resident Evil 5, Resident Evil Op Raccoon City and Resident Evil 6 in every possible way. It's like they've made this game in 2005, shelved it, started working on other games, and now just releasing it as a new game. It feels that "cheap" in quality. I'm sure you can still have fun but not after having played the other newer titles in the series.You have been warned. Buy Resident Evil 6 instead, you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												The Resident Evil series has had its ups and its downs from the greats of  the franchise like 2,3 Code Veronica and 4 to the worst entries (survivor,0,5 Raccoon city and 6) but this game is definately a decent entry and probably the only entry since darkside chronicles that is actually fun to play.The story of the game is basically that Jill Valentine is trying to find her partner Chris "steroid junkie" Redfield who has mysteriously gone missing. This game also takes place before 5 although some things like Jills older look (though I guess that you could put that down to the fact that the game was originally done on a Nintendo console) and some of the technology available like the fact of a city built on the water are hard to believe because of the timeline.The gameplay is a lot like that of 6 in the fact that you can move whie aiming but with the restraints of 4 in terms of melee combat. There is also a dodge feature that Jill originally had in 3 but it isn't as reliable as that one as you can never be too sure if it is going to register properly and this can be a problem as some of the enemies and bosses play out that you can damage them by dodging them when they go to charge at you whic will leave them open to attack.You can only carry a total of three guns at one time and ammo is actually scarce if you play on normal and if you feel up to the challenge, infernal. The upgrade system for guns is also back but you can never really upgrade them enough to think that you can kill everything and still complete the game with loads of ammo for every gun. The upgrades are also interchangeable so you can change what your guns atributes are if you want to tr using it to stun enemies more of veen give one of them a burst ability.The order in which you get weapon types is a bit weird in the whole fact that you can end up getting the stronger version of a weapon type before you get the weaker versions and some of the weaker versions can only be gotten by doing things like playing he game on infernal as that is the only mode that they appear on.Overall if you are a fan of the series of old, mainly 4, and want to play a decent modern Resi game then you should definately give this game a tryscore 86/100

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												I'm not sure what precisely other people see in this game. Is it just nostalgia for old Resident Evil because RE5 and RE6 were so awful? You can try to put lipstick on a pig all you want, this game is decidedly medicore. The old tank like controls for RE aren't the least bit compelling without a decent atmosphere to help it along. The optimization attempt during the conversion from a portable platform (Nintendo 3DS) to PC is laughably substandard. It looks like middle-gen PS2 game at best. I realize that plot and dialogue (Yay for Jessica's "sweet♥♥♥♥♥") have never been the priority for any RE games, but in Revelations, it's comically absurd and don't get me started and the laughably bad character designs. The gameplay and level design are just so bland. Again, this was ported from a portable platform and Capcom did little to hide it. The limitations show at all times.I get where Capcom was trying to go with this in trying to satisfy RE fans, but this feels more like a mockery than fan service. This game probably should have remained on portables unless Capcom was willing to port this to the PC correctly.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												While RE:Revelations wasn't horrible, it... wasn't a very good game either.Revelations suffered from many gameplay idiocies that more modern games have been plagued with. Here are just a few:This door is blocked/locked from the other side, jump through the huge window to get inside.-Why make me go through that trouble? Just have the door unlocked.My partner has the key to unlock the door, but insted of unlocking it himself, he gives me the key so I can unlock it.-Again, WHY!? Just have the NPC unlock the door. I had to walk past a locked door (with a fingerprint scanner), walk down a hall with no other doors, go into a room and wait for my character to register her fingerprint into a system, so that I can walk back down the hall to unlock the door I had to pass. -WHYYYYYYY!? Just don't put a lock on the ♥♥♥♥ing door! The game has so many dumb design descisions that make little to no sense all for the sake of making the game feel longer. The old Resident Evil titles had some of this, but the backtracking and running around and performing seemingly pointless tasks always had a meaningful reason. The character movement also feels really sluggish, and sometimes the character would not perform tasks when I was mashing on the buttons (throwing grenades) which led to a lot of other-wise avoidable deaths. This may be a side-effect of the port from the Nintendo DS, but is something that should have been given a little more considderation when making the move to PC. As critical as my review sounds... in general this is not a horrible installment in the Resident Evil franchise. It's leaps and bounds better then Resident Evil 6, but I can't really see a reason to play this game unless you get it in a bundle (as I did), or its on sale. The fun moments in this game are few and far between, letting the light spend more time shining on the shortcomings of the game's overall design. Hopefully Revelations 2 has learned from these mistakes. 2/5

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												One of the latest Resident Evil titles to come out at the time of this review, June 2014, Revelations is a new entry in the franchise that originally came out for the Nintendo 3DS in 2012. The title was generally very well-received and, not a full year later, Capcom annouced that the title would be released to household consoles and PC. The story behind this title presents a difficult reality that I feel must be tackled right off the bat: this is a handheld game being ported to a household console, so it features a limited budget. The implications behind this statement are huge. Every single aspect of this game will (most likely) not be on par with every other game being released alongside this title. However, that doesn't mean this game is bad. A game is a system that's worth far more than the sum of its individual parts. Resident Evil 6, the other recent release at the time of writing, was a competent triple-A game with impressive visuals and full-fledged controls that allowed you to roll out of the way, lay on the floor, place explosives, take cover behind objects and other actions necessary for that game's core loop. However, it is very easy to see how one might not consider that a standard Resident Evil experience. Luckily, Revelations is the most classic-like Resident Evil game to be released since the mid 2000's, when the final remakes of the original Resident Evil and the last Outbreak entry were released.Do keep in mind, though, that this game strikes a balance: it is not the return of old-school survival horror that every hardcore fan of the series seems to be crying out for. The controls closely resembles an updated version of what was initially set established by Resident Evil 4 and barely modified in Resident Evil 5. Your camera is placed above your shoulder and always face what your avatar is looking at, you can strafe, aim and shoot. Perhaps the biggest addition to the controls is the fact that you can, finally, shoot and move at the same time. Overall, the gameplay works well and feels really tight. With a core set of mechanics being matched by well designed enemies.In most chapters you'll play as Jill Valentine aboard a derelict cruise ship, those are the chapters that feature the classic horror atmosphere and feeling. But in other chapters, that can be quite numerous, you'll play as different characters like Chris Redfield, Keith "Grinder" Lumley and Parker Luciani. It is during these chapters that the gameplay is changed to something that closely resembles the more modern Resident Evil gameplay experience: you get plenty of ammunition and level challenges usually boil down to surviving enemy waves or fighting through enemies to get to safety. Though, as in most games of the franchise, the general gameplay will naturally shift its focus towards something very similar to what is presented in these secondary chapters as the narrative reaches its climax and approaches the ending.The game's narrative is an interesting beast. While I personally loved the narrative and the plot twist in it, it is undeniable that Revelations makes use of some really exaggerated characters that draw a lot from the, sometimes ridiculous, world of Japanese animation. They're not many, but they are key personalities in the narrative that end up getting their fair share of screen time. The story segments featured in the secondary chapters are used to explain or advance the plot without having to rely on the magical convenience that every single answer to the game's mystery is aboard the Queen Zenobia.The narrative always pairs you up with a partner, but the game features no cooperative play in the campaign, being only available in RAID mode. The partner is controlled by an AI that does its best to stay out of your way: it deals almost no damage to enemies and, in turn, is mostly ignored by them. This results in a gameplay that feels more like the original games, when there were no partners around, even though there is someone there with you to be used by the narrative to advance the plot.In terms of additional information, I could list that the game's campaign features three difficulty modes (Casual, Normal and Inferno) and the highest difficulty features scrambled puzzles and new enemy placement that is supposed to breath some life into the game even after you've beaten it once and feel like the story mode has nothing else for you. Item boxes are back, but with a twist. Puzzle items like keys, cards and other miscellaneous items are stored in their own separate inventory that never runs out of space. Ammunition is stored separately as well, with each type having a maximum amount the character may carry. These quantities can be expanded by finding particular items, but the extra ammo you find must be left in place since you cannot store it in the box. You can carry up to three weapons at any time and that's where the item boxes come in play: you use them to swap weapons and parts. Parts are upgrades that you may find for your weapons throughout the journey, they exist in the campaign but have no significant impact in your performance. They are, however, a big deal in RAID mode.RAID mode is an alternate game mode that is unlocked as you beat the game for the first time. In it you get to choose an environment from the single-player campaign and play it with any character and weapons you choose. Enemies feature a life bar in this mode that help you make tactical decisions and there are special enemy types. These special enemies, sadly, are only enlarged or shrinked versions of the standard enemies with a distinguishable symbol that indicates how their behavior has been modified. You have strong enemies that deal extra damage, agile enemies that are smaller and move faster and many others. This mode's objective is to navigate the environment, dealing with any enemies along the way, and destroy the symbol that is at the end of the level. You usually don't have to kill every enemy to proceed, but some levels make use of chained doors and segments to force you to face a large enemy force, when you finish off the last enemy in the wave you'll get a padlock key that unlocks the way forward. The levels implement this mechanic in a wide range of success: some are really memorable, some are really annoying. There are no NPC's in this mode, it is a straight-up fight up until the very end.However, as has been mentioned before, enemies have health bars and they help you make tactical decisions. But that's not all they do, they also help you gauge your character's efficiency. Unlike the single-player campaign, RAID mode features a heavy RPG influence, something akin to what's seen in Monster Hunter and other action RPG's. Players have a RAID level, any characters they use deal and take damage based that level and the level of the monster they're interacting with. As you face more advanced environments, the enemy level increases. As a result, you'll deal less damage while taking more damage. The RPG influence on RAID mode goes even further: weapons have levels too and you'll need to grind for more levels and better weapons (you can't level up your weapons) as you progress through the different environments. You'll also have to buy items and ammo to supply your runs on each map. The whole mode provides an action RPG experience that, in my opinion, is overall superior to the usual Mercenaries mode. But I'm not a fan of being bound to stats, since the rest of the game is really about resource management and reaction time.If you like Resident Evil, then you probably won't mind paying full price for this game. Othewise, you might want to get it at a discount. Finally, I'd say that Resident Evil Revelations is not the game fans claim they want, not yet. But if future installments take inspiration from Revelations and continue to place horror first, then at least we're headed in the right direction.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												The Resident Evil series has had its ups and its downs from the greats of  the franchise like 2,3 Code Veronica and 4 to the worst entries (survivor,0,5 Raccoon city and 6) but this game is definately a decent entry and probably the only entry since darkside chronicles that is actually fun to play.The story of the game is basically that Jill Valentine is trying to find her partner Chris "steroid junkie" Redfield who has mysteriously gone missing. This game also takes place before 5 although some things like Jills older look (though I guess that you could put that down to the fact that the game was originally done on a Nintendo console) and some of the technology available like the fact of a city built on the water are hard to believe because of the timeline.The gameplay is a lot like that of 6 in the fact that you can move whie aiming but with the restraints of 4 in terms of melee combat. There is also a dodge feature that Jill originally had in 3 but it isn't as reliable as that one as you can never be too sure if it is going to register properly and this can be a problem as some of the enemies and bosses play out that you can damage them by dodging them when they go to charge at you whic will leave them open to attack.You can only carry a total of three guns at one time and ammo is actually scarce if you play on normal and if you feel up to the challenge, infernal. The upgrade system for guns is also back but you can never really upgrade them enough to think that you can kill everything and still complete the game with loads of ammo for every gun. The upgrades are also interchangeable so you can change what your guns atributes are if you want to tr using it to stun enemies more of veen give one of them a burst ability.The order in which you get weapon types is a bit weird in the whole fact that you can end up getting the stronger version of a weapon type before you get the weaker versions and some of the weaker versions can only be gotten by doing things like playing he game on infernal as that is the only mode that they appear on.Overall if you are a fan of the series of old, mainly 4, and want to play a decent modern Resi game then you should definately give this game a tryscore 86/100

												So straight up - my resident evil experience isn't huge.  I've played most of RE3, played a bit of 5 on the PS3 and completed 6 also on the PS3 in a co-op run.  This one feels the most like the Resident Evil games I was expecting.  Backtracking, scavenging for loot and some good atmosphere.  The writing is very RE which is to say over the top and great fun but not to be taken too seriosuly.  I enjoyed Revelations and will be trying RE2 in a co-op run as it has that available. Downsides?  The graphics show both its age and the fact we are looking at a HD port of what was a 3DS game origninally I believe but aren't so ugly you can't enjoy the game.  I'd recommend this one but don't buy the weapons DLC.  They're nice but for the campaign which was all I was interested of no use or bonus.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												ONLY BUY THIS GAME ON SALEPros+Game is graphically appealing despite being a 3ds port+The difficulty Infernal truly makes this the HARDEST RE I have EVER played and I have beaten every RE game including Dead Aim and RE: Outbreak Series. The ordinary oozes will kill you in 3-5 depending how they attack you, two enemies kill you instantly if you get caught(The Wall Blitzers and Scagdeads), and your toughest bunch are the hunters and scarmiglones.+Their are NUMEROUS amounts of enemies in the game to keep this game fresh. Their are roughly 14 different unique enemies in the game  with 4 big bosses included in that 14. I don't think any RE has came close to this amount of enemy variey. +Weapon Variety is also consistent with past RE like RE3 and RE Code veronica from, handguns to rifles to the good ole rocket launcher+A new perk called Parts are added to the game to make it a little more easier. When you find these parts, you use them to attach to your weapons to do things such as additional damage, faster fire rate, increase reload space, faster fire rate, and more.+The games new game mode is called RAID MODE. It is a game mode that focuses on completing the levels objectives by killing all the enemies, transporting an object to the objective or simply reach the objective. The game uses the EXACT same levels in the campaign in RAID MODE but just in incriments. ALL the characters in the story are playable in RAID MODE by completing bonuses or reaching a level. 3 of the characters-racheal ooze and Lady hunk. Including your old time favorite,(which btw has not been in an RE canonical story since RE2) HUNK. The mode comes in 3 tiers, Chasm(Easy), Trench(Normal) , and Abyss(Hard). However, ghost ship is unlocked from the start a lvl 50 recommended stage as a way to boost to 50 quick. If you die whether it be you playing solo or you or your coop partner dies in the raid mode stage, you have to start ALL over. Their are no lives and their are not checkpoints. Just to let NEW RE fans know, these additional game modes are NOT new. Additional Game Modes have been here since the Original RE. Battle Mode(RE1, RE2, RE Code Veronica), Mercenaries(RE3, RE4, RE5, RE6), and RAID Mode(REV1 and REV2).+You have to beat story mode in order to unlock additional content in the game. Forcing the player to work for it. Which is good, because A) It feels like you earned it and B) too many games unlocks everything from the start(Tekken Tag Tournament 1 and 2 for instance)+The Dodge mechanic from RE3 is back! You are able to dodge ALL enemies except one in this game including bosses. This is great way to practice your dodging.  Not only can you dodge enemy physical attacks but also projectiles. Each enemy has a different unique way to dodge their movements so you have to watch carefully. Cons-This is an RE game. ALL RE games are supposed to be heavy on the STORY primarily. Everything else is secondary. The game takes place between RE4 and RE5. The story in this game is ATROCIOUS. This game has the worst story of any RE game I have ever played and every RE including spin offs have been decent. It utilizes a technique that derives from cinematography called "In media Res" This technique, tells you what happens in the middle of the game or the ending and reverts back to the past from player's perspective. In Revelations, the story goes back in forth like you boat(no pun intended) It starts you off in the present, then after that it goes to the past, then back to the present, then back to the past 1 year earlier due to a terrorist incident, then back to the present; its ANNOYING!!!! This disrupts the flow of the story. Hell, their is an episode that takes you back 30 mins ago!!! WTH??? -The characters in the game are easily forgettable except for Jill and Chris. Everyone else is expendable. Nothing about the characters are interesting except typical stereotype. You got your typical white spoiled girl who uses sexual appeal to be likeable(which she all has), you got your typical imported foreigner from another country, you got your 2 stooges, and you got an insane old guy who likes to use poetry as their slogan for their terrorist group. Its so cliche and not even funny. -The game's movement pacing is PATHETIC. In the original demo for revelations on RE mercenaries 3D, you COULD run in the game. When the final product dropped, the game got rid of running. This is unacceptable as running was essential in every RE game. In the Past RE games, you could outrun almost every enemy except the hunters. In Revelations, if this was a race, You cannot outrun 75% of the enemies in this game, FORCING you to wait for them to attack you and dodge them or Kill them. This makes Revelations the ONLY game in the RE series to make speedrunning useless and borning unless you are DODGE GOD like myself. -Using the Genesis is the most tedious gimmick I have ever encountered in a RE. In your traditional RE game, you use first AID sprays and herbs simply by finding rooms or gardens filled with them. In Revelations their are very few herbs simply lying around. Instead you have to use a device called the Genesis to scan enemies that stores a percentage of their data until it reaches 100%. Once it reaches 100% a herb is deposited into your inventory. Mixing herbs are not in this game as well as first aid sprays. HOWEVER, each green herb instantly restore all your health to make up for the lack of mixing/first aid spray. On top of the genesis being a gimmick, the game forces you to use it too much in order to gain herbs. So many emeies don't  give you the chance to scan them more than once, because they are too fast such as Rachel Ooze, wall blitzers, or T-abyss fish(They jump a lot). If you are playing infernal mode and you HAVE no herbs where you fighting a battlion of BOWs you may have to restart the game or make sure you create an earlier save.-Their are no typerwrites and no chapter selects. You are forced to rely on checkpoints. If you want to play a certain chapter of the game because it interests you, TOO BAD, you can't. You have to restart the game all over again. -RAID mode leveling system is out of control. The max level in RAID MODE is level 50 and it will take you FORVER to reach it unless you have a coop partner. The only way to maximize your EXP bar is to establish a trinity bonus(Don't get hit, beat a level with the recommended level or below, AND kill all enemies in the game. Earning a trinity bonuses gives you good items on the level. It will take you WEEKS of constant play to get to levle 50. The quickest trick people have done to level up to 50 is have a COOP partner do ghost ship entirely by themselves while themselves sitting their for 20 mins-1 hr. -Some RAID MODE chapters on harder difficulties are TOO long to the point it almost makes it impossible to beat on your inventory. Their has been TOO MANY instances where I have ran out of ammo and I had to rely on knifing or finishing the level up and its stupid(perfect examplle-GHOST SHIP) You have to make all your shots count or your in DEEP trouble. -In order to finish some of the toughest levels on RAID mode, you need to get get parts that are ONLY obtainable either on THE LONGEST LEVELS or INTERMEDIATE ONES. I said before that some RAID MDOE levels are so long that you run out of ammo. In order to increase my ammo capacity I need to get certain parts by trinity bonuses or luck. Problem is, the best parts are on the LONGEST levels. That is LUDICROUS. This FORCES you to get a coop partner who has beaten ghost ship countless times. It is nearly impossible to finish RAID MODE completely by yourself WITHOUT constant farming or without a coop partner. -A lot of parts are ONLY exclusive to RAID mode and not story mode, but not vice versa- Running is ONLY available in RAID MODE but ONLY through parts. I play REV1 ONLY for RAID Mode as REV2 raid mode SUCKS!

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												Resident Evil Revelations is a PC port of a 3DS game that was released on 2012. It's a disappointingly short game but still enjoyable enough at the discounted price I paid. It's core gameplay borrows heavily on Resident Evil 4 (RE4), some might say even better but that's up to the person playing. While it does have some horror elements in it, I honestly think it's not as scary as the previous entries. It rather focuses on action a lot more than survival horror and puzzle solving. Thankfully, thanks to the borrowed gameplay mechanics from RE4, shooting zombies (or B.O.Ws) has never been so fun.Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for it's story and characters. I think they're pretty weak, filled with obvious plot twists and lifeless dialogues.However, despite it's flaws, I still found it fun to play (though it has a very little replay value). Definitely recomended for RE fans.RECOMENDED: For RE4 fans and players who doesn't mind some of the ported 3DS game shortcomings.NOT RECOMENDED: For PC elitist who insisted in 1080p and 60fps.

												This game is a a decent port of the 3ds version. other than that there's not much that can be said about it. But i do not recomend this game if you are a stickler for spot on audio, to give you an example. At multiple points there is alot of talking between characters. The audio lag is so bad that it is about 4 characters behind in dialogue, and because of this issue the actual audio gets cut off by the cut scene actually ending. I only stomached through it because my viewers on twitch were ok with it. But after i finished this i uninstalled it. because i will not play this garbage again until capcom decides to get off their butts and stop putting out half baked content. Be advised, before you get angry because you think it was my system. its not. I've tried this on 3 of the computers we have in my house. I've scoured the internet and found other people having this issue, The fixs some people have posted don't work for everyone, and no it wasn't my streaming software as it happened to the other computers who were streaming anything when i booted it up.

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Revelations is a welcome addition to the Resident Evil franchise. It attempts to go back to its survival horror roots with a tense atmosphere and semi-tank controls. Revelations does not disappoint in that aspect as there are several moments where you do not expect what will be around the corner waiting for you. It really is no secret that Capcom wants to take the franchise into the action/third-person style; and Revelations still has aspects of this as well. It may not be as bad as other Resident Evil games but the game is still quite enjoyable. With the introduction of Revelations comes the Genesis, a device used to show hidden items through-out the environment. The Genesis adds an interesting layer to the gameplay. The main purpose of the Genesis is to gain additional ammo and herbs. Of course you can also use the Genesis to scan B.O.W.s., whether alive or dead, to gain more herbs with every 100% completion. There are very few healing items in the open world so it is highly advised you use the Genesis as much as possible. Overall the Genesis is an interesting addition to a Resident Evil game but in the end it shows that the game really was made with a handheld in mind.A few gripes with the game is that the story telling isn’t the best. You are constantly switching back and forth between several people and this tends to mud up the flow of the timeline within the game. Another annoyance is the lack of healing items. There will be quite a few times you run out of them, as you can only carry five, and you only gain a small percentage from scanning monsters. The game also tends to hold your hand when you die, basically telling you what you did wrong and how to overcome it. I wish Capcom didn’t do and let the player figure it out like the past games. In conclusion Revelations is a must have for any fans of the classic Resident Evil series. It takes a step back to recreate the tense setting and tries to instill fear into the player like the games of old with a few new twists on the gameplay.Overall I give the game a 7 out of 10.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												I'm just going to say this early on, as I'm confident I know what I'm in for. I got the game for pennies so it's no big deal, but HOLY HELL can you tell this came from the handheld 3DS system. Right off the bat, it was unplayable on a TV with it's super low FOV. Thankfully this could be fixed by the "Widescreen Fixer" application.Beyond that what you have here is a very stripped down Resident Evil experience. While it has some control refinements over, say, RE4, its been vastly improved upon by it's sequel, Revelations 2. I say jump to that game and just watch summary videos of this one, if you must. There's absolutely no one online here anyway, so the raid mode is a bust. Its my opinion that the franchise hasn't had a plot worth following past RE3, but even if you disagree, I think anyone can tell this is shaped up to be an afterthought from the core series. I wouldn't pay more than a few bucks for this.They did their best with the PC port, in that the videos are HD quality, and the textures, frame rate, models, etc are all as good as one could hope coming from the 3DS. There's definite enhancements.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												You want Resident Evil Revelations? I will give you revelation -> this game sux. I could not stand playing for more than 3 hours. Just... impossible.TL-DR : I got this game for free. And I did not even get my money's worth. I do not recommend it at all.This was the first Resident Evil game I played and I believe it will be the last.What is this game about? Protagonist is a crippled person, uncappable of anything but slow walk. So you charge at your enemies with agility of 95 yo grandpa with clutches. You can not even move a chair if it blocks your path. You shoot zombies that hardly notice it. You scan desks with scanner to find hidden ammo. You look for keys to find doors to get you to doors that you need to find key to open, to get to door that you have no card to open and need to slowly walk to another door that magically opened at your convenience to get it...Gameplay is terrible. Terrible. You can not dodge or block in normal way, nor jump or crouch. Not even run. You just walk with zombies behind you. And if you shoot them, even in the head, they do not even react, they do not flinch. They are not thrown back even if you shoot them with shotgun to the chest at arms length. And you must be almost stationary to shoot. No Run and Gun. Nope. If you try that, you swing knife at enemies... You want to spray them down while backing like hell? Nope, not here. Ah, there is a door! (the corridors are a few metres long, then there is a door. Always a door... every few steps. And the monsters disappear or appear when you go through that door. And you always close the door behind you. Smart). There is some debris blocking your path, that you coul walk over (not even need to jump) ? Too bad, you need to take a de-tour. There is NO place for cyber-athletics, no agility.  No using corners, ducking, running back and charging at enemy when you see fit. Nope, not here.You just walk at enemies at the speed of dying turtle, shoot them (shooting makes no difference until enemy suddenly drops dead) and open doors. Ah, and eat a plant that grows everywhere to magicaly restore your health. And use super-advanced scanner to find ammo you can not see otherwise. Tasks are extremely dull and boring Every zombie runs at you. Every one tries to kill you. Unless the zombie carries a key that you need. Then, for some reason, it runs away from you... and you need to chase it to the start of the level, so the game  seems longer and not so linear. So you end up walking here and there like a confused freshman looking for his class. Go get the key to get through this door. Ah god, why not learn how to pick that locks, they seem to be everywhere...Shooting does not feel natural. It has no real effect on the enemy, apart from lowering their health bar. So you are stationary, can not run, and can not use guns to clear some space. You just stand, walk back slowly and shoot. It is extremely boring. No satisfaction in killing enemies, no thrill in battless. None at all. The atmosphere is not like in a horror movie. It feels like in a parody of a horror movie. There is actually no atmosphere at all. The game controls feel so unnatural that it just will not let you fall into the story. The battles are so dull you will get no rush of adrenaline. They try to make it scary, and they fail miserably. A zombie attacked me from a washing machine... seriously? A lot of jumps scenes that try to scare you, but they simply do not work at all... The only "scary" moment is when the game crashes and you are afraid of losing your save file. You want a good horror-shooter game? Go and buy Metro 2033 redux and thank me later. Leave this be. It is not worth your time.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
rating: Not worth playingscore: 5/10 - hard to recommendsimilar games: Resident Evil 4,5 and 6target audience: Resident Evil fans who played every Resident Evil game and hunger for moreResident Evil fans were dissapointed by Capcom because of their change of focus to more action-packed games instead of survival horror. For those fans Capcom made Resident Evil Revelations which originally came out for Nintendo DS and was later ported to all the main platforms. Does this version of Resident Evil really go back to its roots? And is this a good port from the Nintendo DS?Disclaimer: I love Resident Evil 1 HD Remaster (the first time I played RE1), I really like Resident Evil 5, I like Resident Evil 4 and the Leon Campaign of RE6 wasnt that bad.GameplayWell. Not only are there only very few "horror"-sections in this game (which were supposed to be the main part), but also these horror-sections arent horror at all. There isnt a single scary moment in this game, not even a creepy atmossphere like in Resident Evil 4 or the Leon Campaign in Resident Evil 6. The biggest design flaw of this game is that you have a coop partner with you (AI driven). This not only makes the game less scary than it already is, but also the AI is HORRIBLE and the game isnt even properly designed with coop in mind. The only thing your partner does is sometimes distract enemies and other times give you some additional fire power.Let me makes this clear: This game is VERY far away from survival horror, but the problem is even as an action game it fails in many parts. The guns feel weak, have ugly sounds, ugly animations, clonky movement system, boring level design, boring weapons and also many unnessesary weapons. This game felt like a japanese MMO with tons of grinding most of the time, especially because it was so damn easy, probably because its a port from the nintendo DS where you have worse controls so it gets easier on PC just because of Mouse+KB.The "puzzles", if you can even call them puzzles, were uninspired and boring. The worst parts of this game is when you are trapped in an area and you have to fight waves of enemies which is extremely dull.But there is one thing which I want to give this game huge credits for and thats the creature design which is actually one of the best creature designs of all Resident Evil games, however for every cool enemy there is also a boring, uninspired enemy.But especially the very first enemy you meet in the game is really cool, because their ugly look not only makes them look scary, but also because of their weird movement it makes headshots more challenging. If Capcom would capture the survival-horror atmossphere of the previous games in this game, these enemies would make you♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants.The thing is, if you consider that this game was originally made for the nintendo DS you can understand why it cant be good. Not because the DS is a bad handheld, but survival horror simply doesnt work on DS and if you make an action game you have to make it very simple for the DS, which is way too simple if you port it to PC.Thats why I am excited for Revelations 2, because that game is made primarily for PC and current-gen consoles, but there you also have Coop and multiple playable characters so we will see...NarrativeThe narrative of this game is absolute garabage and functional at best. Not only is it full of annoying and cliche characters, it also is told in a very boring way, because it keeps jump from location to location. When you play some time with Jill and get used to the Queen Zenobia, suddenly the chapter ends and the next chapter starts at a completely different location with diferrent characters. I guess they wanted to introduce many characters (some from previous RE games) and make their storys connect later, but the ONLY reason they did this is because they needed filler and they wanted to have some action between the "horror" parts of the game (which arent horror as I explained).Every character in this game is SO ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cliche, terribly written and annoying, even known characters like Jill and Chris are so bad in this game (what the ♥♥♥♥ happenend to Jill´s face and voice?). Chris is the only character which isnt annoying.Also the game does take itself serious but at other times makes some stupid jokes and both of these dont fit at all, especially if you want to make survival horror (which this game isnt anyway).AestheticsUgly. Only word I can describe this game is ugly. Character models, weapons models and the location, everything is ugly. Of course this is because of the technical limitations of the Nintendo DS, but they could still put some effort into the design of the places. Only thing which is designed really good are the enemies (but there are also many ugly enemies, and with ugly I mean bad).SoundtrackDidnt even notice any kind of soundtrack, its just some random music in the background.GraphicsOh my, the graphics of this game are worse than playstation 2 games even if it runs at 1080p60fps. I know its a DS port, but they could at least put SOME effort into and increase the quality of the textures and make better character models.This game is just a pain to look at.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												This is a step in both the right and wrong direction for the Resident Evil series at large- the atmosphere is closer to what the older iterations of the series felt like, with dingy corridorsand a sense of threat absent from other recent versions of the game. It offers a nautical residentevil 'experience', for better or for worse depending on the taste of the player. There is a horror of a sort here, but it is underused considering the setting and isolation of the sea.The controls handle well, but the fact you have to use the mouse to shoot, without being given the option to map it to the keyboard, is a massive drawback- Resident Evil 5 allowed you to do so in its own PC port, so it seems inexcusible to have it absent here. Otherwise, most of the other controls are no different from previous iterations. Being able to charge one's physical attacks is satisfying but it breaks up the frenetic flow of combat a little too much.The further lack of an inventory system again moves away from the crux of what has come to have been expected from the series; it feels too deliberate an attempt at distancing itself other games. In addition, the lack of variety in enemy types is also rather disappointing, although the designs of those included are suitably grotesque. The scanner, however, is one addition which I think works well, though it has teething troubles here from being typecast in a similar vein to the 'vision' mechanic present in recent Batman, Lara Croft and Hitman games. Altogether, this is a back-to-basics Resident Evil game, which it strengthened and weakened by this move, but its glaring flaws for me cannot be balanced by its positive ones. Go for the first Dead Space game instead- it is a more effective and streamlined horror shooter game.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8
[This is a tryhard review because of my extreme boredom and dislike for this game. I have nothing to do and I want to waste a half hour. Enjoy.]Revelations is a disappointment in the Resident Evil genre especially after masterpieces such as 4. It lacks the atmosphere, scares, and, especially, gameplay that the previous titles have presented.PROS:- Controls are fine.- Good graphics for it's time.CONS:- Only atmospheric for the first 20 minutes, then it's a matter of walking around the map with no fears.- Enemies, sounds, and music just isn't scary.- 1st boss of the game is literally impossible to new players and will turn many off from the game.- The gameplay is boring and consists of running back and forth with occassional enemies.- The map (that you run around) is impossible to navigate causing players to get lost.- The map (like the radar in the menu) is 3D and impossible to navigate causing players to go the wrong ways.- The story is BAD.- No secret treasures.- There is no shopkeep :(.- The game is overpriced. (currently $29.99)- Originally was supposed to be a 3DS exclusive game. Now I see that it's not meant for PC.My selling point would probably have to be the gameplay. It's so bland and boring that you realize you could be spending your time better doing something else.EXAMPLE:Objective: go to the bridge on the ship*goes to bridge on ship* *kills like 2 guys*Objective: go get a key for the door*walks across map* *gets key for door* *walks all the way back to door*Objective: go to the communication room and call for help*goes to room* *communication system is broken*Objective: walk to [room name] and fix the communication system*walks all the way there* *fixes system* *walks all the way back*I like the RE franchise but this game is just so bad especially for being newer. I can't completely judge it, (although I kinda just did), since I have not fully completed it. HOWEVER, I have played enough to the point where I can write an honest review about it. It is bad and I don't plan on finishing it soon. If you're still looking for a great game in the franchise, Resident Evil 4 is the way to go.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												Yay! More Resident Evil! I was very hesitant to buy this when it first came out knowing that it is a PC port of a Nintendo 3DS game, but I wanted it anyway because I love Resident Evil and it got mostly favorable reviews. The only thing stopping me was that it was $50 new for a Nintendo 3DS port, which sounded insane. That was May 2013 when it came out. 16 months later and the price is still $50 and that is one of the most ridiculous things I have ever seen. First off, it never should have been $50 new and a ton of people voiced that concern in the forums. I have no idea how well the game sold during its initial release days, but I can only imagine that quite a lot of people withheld their money, and rightfully so. The game should only be $25 max because of the quality of the game. It is more generic than other RE games (4, 5, and 6) and the graphics are all horrible save for the character graphics are actually really good. But considering that it is more of a survival game than 4-6 are, especially considering that 5 and 6 are almost pure action games, is what makes it push its max worth in my mind to around $30. If it had the polish and AAA engine of 5 or 6, it could easily have been quite possibly the best RE ever. But that would take an entirely different game since this was ported from a 3DS game. For what it's worth, they actually did a very good port job. Capcom used to be the kings of horrible PC ports (that title belongs unanimously to Ubisoft now), but over the years they have actually been putting out very good ports. RE4 and 5 were ported horribly, but 6 is very well done and so are other Capcom games since that time including this one. The only problem is that when you port a 3DS game you are inevitably going to have poor graphics, and 3DS quality gameplay. The movement and controls are great, but when you fire into any enemy, it is noticeably generic and seems like you are playing a big screen 3DS game for sure. But the game is still a lot of fun and also goes back to the old find this key for this door, card reader, solve a puzzle, etc. So it feels more like a old RE game like 1-3. The weapons are all great and fun to use, and the Raid mode is a very nice additional game mode that has you re-running levels but in more of a arcade style and you can customize your weapon loadout and choose different characters. There is no combine herbs BS here, you just pick up herbs and use them as you go. That is one thing I never liked or hated, but could have done without, was the herb system of the games. This is a good change, but still RE6 has the best herb system imo. The cutscenes are almost all pretty good, but the ones with the guy with the nickname “Jackass” are just painful to watch because the character tries to be funny but it's like a white version of Urkel with a gun. I just want to punch him in the head every time I hear his voice. And like every other Capcom game in existence, they somehow manage to strike a perfect blend of cool cutscenes with good writing but horrible, laughable voice acting. Not one Capcom game exists with even decent voice acting. Capcom are the kings of serious cutscenes with voice acting that sounds like it was delivered by the characters from Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure. The biggest flaw with the game imo are the underwater parts, which take up about 2 whole chapters, maybe more. Swimming under water should not be in a RE game. The swimming underwater parts are way too long. The pressure of finding where to swim before you drown while stopping at points in between where you can swim up and catch a quick breath, does not introduce any new strategy in the game and requires no skill. It is just irritating and stressful. You can't attack underwater but you can push enemies off and not take any dmg, and you swim, and swim, and swim and it is pure ♥♥♥♥ing boredom at its finest. I would like to play RE please, not a crappy diving and swimming simulator.Although I'm a big RE fan, RE6 and all the other games I own kept me busy until just recently I got this game for $13. Well worth that price too. $50 like it still is normally? Lol. Catch it on sale for $20 or less. And please. no more underwater parts in RE games, thanks.7/10

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Combination of Old RE and New RE.  There are puzzles to solve, switches to hit, and backtracking.  Everything that makes a resident evil.  This is a great example of a Resident evil done right with best of both old and new.  There are action moments but nothing over the top like RE 5 and RE 6. You will play mostly on a ship infested by the new T-Abyss virus.  The ship is rather well crafted and interesting to navigate.  Jill and Chris are BACK!!  Just that is worth a purchase if you are a fan of old resident evil.  Story is interesting, although I didn't find any of the new characters memorable. As for the multi-player, raid mode is very fun.  Go through stages of the single player map and take down mobs after mobs. Upgrade guns and mod them and repeat.  Gets addictive.  As long they keep this format in the upcoming Revelation 2, that will be good  as well.  --Recommend BUY

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												TLDR: Didn't play single player (not what I bought it for). From a technical perspective co-op is so broken it's not worth trying to play. Just search for ReR co-op issues (lag/desync), they're widespread.Bought it specifically for the co-op. First off, IT'S NOT campaign co-op. If that's what you want, look elsewhere. Co-op in ReR exists entirely in a new Raid Mode, and if you're thinking it's anything like mercernaries, it's not. It's almost like playing campaign co-op but without any story whatsoever. It simply drops you in an area and you start moving through  killing stuff. It has persistent leveling and tons of guns/gun mods that can be unlocked with the points you get from the levels. It actually seemed really neat (particularly some of the gun mods, huge variety, some really neat stuff) HOWEVER... crippling performance ruins the entire experience.There seem to be massive network problems with the game, it almost feels like you're constantly having massive lag spikes. Your partner can run halfway through a level, but on your screen they will still be standing at the beginning. Every once in a while the game will update your partner's position and you can get a general idea of where they actually are. Oddly enough it seems to register all actions pretty well, so even though I can't see my partner move, he can still shoot at enemies and I can still see the damage that he's doing to them... It's just that from my point of view my partner is hitting the enemy through walls and whatnot. The whole experience was really bizarre. Searching online for ReR co-op issues shows we're not the only ones having problems either. There seem to be technical issues going back to the game's release that have been completely ignored by Capcom. Saw mostly positive reviews on Steam but very little feedback on the multiplayer, so I thought I'd get this in.

number of helpful: 10 of 23 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 6
												Resident Evil Revelations was originally made for 3DS so its not a big surprise that this supposed to be HD port of handheld Resident Evil game. and dont get me wrong - the game is actually as good as Resident Evil 6 with few interesting (and few stupid) mechanics so anyone who just want to play a third person shooter game gonna enjoy it for sure.But unfortunately as a fan of old Resident Evil games, Iam very disappointed by how repetetive this game is with a lot of backtracking (yes, old RE games also have backtracking but at least it wasnt as bad as here) and this latest Capcom's obsession with doing cutscene or waiting for loading map (like using elevators or specific doors) every ♥♥♥♥ing minute. Half of the game you dont even shoot the monsters cos you are too busy watching said literally filler cutscenes or swimming.-----------------------------------------The story is all over the place and as confusing as modern Resident Evil games trying to be - the plot will constantly switching betwen 5 different places, characters and times (and at the end its not even that interesting.) Characters are really shallow and they dont have much interesting to say in the whole game and the whole "episodic story" is really annoying, constantly doing the same thing:>do a crappy cliffhanger>show the stats and save options>show "previously at Resident Evil Revelations">now the story takes place in different place, with different characters and different timeOn beginning of the game its not a big issue but later on you will be♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off with that so much when you realise how much this game is trying to deny you from any kind of gameplay.-----------------------------------------Does game have puzzles? Wait, what puzzles? Oh, you mean this "minigame" with moving wires that you gonna do like 6 times? Hard to call that even a puzzle cos it gonna take you 30 seconds everytime to solve it.-----------------------------------------There arent't many guns and even those are lacking anything special unlike other Resident Evil games where you could find grenade launchers or laser cannons. We have pistols, magnums, shotguns, smgs, sniping rifles and one shoot use, rocket launcher.There is few weapons per each type but those arent much different from each other, beside number of upgrade slots and very minor stats.Inventory is really dumped down when comparing to Resident Evil 4.You can have only 3 weapons at once and you can change them only at "weapon box". There is also very limited max ammo (you can increase it by finding special items), only healing item in whole game are green herbs (max 5 at once), 3 different grenades and no herb mixing. Also 3D map is really, really bad. You dont have full rotation control and it doesn't even tell you precisely your location in the corridor/room. You gonna end up keep looking at it just to make sure you are going in the right direction a lot of times.-----------------------------------------The main feature of this game are two things:>Unique scanning mechanicYou can scan enemies (both dead and alive) to get free herbs or scan environment around you to solve a puzzle (not really a puzzle to be fair) or get free items. Unfortunately its more like a bad distraction from gameplay, slowing it down even more most of time.>Weapon part system. Well this one is a bit more interesting. Almost every gun have more than one weapon upgrade slot, where you can insert different upgrades that you collected around the game (you can do that while using "weapon box"). You can add and remove them for no cost so its encourage you to try out different things everytime. Upgrades arent really that special tho: most of them are very generic, like increase of clip, increase of damage, burst of more bullets per shot or bigger chance for stunning enemy. Too bad that 25% of the game you can't even use neither of those things.-----------------------------------------Another problem that I have with this game is how slow characters are moving making it really hard to strafe or avoid incoming attacks. Well, probably thats why there is dodge system. I see that many people are complaining about it - that its confusing, hard to use or just unresponsive.Let me tell you ..... thats a lie. The dodge system works very well and its easy to do - just stand still and move forward or do quickturn right before enemy supposed to hit you. Its very easy to use and to abuse, making the game very trivial. Dodge is very generous too - you dont have to even do it with perfect timing and many times you gonna dodge by mistake, cos you just wanted to actually move away and the game registered it as dodge.-----------------------------------------Enemy variety is really small. Lets see: common enemy that can only grab you, same enemy but with claws, same enemy but now he can shoot, suicide bomber, big one with instant kill hit, half-shark thing that hides in the water, typical RE dog, mutated fish, enemy using shield and good, old re-used for the n-th time Hunter (that is hands down, the most annoying enemy in whole game. Why? Cos he spend 90% of time jumping left and right so you can waste even more ammo everytime you try to shoot him. Like really, he sometimes do five jumps in row before you can actually even hit him - and they dont even have that much health, they are just annoying cos of those jumps).Heck, even bosses are weak. One is just upgraded common enemy that you can avoid (you can kill him for extra weapon part - you gonna meet him few times - whole concept of it is very similiar to Nemesis), second is also upgraded common enemy that you just outrun and shoot until it die,third is a generic "I will charge into wall and you shoot me in my weak spot" type enemy, fourth is half horde mode, half turret section and fifth is just typical Resident Evil boss (tyrant). I admit, its a cool looking fight that will test your dodge skills but nothing special about it really.-----------------------------------------Beside singleplayer mode there is Raid Mode. Nothing much to say about, its just cut out parts of the single player mode where you can play solo or with your friend. Its actually more fun than singleplayer mode but its not very long.-----------------------------------------Gameplay is really short (it would be even shorter if not all backtracking and cutscenes). The story is really meh with lame plot twist ("ups, this is the wrong ship") , not even much of whole "revelations" going on in it if you ask me. Actually story gives you more plot holes and questions than answers.Its just generic, typical Resident Evil plot where you go to X place, do Y thing, kill Z enemy so I dont understand why Capcom is trying so hard to make it some sort of emotional movie/serial.I finished this game as fast I could, didnt enjoyed very much - especially with how cheap enemy placement is (enemies spawning behind you or behind corner giving them free hits) , terrible gunplay (most weapons, including shotguns, feels very weak, enemies wont get stunned that easy and like srsl - where's fun in using just 3 guns?) and boring in-game fillers. After playing it once, I dont have any reasons to play it again to be fair. I preffer to just replay for 10th time Resident Evil 4 with good, old "inventory Tetris" instead.At least I will have more freedom with choice of weapons there (same with upgrades)and the game wont stop me every few minutes to pull a lever and watch unskippable cutscene.I expected something better than Resident "Less gameplay, more cutscenes and QTE's" Evil 6.I got even more dull game with less, both enemy and gun varity, and probably the weakest monster design in entire franchise.I recommend it only to hardcore fans that just want more RE and people who love third person shooters. Anyone other - better skip it.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Resident Evil Revelations is another step in the downward trend of the Resident Evil franchise. The fact that the HD version came out after the sixth installment is what makes it seem better than it actually is, because frankly anything is better than Resident Evil 6,The setting is appropriate for a horror game, having been explored previously in the series with Resident Evil Gaiden and Resident Evil Dead Aim. One cannot criticize this story without doing so for the other games in the series because it's just as silly as the previous games, albeit without any of the charming character of Resident Evil 1 or 4 (both directed by Shinji Mikami, coincidentally).It's a shame that they had to complicate such a simple story by going back and forth in time making the player control a variety of characters, most of them unecessary, a consequence of Capcom's decision to incorporate co-op or AI partner all the time. What ends up happening is that you have lots of names, throwaway characters and  a breaking of pace as a result of playing out irrelevant events in the story (playing as Chris in a boat to show him boarding the cruise ship for instance).The gameplay is a step forward from Resident Evil 5, and a more sober affair than the mess that is Resident Evil 6's combat system. You move and shoot/stab and can occasionally stun an enemy to perform a high powered physical attack, which is satisfying. Less so are some of the enemies with instant death kills, which are a little cheap, but it's nothing new for the series. The gameplay does become tiring though, because the enemies are designed as bullet sponges and are very repetitive. That's not to say the zombies in the previous games are not, but they were shorter experiences as well.Thankfully, the quick time events from RE4 and RE5 take a break in the game, being relegated to escaping an enemy's grasp and turning valves.Being originally a 3DS game, some of the geometry and facial expressions do look a bit basic, and some of the textures are not up to PS3/360/PC standards, but it's not a bad looking game, it looks on par with early generation graphics. It's certainly well optimized and runs better than Resident Evil 4 Ultimate, which is mind boggling.The difficulty of the game is balanced, but with some spikes that detract from the TV series approach and pace of it, namely in the boss battles that can be quite infuriating in the first tries. The Infernal difficulty mode is different from RE5's Professional mode but just as silly. Instead of overpowered attackers, the enemies become even bigger bullet sponges, turning the game into a brick wall, though it softens as one progresses and gets better gear. It's  a far cry from the challenging but fair Real Survival Mode of the 2002 remake, it's just pulling the bars to make it as unbalanced as it can be.To add to the longevity is the Raid Mode, which is a worse time waster than Mercenaries because it features levelling and each level takes way longer to complete, and the difficulty ramps up to where you need to grind quite a bit through the ship you're already sick of traversing and the enemies you're already sick of fighting from the campaign.It's a better game than what came after, and does many things better than Resident Evil 5, but it lacks character and importance in the overall series. For a game that's called Revelations, removing it from the story arch does no difference at all and makes it an entry that can fade to obscurity.

Also the last boss is just the stupidest thing ever, I wont mention any spoilers but You enter a room, thsi guy who thinks you are the enemy starts mumbling abotu how he hates his enemy(who he thinks you work for) and gives you what you want...by accident? Then you walk off with the item and he tells you to wait so naturally you watch him mutate himself (even though he already did it before but whatever because ♥♥♥♥ logic) Then insted of just walking away, The charcters then decide to explain they are not the enemies even though the guy has already mutated himself.  Jill's quote" Its useless, hes gone mad" No♥♥♥♥♥♥sherlock, maybe you should of told him before he injected himself with aids virus. So then you wait for the boss to teleport to you so you can wait then shoot its heart with only a 0.5 second reaction time to look around, aim and shoot enough bullets. Dont bother trying to dodge it, dodging in this game is dumb and the game thinks you are trying to do a 180 turn most of the time. But nayway you cant dodge it and it doesnt matter if you are anywhere near him because its scripted that you get hurt.....yeah thats also ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Oh yeah, then it get to the ponit where you have to look at 2 of them and decide which one is the real one but even then you have to wit until jsut before his swing hits the ground because only then it shows who to shoot.....trust me its a massive facepalm of a game at this point. YOu jsut keep shooting at him for hours. The door isnt even locked but you cant get out just because this guy told you to "wait" so naturally you have to wait and get stab to dead by him while Chris stands in the corner of the room shooting him with a Nerf gun like he always does (he doesnt do anything and has no purpose, just like all the co-op AI in this game). But like I said, some parts of this game are fun but when you run into the many ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t moments then you get a really bad taste in your mouth because of this game.

content:
Posted: February 4
												I went through the trouble of trying everything this game had to offer: The BAD- Story mode is relatively short.- Story mode has some of the most obnoxious characters I've seen in a video game.- Story mode never went down the whole 'survival horror' route, which I was really hoping for.- Honestly - it's quite boring and not worth playing through.- 'Infernal' difficutly (hardest mode) is a joke. Expect bullet spongey enemies and not much else.The GOOD- The 'raid' mode is somewhat fun. Looks like they put some thought into it to offset the short storyline.- The setting is very cool. Which makes me sad that it wasn't done better.In summary:I know the game was a port from DS, but that doesn't excuse it for being a poorly made game. The potential was here to be a great survival horror, trapped alone on a ship full of new mutations. You get hints at how good it could have been throughout the story, but nothing lasts...
