content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												Seriously, this is got to be the cheapest game i've ever played in my entire life. Nothing, literally nothing in this game stands out as redeemable as a video game.This game tries so hard to grind gamplay hour out of so little content it is absolutely ridiculous:1. Very little savepoints. I'm fine with not having manual savepoints, but autosave every other half an hour in the story, really?2. Instant kill boss fights, and even that, each death sends you another half an hour back BEFORE the boss fight, which is completely unnecessary3. Instant kill grunts. Yep, even some grunts can instant kill you, and guess what, back another half an hour you go.4. Absolutely no indication of sequence of events. Some random guy handing me a key is a perfect indication of the pool finished draining, Really? Are the developers even trying at this point?5. Backtracking. For the little amount of content it has, it makes you backtrack the same area, FIVE TIMES. Each time you get a new key, you go back to the same area to unlock new doors, so you can get more keys to come back to the same area to unlock even more doors, absolutely ridiculously lazy.For a game released in 2013, this game has absolutely nothing to offer that stands out from the rest, I can name tons of survival horror games that beats this crap out of the water (BioShock, Dead Space, etc) in terms of gameplay, story telling and graphics. Words cannot express how much I despise this game, for the cheap lazy piece of crap it is.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												I cannot hate against this game enough. While Revelations 2 was pretty kick♥♥♥♥♥ this game is hours and hours of abuse on the player. It's the first horror game I've played where YOU CAN'T RUN. The dodging sucks dog butt too. You move so f-ing slow in this game while everything against you is super charged. Half the time you can't even get a quarter of a rotation before the thing you were turning to shoot at is on you and killing you. You're set up to fail in this game and have to fight programmers, not monsters, to beat it. And just to make it even more fun, while you sometimes have an ally to fight, not only doesn't the AI recognise them in the slightest, they don't help you in battle. They shoot, but it doesn't damage them. So you have NO advantage, while everything else has cheat codes against you. So to speak.After 12 grueling chapters of the same scenery, sloppy, chopped up storyline that's almost impossible to follow and the promise of the end of the game given and taken away so much you wish it were on a CD so you could yank it out and break it, they give you the final boss...The final boss is 100% invulnerable until he disappears and reappears next to you and just off to the side of you. remember what I said about extremely slow movement of the character? You have to move QUICKLY to hit the heart that suddenly opens after he reappears and attacks you. If you are 100% perfect, it doesn't hurt him in the slightest. If you do, he doesn't strike you and staggers back a bit, but good luck at being able to do that more than a handful of times before the change happens. With the change, not only does the boss disappear and then reappear where you are almost guarenteed not to be able to shoot him, but he can now suddenly clone himself. You have a split second to choose which one is going to open up their vulnerable spot, which is only open for a second or two tops, before they strike you with hits that, even on the easiest more, wipe out most of your health in just one attack. Did I mention you are limited to a very small number of healing items?Also, don't tryin putting distance between yourself and the Dynamic Twins of Extreme OP. They don't even need to touch you to kill you. you can be on the other side of the room and they just need to slap one of their baseball mit looking hands into the ground and you drop, take a good chunk of damage and have to mash A, (if on a controller) for about 20 seconds before they will let you stand. Which gives the split body super-boss plenty of time to come over and beat you to death. I don't mind games that offer challenges. I actually like games that offer challenges. But when I need a freaking PhD in game mechanics just to get past a boss, I have to say F*** this game.They made this game to punish the players, and made them go through 12 boring, unchanging chapters of frustration before the biggest turd was dropped.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												I usually don't write anti-recommendations but in case of this game I felt compelled. I've played and loved many Resident Evil games since the original release and my favourites are Code Veronica, Resident Evil HD remake, Resident Evil 4 (with Wii controls) and Resident Evil 5 when played as co-op. While I used to enjoy Resident Evil games I am afraid their design has become archaid and stale. Game is neither survival horror nor action game, but tries to incorporate horror elements into action by having a horrible control scheme. Most of the game play consists of wandering same stale environments looking for a lever or key while getting streams of same type of monsters thrown at you to try and take a shot at them while game's control scheme does everything in it's power to make second to second game play frustrating. You do manage to kill off the beasts time after time, but it's not fun and hardly feels like an achievement. But worse than the combat is game's lack of focus and uninspired story telling. First of all pacing is off the wall, there's a flash back after a flash back that leads to constant change of scenery and chararacters, you don't get hooked by the story and just when you have forgotten what were you doing, you'll get pulled back to the original scenery where you started at. Then the "episode" ends and there's a video explaining what happened last time in Resident Evil Revelations. Okay uh, I guess this game was originally released in episodic form or something? Still it feels weird to watch a video about what happened when it literally just happened 3 seconds ago. Characters aren't interesting, especially female characters are just for showing skin,  environments are boring mazes full of key & lever hunting. There's a lot of time sink type of content, I suspect they got away with it due (assumed) episodic structure? Game builds no kind of tension with it's "horror parts". Game's full of Hollywood-envy, it wants to be a movie an action game and horror product. Unfortunately it just feels unfocused and repeating.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Definitely scariest game I've ever played. It crashes every few minutes, sometimes fail to completely open at all. 10/10 spooky haunted computerJokes aside though, once you actually get the game to start, it's pretty amazing. Sure, controls feel incredibly clunky at the start, and it almost feels like you're navigating a tank. But I suppose that 3rd person degree inflexiblity retains some hint of its origins as an arcade game. After getting adjusted to the controls and the mechanics, the game actually becomes enjoyable, and forces one to manage resources efficiently. It is definitely a survival horror. Beyond the story mode, raid mdoe offers a whole new dynamic to the game. Instead of struggling to scrape together bits of metal for a bullet, one can purchase equipment at the ingame shop using BP earned from story mode missions and raid mode. Raid missions offer a more intense, "arcade" style of a zombie shooter - players rush to complete the map in shortest times possible and without taking damage for achievements, etc, and a whole host of characters are available to choose from, with each character boasting their individual skills to augment your zombie slaying abilities. Pretty good, but not a recommended purchase at all unless during a sale, and definitely do not recommend any add-ons at all. They are all available throughout the game, and the ones you buy are going to be weaker than the ones you can obtain in game by degrees. It falls short in areas of player control, and since that is going to pretty much be a persistent issue throughout the game, it is not entirely recommended. It is, however, much better than the non RE Rev games. So comparatively would choose Rev over the non Rev ones if you're going to buy a RE game anyway

content:
Posted: November 13, 2013
												I'm a big fan of horror in games. I loved Resident Evil 4, even though it shed its horror mid way in, and I tolerated Resident Evil 5 because the coop gameplay was fun. Revelations, unfortunately, is not the return to horror it's been marketed as. Instead, this game feels incredibly like an android/iOS game. There is very little complexity; no inventory, no management of herbs or ammo. Environments are restricted making it feel more like a rail shooter than anything else where your only choice is forward or back (akin to Killer7, a much better game). Characters and plot are boring. Skip this one.

content:
Posted: April 1
												God was this awful.I mean, i LOVE Resident Evil. I played only 5 games from the series and the most were disappointing. But i do love Resident Evil 4. Revelations is supposed to be "back to the roots". Its not. When you mean by roots, the original 3, no its not. If back to the roots mean Resident Evil 4 as root, no it's not. It is a mix of Resi 5 and 6, with less good graphics (Yup, because of 3DS Port, and for that it looks impressive, but the point is a point). And a lame♥♥♥♥♥story, some bad characters and bad jokes and self-referencing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. It is not good if you use bad level design and let the characters ♥♥♥♥♥ about it. Srsly.The game starts quite good. A little bit spooky, some lame jumpscares but also kind of nice. You have constantly Jills beautiful backside in view. I am not complaining ;) But then it starts to annoy. A bossfight early on which consumes all your ammo even WITH flammables everywhere. Annoying backtracking starts to come in. But the game still is a little fun. But then the other characters come in. First you play as parker, in a boring level, nothing to do, a ♥♥♥♥ing BOX is blocking your way, a BOX another character steps over it without problem! The next characters are introduced, a nerd and a whatever guy, talking ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and very bad jokes -.- Lame and boring sections and so on. Then you have Boss battles. Annoying Boss battles. Especially the last one. Oh and dont remind me of the awful swimming sections!I played the game with growing agony and anger. I nearly dropped it at least 2 times. The last custscenes i only skipped because it got more ridiculous every time. Then I defeated the Ultimate Boss somehow and was glad that this♥♥♥♥♥♥was over. I can not and i won't recommend that game. Ever.

content:

												I'm sorry, but this Resident Evil doesn't feels like Resident Evil. 1) Bad controlI mean, come on, aimming something has some problem, can't move it around, can't aim for headshot easily? Game engine fault? Maybe, I'm not sure since this game came out long few years back.2) Bad storylineReally? If they really wanna corrupt the sea, why not just do it and stop yelling like you need to let the world know your evil plan before doing it. A small dose of it could have infected most creatures.3) Doesn't really matchup with RE storylineI like the idea of the new T-virus, but the virus now is like inactive? Not this game fault for it but, if they didn't intend to really put it in the future storyline, why bother making it?4) Gun sound is really..This is the one that I literally got nothing to comment about. I mean, why does the all the gunfire sound just sound so like SMALL AND EFFORTLESS?? I JUST DON'T GET IT. Capcom could have at least put it normal gun fire sound, instead of making it sound like you're using a cardboard to make a sound. Come on Capcom, get the budget and make a decent game. Overall, it's quite boring to be honest. I thought it would be more of like Rev2 but sadly, it's not. It's the worst RE game i have ever play. But hope this is a lesson to Capcom, please, plan some budget to make a decent RE game. Rev2 was good, but also, the sound isn't that good. If you like slow storytelling, action RE game, this is for you. Otherwise, I would not recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 8
												Do you like busy work? How about cumbersome controls? Wait, you enjoy games that require you to revisit the same places over and over and over and over? Then this crap game might be for you.I've only spent 13 hours on this crap game, and about half of that was on this stupid final boss. The other half was spent going back to rooms I'd already been through. So I'm unistalling it. Ugh I wanted to like it, too. But the combination of: unecessary actions (it's one of those games where you have to "press f" to go down an effing ledge instead of the character just automatically going down, i.e.), unfathomable gameplay glitches (if the boss got close to me my gun would vanish so he couldn't be shot), pathetic map systems (they want to seem high-tech by being moveable, but you can't turn the ship (i.e.) all the way around to plan a route, so you're left guessing how to get certain places), and laughably trite storyline/dialogue (a SyFy channel movie would look Oscar-Worthy compared to this garbage), makes it maddening.I should say that this is my first experience with Resident Evil franchise, so I realize I'm complaining about characteristics of all the REs. most likely, but this is just unplayable. Not enjoyable. Waste of time. Boo.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												My review of Revelations 2 can be seen here.http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/287290(YES Revelations is still active online for those only getting this for Raid mode)Back on the 3DS I came for the graphics and stayed for the gameplay. I was surprised to find that while Revelations was a handheld title it the best Resident Evil game of 2013 which saw the release of the terrible Operation Racoon City and the linear QTE riddled mess that was Resident Evil 6. Having beaten the 3DS game 100% I couldn't wait to be able to play it on my PC with more content, some slightly nicer visuals, a higher framerate and of course mouse aim. It delivered on everything I expected and a little more. First off, Revelations is insanley well optimized although considering it was first made for and released on the 3DS first it damn well should be. While my current PC was no slouch when I first picked this up (These are my current specs: A GTX 980 SC ACX 2.0, an i7 4790k Devils Canyon and 16 Gigs of RAM.) I've seen it perform very smoothly on a laptop with an AMD A4-5000 1.5ghz, ATI RADEON 8330m 512MB VRAM﻿ and 8GB DDR3-RAM with High textures and everything else on low. While the absence of the laser and third and firstperson aiming that was present in the 3DS release is a bummer the PC version still trumps it in every other aspect: The characters mouths now move ingame, the common ooze are now more varied in appearence sometimes having malformed arms, an extra enemy has been added, you can pick, choose and swap between different costumes for the main characters the story mode, the Ghost Ship stages in raid mode has been slightly overhauled with more enemies and different enemy placements, there are more characters and costumes for the said characters in raid mode, more variation in the stats for characters and their costumes and more weapon attachments. The game caps at 120 fps when you choose Variable and rarely if ever dips unless you are in an elevator (Which it disguises as the elevator rumbling) or a water lock, but in the context that this happens it's completley understandable seeing as you are still free to move around while it's happening and it's more of a loading issue than a general performance problem as the frame counter remains the same. One thing that I don't understand and that isn't really excusable is why the game doesn't allow 4k or provide non FXAA related anti aliasing.The audio quality and sound design in Revelations were already superb but what few sounds were compressed are now crystal clear. It's not quite on par with RE5 but asthetically Revelations it trumps it. It does noticeably increase the texture,shader and polygon count though in addition to removing a really ugly bit of water that could be seen out of a window in the 3DS version. It makes it look like what you think it looked like on the 3DS unless you really really squinted. It's also one of the few games where it feels rewarding to get aheivements as you are rewarded with awesome ingame unlockables like an infinite RPG for clearing the hardest mode without being hit. Give it a shot this game is great! I really didn't expect greatness when I first picked this up so that was a REVELATION in its own right, I can't say it's the best Resident Evil game without being super biased but I can say it's a great game in it's own right and one of the better recent entries.Oh yeah and then there's Raid mode which is basically it's very own games bundled in this one but there's too much in Raid mode for me to cover.My review of Resident Evil 5 (The product as a whole) can be seen here:http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/21690Here's my review of Resident Evil 4.http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/21690My review for Resident Evil 6 can be seen here:http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/221040

Posted: August 19, 2016
												Bought 2 copies on humblebundle to play with a friend after seeing it has co-op. Found out co-op was just some side thing that you have to do the solo main story to unlock chapters of. Figured maybe it'll be fun so we just decided to play at the same time anyway so we could talk about it while we play. I was okay we played together had some laughs while he laughed at my constant little screams cause I'm a scaredy cat. I had fun for a while though still♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥that says co-op but has no main story co-op even though you always have an ai partner with you (unless you split up scooby style on a boat of monsters that are trying to kill you cause that is smart) that is an idiot, such as me getting grabbed and Chris deciding to shoot it once every few seconds with a pistol while it had me pinned to the ground before breaking me in half. I liked Rachel even though she only showed up for like a second but I felt genuinely sorry she got dragged into this cause hearing her voice in the co-op she seemed like such a happy person and in the journal she didn't want to be there and she knew her chances of surviving were slim. Hated Jessica from the second she showed up with her impractical clothing choices like  her shorts and purple legging things in the middle of investigating on a snowy mountain and a wet suit missing a leg like wtf is that. Chris is Chris and Jill is Jill. Other characters I couldn't care less about but the pair of science guys were kind of funny to listen to. Gave up on the last chapter when we would shoot the boss and he wouldn't stop his move or get stunned, after trying the fight like 5 times we gave up cause by that point we were over it and getting more bored by the second and didn't want it to ruin our day.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												I'm going to give this game a pre-finish review...  I will add and change it later as needed.So... I'm just going to come out and say it...  This game SUCKS.  That's the short answer.  To be fair, I knew it was going to suck from the demo I played before it came out but that's besides the point.The long version.Cons:Scanning for items.  What.  The.  Hell!   What kind of lame BS mechanic is that!  These supposed people who have dealt with all manner of monsters ranging from rabid acid spitting spiders all the way up to Nemesis and more suddenly cant see the herb that's nestled between a storage rack and sink?  I call BS!Episodic. This.  On its own is a horrible idea for a Resident Evil game.  It kills the immersion in the story at every story and episode break.  I do not even mind the character swapping to see different sides of the story as much when compared to this flaw!Jessica.  I would be making blond jokes for DAYS if in-fact she was blond.  The sad part is, shes not.  How she managed to get into the same category as Chris and Jill is beyond me!  WHO THE HELL WEARS HIGH HEELS TO A BLOODY FROZEN MOUNTION!!!  And then whines when her feet hurt!  She acts like the standard clingy girlfriend who wants to know everything about you and your past when there is no reason to be asking about it!  Honestly, Id have fed her to the zombies the first chance i got >.>The story.  So far the story is...kinda Blah.  Its not the worst I have seen. ((Cough cough RE5 and 6 Cough Cough)) but its still up there.The inventory.  Where the hell did it go?  Whats with the F buttons half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥inventory???  Give us back what we had in RE4 or before cause this sucks.  I'm ignoring the whole “Presss TAB to insta heal” thing.The map.  Why is there a mini map?Netural: (This is here because its both good and bad... take it as you will)Jill.  More to the point, her outfit.  Sexy...but no!  Just no!  Skin tight leathers(I think)?  Why would you do that?  It was not necessary...   BUT....  Appreciated none the less.Mouse movement.  Its ok, not great though.  It has a slight tendency to jump around or the sensitivity alters randomly.  Still playable however.Good:Movement.  The game plays smooth for movement.Graphics. Also OK.  The models are decent, the areas are good and detailed.  Some weird effects with water and goo but that is OKSub-weapon use.  Able to just press G to chuck grenades while aiming?  Yes please.  One of those things that you just do not thing about until its given to you.Its kinda hard to find anything good about this game currently to be honest...I will add more as needed.EDIT:I dont know how, but this game got worse...  Now, we have Jill, Chris, The chick from Legaly Blond, 2 of the 3 stooges(Slapstick and all), the emo redhead guy and that other guy whos name escapes me...  This is some horable writing coupled with terrable acting.  Also...Who the hell flys to a ship on a chopper and doesnt check the name on the boat before landing!!!  Its right there!  You have the technology!  Im done with this game.  I cant bring myself to finish it just because of the afore mentioned.  To say nothing about the god aweful story.  The best this game deserves is 4/10, thats it.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												This has to be the second worst Resident Evil game I've ever played. Out of the new set, you have 4, 5, 6, Raccoon City, then this. This only succeeds at being better than Raccoon City, but that's up for debate since that title wasn't actually made by Capcom. It was a game made by someone else, being skinned to look like a Resident Evil game to sell it. It's definitely the worst, no question, but if you ignore it and only count official Capcom made titles, then this is actually the bottom of the barrel. And that's still quite an accomplishment because RE 6 is just terrible. This game can't even rise to the low bar that RE 6 set. It's sad to see a series get worse with each title rather than better. But let's not get off topic, this is a review for Revelations, specifically, the PC port. I don't own a DS. I own PC, this on PC, and am reviewing this version of it only.So what do we got? What we got here is basically a cheap port from the DS. Despite touting how improved the graphics are for PC, it is not up to par with the other titles. There's still tons of low res textures everywhere in the game that they couldn't bother to update. One positive note is that there aren't many cutscenes. RE 6 was infested with more of them than zombies. But the graphics aren't really what kills this game for me... it's the cockteasing. They tease us with a ship that's suppose to have open exploration, much like the older games. A lot of its interior is actually modelled to feel similar to the classic mansion. A haunted/infested cruise ship is the perfect setting for a Resident Evil game, and offers a lot of possible stages. Sounds great, right? Well, it has some of your open exploration... then the other 90% of the game is a linear corridor shooter like the other games. You're also teased with Jill making a return, but again, barely get much time to actually play her. Too much of the game(hint: any is too much) is spent being forced to play these other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you'll only inevitably hate as much as possible and never want to actually play. You're forced to play them, entirely against your will, and will rush their sections as fast as you can because you just want to get back to Jill. They're literally wasting your time. My point is that Capcom found a great potential to make another game, then proceeds to waste that potential, pouring it all right down the tube, in every possible way they can. This is another "shoulda woulda coulda" title, and everything good about the game just makes you wish it was in a better game rather than being wasted in this one.Speaking of the characters, they manage to be more annoying and stupid than the ones from RE 6. That says a lot. You are also forced to switch between them constantly whether you like it or not. In RE 6, you were at least able to PICK the one you wanted to play, start to finish. Here they are like "no no no, now you're going to get jerked around every 10 minutes between them all. Have fun fanboy." For example, in RE 6, you could PICK Leon, start to finish, and NOT have to play Chris' Gears of War ripoff at all. Here, no such luck. RE 6 was a disaster partly thanks to having a bunch of differing campaigns that are all junk instead of just having 1 good one(RE 5). Imagine that, but now switching between all of them with no say as to when or which one you play at any given time. Sound fun? IT'S NOT. You'll run down a hallway or open a door then suddenly find yourself dropped into a diferent time and place, and character, for the next 20 minutes, then be dropped back. It doesn't even really add anything to the story and could have just been in an exposition. It just wastes your time with annoying characters you don't want anything to do with, and you're forced to suffer through it until the game "decides" you can go back to where you were on the character you came for and actually wanted to play(Jill). One big bait and switch, this game was.The story as a whole does manage to be a lot less ret@rded than RE 6, but it is a spin off story you don't really need to know. It has no real connection to any other game and I doubt any game from now on is going to reference this or the characters here. The story is a convoluted mess, but RE games were never known for stories that made coherent sense. It's not a good story, but it's a servicable story that could have been acceptable in a better game. But that's not what we got, so it's basically all for naught. At this point I wish they'd give us 1 decent game instead of a bunch of crap ones. I'd happily sacrifice 6, Raccoon City, and Revelations, all for "1" decent RE game. CoD fans will hate me for saying this, but quantity is simply not a replacement for quality.Another big death nail for this game is the lack of Co Op. Once again we're forced to buddy up through an entire game that should be a solo survival/horror experience, but where as before you could Co Op it, now you can't. Yes, they did the stupidest thing they could with Resident Evil. It finally happened. No, it wasn't adding in Co Op. It was adding in Co Op that you can't Co Op. You're stuck with the stupid A.I. partner, start to finish, and cannot possibly Co Op it. Why is it even there then? Is the partner at least done right, like in RE 5? Hell no. It's RE 6 again, the one that borked it. They copied the one that ruined it instead of the one that was good. To clarify, the partner is invulnerable, has infinite ammo, and shoots water pellets. This is unlike RE 5 where the partner actually felt like a person you had to care about. Sheva needed bullets, she could get hurt, she could die, thus you really felt important to each other to survive. It was the proper way to do a partner, even as A.I. Here however they copied the RE 6 partner system, which was sh!t. They're a complete waste of space. They can't die, and won't kill anything. And since you can't Co Op them, why are they even there?! They ported this to PC, and couldn't be bothered to give us Co Op for the partner, when others on PC and Steam have that Co Op. Talk about not giving a sh!t about their franchise anymore. The partner does nothing but tag along, get in the way of bullets or pathing in the tight hallways, and make stupid remarks that'll make anyone over the age maturity of 13 cringe. They're just wasted space and you'll keep wishing you were alone, in peace and quiet, without them tagging along like an unwanted parasite leeching on your campaign. It's like having an annoying brat watch you play but you can't tell them to go away because you're supposed to be babysitting. Ashley from RE 4 wasn't this worthless or annoying. Not even close. At least she could get hurt, and die.In summary, this game is a plate of @ss. I played it start to finish, and I hated almost all of it. I tried to squeeze any bit of value I could out of this to justify my purchase and it just wasn't there. It's a sad pathetic corpse of what used to be a decent franchise, even up to 2009 with RE 5, a game I loved. I leave with nothing but regret, and am saddened that Capcom couldn't care less about what they've done to this franchise since then. It's an abysmal singleplayer experience with no ability to Co Op except for this totally pointless endless repetitive "Raid Mode". If you want a better singleplayer game, it won't be hard to find. If you want a better multiplayer one, it'll be VERY easy to find(Borderlands?). This game is a port that never should have been made, but Capcom knows when they can make an easy buck, and did exactly that. For long time fans like myself, this is probably the last straw. I seriously doubt I'll even consider paying money for a Resident Evil 7, or whatever PoS title leeches off this franchise's hollowed out corpse next.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												Resident Evil® Revelations returns redefined for PC complete with high quality HD visuals, enhanced lighting effects and an immersive sound experience. This latest version of Resident Evil Revelations will also deliver additional content including a terrifying new enemy, extra difficulty mode, integration with ResidentEvil.net and improvements to Raid Mode. Raid Mode, which was first introduced to the series in the original version of Resident Evil Revelations, sees gamers play online in co-op mode or alone in single player taking on the hordes of enemies across a variety of missions whilst leveling up characters and earning weapon upgrades. New weapons, skill sets, and playable characters including Hunk, take the Raid Mode experience to new depths. The critically acclaimed survival horror title takes players back to the events that took place between Resident Evil® 4 and Resident Evil® 5, revealing the truth about the T-Abyss virus. Resident Evil Revelations features series favorites Jill Valentine and Chris Redfield, plus their respective BSAA partners - Parker Luciani and Jessica Sherawat. The action begins on board a supposedly abandoned cruise ship, the ‘Queen Zenobia’, where horrors lurk around every corner, before players head for the mainland and the devastated city of Terragrigia. With limited ammo and weapons available, the race is on to survive the horror of Resident Evil Revelations.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												At it's core, Revelations is basically an experiment for Capcom. They tried to do something different than what they've been doing since RE4, and it paid off. While there may not be zombies or traditional B.O.W.s in this game (other than so many dozens of hunters) it is the closest thing to a classic Resident Evil title in years.Revelations covers the initial days of the BSAA and shows some of the events preceding Resident Evil 5. Evidently the world is in a state where they can build solar powered cities that float on the sea, but not stop making bioweapons. The story revolves around solving the mystery of how BOWs keep showing up in the area with ties to the terrorist organization that got the city destroyed. Obviously, this leads in classic RE fashion to an overly complicated environment - a cruise ship which frankly looks too Spencerian and not remotely like a vacation cruise ship - that, of course, houses a secret bio-weapons research lab. In addition to the lab, almost all of the new ancillary characters are revealed to be double agents or traitors, continuing with the trends of RE, and are working for a mysterious organization or for themselves. Thematically, Revelations really is about as close as possible to the older games. It also has plenty of horrible characters and character dialog - between Jessica's forced attempts at appearing sexy to players, Quint and Keiths ridiculous "Internet nerd/black guy with a life" cliches, and Raymond and Rachels haircuts - What the actual f? - the cheese level is easily higher than RE1.There is no co op in this game's campaign, either. You are on your own. Rarely ever will your AI teammate be anywhere near you and when they are they truly will not be helpful. As for environment, Capcom did a pretty decent job. Again the cruise ship looks nothing like a cruise ship and it's ridiculous, but what it does is emulate the claustrophobia and grandeur of the Spencer Mansion. In addition to the only true Resident Evil plot in years, Revelations also of course contains raid mode.  Essentially, raid mode is Diablo 3 with guns and third person camera. You just play through the campaign levels on varying difficulties, and kill enemies to get new gear and points, but its still quite fun. Although stunted by having been originally developed for 3DS, Revelations is the closest thing to a Resident Evil game since Code Veronica, and does an admirable job of blending both the new and old styles of gameplay.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												Alright where to begin with this mess. It's a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor port of the 3DS version of the game (which is even worse than this, so thank Capcom for porting it... I guess?). There's higher resolutions and gameplay changes to Raid Mode so players can't expoit the lewt drop system... but it doesn't stop save editors and trainers... so the point of that was? What exactly? Waste time? Yeah... sounds like it.The plot is contrived and stupid... the twists to the plot were obvious so there's really no *gasp, SURPRISE!* moments. If you've been following Resident Evil up until now then you'll be pleasently surprised that you and non-fans are on the same page... I dunno where all these extra characters came from but they suck balls and lack personality. I was lost right from the get go and I'm a huge RE fan... back when RE was RE any way... like the first 4 games.There's just too many new faces in this game and it makes me feel like I missed some game that was unreleased. (which I didn't because there is no such thing) These events are supposed to take place between Resident Evil 4 and 5 but they don't do a very good job of explaining how Jill and Chris wound up knowing these new characters or how they got in to the situation they're in... they kind of just banter back and forth between all the bullet spraying about a time they took a trip in Aspin together... or some trivial♥♥♥♥♥♥like that.It's a bit confusing and made me feel detached from the plot. I figured this game was going to stick closer to the roots of Resident Evil but it's just as bad as Resident Evil 4 for missing the point entirely. Instead of fighting Spanards or African's you fight Crab People and other mutated sea dwelling crustations... oh yeah, and wolves... because you know, they have to have some kind of canine enemy in the game to trick people in to thinking they're playing a Resident Evil game. Still hanging on to the original dog jump scare from  RE1, I see, Capcom?The game is stale and drab the entire way through, enemies are more annoying than ever to kill and require you to learn the dodge system or get locked in to a one hit kill death... pretty obnoxious. Also I've never seen more annoying enemies that have weak spots on their back side and require you to learn a ridiculously long move set in order to get a 3 second opening.Hunters are back... yay? Not nearly as intimidating as before... in RE1 a single hunter meant about a 70% chance of death if you didn't have a magnum handy... In this game you fight groups of 3 or 4, no issues... it's the action portion of these newer RE's that make my♥♥♥♥♥♥soft. If I wanted to play Gears of War, I would do so.Alright on to the multiplayer, it's non-existant for the campaign (I guess that's what Capcom meant by going back to the "roots"... because I see no other resemblance to previous RE games) so grab a friend and head in to "Raid Mode"... A mode designed to bore the living♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you. You run small gauntlets through fragmented sections of the game with a static set of enemies, always positioned the same way until you memorize not to get hit and make sure you kill everything... sounds like fun? It's not. If you're not communicating then expect drop outs during a 20 minute long mission with randoms. (good luck finding anyone who plays this mess now) There's 20 Levels with 3 difficulties all of which must be completed to unlock the bonus stage. The bonus stage is about a 40 minute romp through the entire ship where you have to fight the end boss, twice, once in normal form and once in uber form if you're on level 50... so you can, you know, get the "best drops" talk about redundant and unnecessary... If you hit level 50 and beat this final level... why would you need better drops? Fail design on Capcom's part... It's already ridiculously excessive and grindy just to get to this point, then tack on more grinding without the leveling and what do you get? Heart disease... that's what.

												I'm gonna cut this game some slack for being a port from a mobile console - the graphics actually don't look that bad for a PSP game, they did a solid job porting it. The atmosphere and the new character Parker also give a nice, eerie introduction to the ship that the majority of the game takes place on.And that's about all I can say that's good about this game.I cannot fathom why people said this game was better than Resident Evil 6 - the gameplay is watered down (PSP port, okay), the voice acting is dull, the story is uninteresting and lacks focus much more than Resident Evil 6 did. And the worst part is the character design. If you thought Jill's catsuit from Resident Evil 5 was bad, wait till you see Rachel and Jessica in this game. Just google those names under Resident Evil and you will see what I mean.Point is, don't get this game. Even if you don't mind sexualised character design, there is just nothing good on offer here.

number of helpful: 6 of 21 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2013
												Resident evil: Jill's fine butt returns.First of all pre-warnings:Just fair reminder that there is NO SINGLEPLAYER CO-OP, it only has "raid mode" co-op which is your standard mercaneries but with set levels and enemies. No waves. Just "go from A to B while killing 15 enemies".  Which is surprising because you effectively have partner with you all the game.Co-op mod is being devoloped by fans but it has lot of problems to hurdle first.Dialogue, story and voice acting is pretty horrible and you should NOT buy this "for the story".Not even "capcom horrible", they are just plain bad facepalm level. Its super awkward B-movie quality.At first you dont notice it because its your typical Resident Evil one liners of "we need to help CHRIIIS" "OKAY lets GO".Later on it you will just think "who intern made this up" and towards end I just couldnt bare the horrid non-surprising story and writing. The low budget and dismissive attidute towards story "because its portable game" shows on this side.Gameplay:Kinda fun at start if you liked RE5 with mix of RE6 (you can move while aimin but its RE5 styled over the shoulder).However, it gets REALLY repetive and enemies can get bullet spongy later on. The gameplay is effectively POINT GUN AT ZOMBIE, SHOOT TILL DEAD with very rare QTE "get out when being grabbed". The scanning element is cool addition but you either end up waving that device around most of the game which is distracting or just forget it unless you are out of ammo.Around middle you will get the classical "we have to go back to the start of the game because reasons" level re-use, gladly thats fast because you dont have to unlock all doors.. but kinda waste of time.Graphically:Shows sings of 3DS port and the animations really show it - your character slides side to side with minimal animations when running around, shadows are blocky and some textures are blurry and not really worthy of "HD".Would not recommend for full price unless you are diehard RE-fan. Get it cheap.If you are looking for good 3rd person shooter / horror this aint it. Get RE5 or new RE4 HD instead.If you are lookin for cheesy b-movie resident evil  which makes you facepalm and trigger finger numb, this is it. Its moddable so thats plus. I guess.Big plus for the Jill's butt. Because butts.

												I don't recommend. This game is bad port from Nintendo 3DS (handheld console). Controls are bad and also graphics are worse than in Resident Evil 5 (graphics in RE5 was nice but Resident Evil Revelations was released later than RE5). Story and levels also are not very sophisticated, they are boring and we have to fight with the same enemies all the time. This product is highly overpriced, I bought it in Haloween discount and even then I think that I overpaid. I tried to refund this game but unfortunately gameplay time must not be longer than two hours (it is sick IHMO because two hours is too little to experience game enough good, at least for experienced players like me). It is example that fact that game has very positive reviews does not mean it is good and vice versa (I enjoyed some games with most negative reviews).By the way why at loading screen it is written "Don't turn off your console"? Remember those B-script action-drama shows that would pop up on TV now and then? This game is exactly that. For those who are just getting into it, the story will♥♥♥♥♥♥its-self after the first 'episode'. Then it just gets whackier from there.Yeah, towards the end, the story wraps its self up (and even has a short-clip+text-card sequence explaining what happened to all the characters), but I still can't get over how rediculous it all was.Remember back in the 90s when we had the technology to make a solar powered floating utopia city? Or when the RE universe made use of the orbital sunlight cannon? I can't help but feel that this game was going to be written as a sort of "Own-universe" type of game, but since it ties into RE5, that's not the case. So now we just have to accept that while RE1 was just happening, some philanthropists were making a giant floating city.Anyway, the game is fun, not much in the way of puzzles, but the ship has a strong RE1 vibe to it that I enjoyed. Also there are quite a few hidden things for those who want to explore. Overall, it's probably the most fun I had in a RE for a while.However, your AI partner is even more of a turd this time around. All he/she will do is just stand still and shoot at enemies on occasion. Also all enemies will aggro you, your partner just stands and looks pretty.Enemy designs are brilliant when it comes to the sea-creatures, quite a few looking like they could fit at home in Dark Souls (especially some of the later ones). While for the enemies found in the mountain/flashback segments, you just get your standard Hunter-α (plus a new variant), as well as the return of the zombie dog.Voice acting is on-par with the standard RE-terrible, with some lines like "Jill, where are you?" "I don't know, a room I think. On the boat."For a 3DS port, the game doesn't look that bad. As a PC game; it's passable, but is on par with late-PS2 graphics. Won't find a RE5 level of detail here. Or even RE6.This game also has a comedy duo who have hip-hop in the background whenever they have a scene. I don't really have much else to say.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												I don't know why this game is still $50.  But if it ever gets to $30 and below, it is definitly worth every cent.Campaign is good, I enjoyed it to go through twice.  The hard mode switches up enemies so it can still surprise you.  There is NG+ as well.Raid mode is different from the usual mercenaries.  Instead of going for a high score, you go through levels from the campaign with your own loadout and level.  Enemy placement,  types, and numbers are different for each level over three difficulties.  Throughout you either buy (with points earned from playing the game) or pickup guns to upgrade and use.  The pickups are usually the better ones due to the possibility of having more customization slots (which are more +% better upgrades, but you can get some crazy things in the endgame, a common thing I see are burst fire magnums that don't need reloading and have hundreds of bullets).  The mechanics of the game get a bit deeper as well.  Enemies become weak to certain weapon types, melee becomes useful cause it doesn't take ages to pull off, weak points become important.  The only problem with raid mode is that not a lot of people play the game.  But hey, I'm always happy to play with someone that can speak english.The campaign is single player, but raid mode is co-op.  Co-op is pretty much expected to get the endgame stuff as well.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												Fans who disliked Resident Evil 5 and 6 will find much more to like in Revelations, though it's still not the return to survival horror that many have been hoping for.   The game plays like a hybrid between Resident Evil 5 and the original Resident Evil, pairing the modern combat system with the cramped, atmospheric indoor settings of the older games; think of what the GameCube remake of RE1 would feel like with an over-the-shoulder camera and you're halfway there. The combination works so well that it makes one wonder why Resident Evil 4 abandoned so much of the classic gameplay in the first place.   The Queen Zenobia and its enemies are actually frightening (even if there aren't many of them) and the game often manages to build up genuine dread about the scenarios the player is in, something newer titles sorely lacked.  Ammo and health are also more limited, but not to the point of making Revelations a true survival horror game.   Unfortunately, the exploration still feels watered down compared to the older games with less backtracking and fewer puzzles to solve, but it's still far less linear than 4, 5, or 6.  Capcom can't seem to let go of action and Revelations is packed with a few over the top sequences, most of them occuring in chapters that jump to other characters outside of the Queen Zenobia.    These chapters break the immersion in the ship setting and feel like obligatory diversions from Jill's more interesting campaign, but they're brief enough to be excusable.   In general, the game feels like a broken up collection of moments from all across the series history, in both a good way and bad way- the dumbed down action rears its head once again, but the horror of the older games resurfaces to counter it, sometimes within the same chapter.   The campaign can be beaten in about 5-8 hours, a far cry from RE6's 40 hour duration.  Unlike most entries, Revelations does not include the Mercenaries mode to fill out the package, instead offering a new take called Raid mode.  Raid mode has much more in common with the original RE3 incarnation of Mercenaries in which the player would travel across a large, linear stretch of the single player game rather than fighting enemies in a closed arena.  It's generally fun and serves as a welcome break from tradition, but there are many odd choices that hinder the experience.For one, each weapon has its own level.  As the player collects xp from matches, they will be able to purchase higher and higher level weapons, which forces one to keep purchasing the same guns over and over each time they level up while simply discarding their old weapons (they can't be sold back).  This is already tedious, but the fact that the store randomly displays only a few guns at a time makes the process that much worse.  Trying to do something as simple as upgrade your pistol from a level 41 to 42 may require opening the shop 4 or 5 times until your handgun is displayed, and even then it may actually be a lower level than your current gun or it may inexplicably lack any item slots to equip perks to, forcing you to repeat the process until you find one that does.  Why in god's name they didn't use the system from RE4 and 5, letting the player keep and upgrade the same gun over time, is beyond me.  Online play is also tedious in that a level 50 player will have guns capable of killing enemies in single shot while a level 5 player will have to empty several clips to get the same effect.  To avoid a wild mismatch of power, high level players have to lower their level manually.   Considering that this must be done every time you play with a lower level player, it's hard to miss the straightforward simplicity of dropping into a Mercenaries match.  In terms of what's different from the 3DS release, there's not much worth mentioning- it's 95% the same and the few alterations are meaningless.  Even when maxed out, the game doesn't look good enough to make the 3DS version any less impressive, and the loss of 3D may even give the original  the advantage.  To put it bluntly, it's absolutely not worth upgrading if one already has the 3DS version. Revelations isn't perfect, but it's hard to complain when the game gets so much closer to the classic RE gameplay than the newer installments.  It's certainly worth picking up, but don't expect it to solve all of the series' problems and don't forget it's origins as a more limited handheld game.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Given that I bought it with a 75% discount, I feel like the money was worth, otherwise, I wouldn't buy.The game has a nice atmosphere, a bit too much cheerful in my point of view. I think the songs could have been used in a more chilling way. There were situations in which the music felt like 'everything was ok', and I didn't feel any uneaseness in advancing in the game.Also, dealing ONLY with monsters is less frightening than dealing with them and the undead, which we don't know when they're dead or not and their moanings, their slow moving, and their deadly bitting. So I didn't feel much like playing a RE game.I thought, playing in Normal, that the game was much easier than I anticipated. It's somehow easy to avoid getting killed and the enemies are not hard to kill, although the ones that are tougher, are indeed harder to kill.I missed scenes of being scared to death, or sudden fright appearances, which simply don't occur or you're simply expecting them to happen, because the layout of the places you're going through already suggests you're going to have an enemy springing on your neck soon enough, either when you're going or returning.The story is ok. I was just feeling that kind of deja vú when Chris and Jill started looking for each other (I mean, Chris, Claire, Jill, etc are always looking for each in the games, it's a bit repetitive).Graphics look nice enough, at least you can feel like you're in those places.All in all, I think the game is good, but too much expensive for the experience it provides.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												I first played this game on 3DS and preordered the PC version on Steam as soon as it became available, so hopefully that shows how much I enjoyed it! The Steam version is a great port! The Genesis scanner was my main concern, but I should have had faith! It isn't clunky or weird to use at all. The graphics and sound are a pleasant upgrade. No 3D, of course, but the trade for keyboard/mouse controls is well worth it.If you wanted more Jill from RE5 and RE6, this is the game for you! She's kickin' butt and taking names the whole game through. The combat is more like RE6 and you can move and shoot at the same time, which is lovely. I don't enjoy how often the game makes your partner stay behind to do plot related actions while you go off and find X alone, but I don't like it because it's scary and that's kind of the point of a survival horror game. The atmosphere is pleasantly spooky and combat is mostly fun, although your AI partner tends to hide behind you! Sadly, there is no co-op in campaign mode, only Raid mode, and no local co-op at all, only online. The PC version (unlike the 3DS version) does integrate with ResidentEvil.net, just like RE6. They give lots of free items for use in Raid mode that more than make up for the lack of StreetPass items the 3DS version treated you with. If you're a fan of the series (especially if you enjoyed RE6), I'd highly recommend picking this up on 3DS or PC. (If you do get it on 3DS, please make sure you have a Circle Pad Pro as well! It's almost unplayable without one. You CAN do it, it's just nowhere near as fun.) It's in twelve short episodes and there are recaps before you start a new one, so it's easy to play a half hour here and there or, if you feel like it, blow through the whole game in an afternoon and then start it again on a higher difficulty with all your painstakingly upgraded weaponry in New Game Plus. Have fun!

Posted: March 8, 2014
												The short of it: Not as good as RE4The main gripe I have with this game compared to RE4 is that RE4 had a great combat system, everything was very deliberate and it was very clear what the enemies attacks were, as well as what your capabilities were, and RE4 also had an amazing locational damage system, enemies reacted in heaps of different ways depending on where you shot. In this one, however, all these slimy-looking piranha people all react pretty much the same way when shot; they don't (with the exception of looking like they're tired for a bit so you can go up and kick them in the face, but triggering that is unreliable). There are positives though, the movement system is much more fluid and the weapon upgrade system (in my opinion) is better, in RE4 you had to spend money to upgrade your weapons but in this you find weapon parts and can swap them out. Raid mode is pretty fun, however having to play through the story by yourself to unlock the stages for raid mode so you can play them with a partner is a bit stupid. Overall, it's worth playing, but not worth paying $50 for.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												So I am a huge fan of all things RE, but I am sad to say this is starting to be a dying plot and style of game. If you have played all or any of the RE titles you will, if you are like me, want to play this just to satisfy that OCD "I need to play all the RE titles" itch. If you are new to RE, I have to say this one certainly seems to harken back to RE1 in many ways, so you can get that first time "like a virgin" RE experience.  Unfortuantely, the graphics also harken back to RE1.The Cons: They took out typewriters and went to autosave with this title, and I believe 4-5 (but I don't remeber). I miss being able to run back and save whenever I had the typewriter ribbons to do so. The developers are still relying on graphics from ten years ago, complete with hair that doesn't move and looks like it is being held frozen in space and time with a whole vat of hair gel. Fans of shooters of any sort are going to be extremely frustrated with this game because the hit boxes are just flat out off in some sequences. More than a few times I have been shooting point black at something and not hitting, or the real annoyance is when you go through a door fully prepraed to fire at the creature behind it and it lags for no apparent reason. This game was clearly designed for cotnrollers and the lack of kb commands is a little annoying. I swear these are the slowest running characters in any RE game to date. There is no sprint, and dodge is about as clunky as it has always been in RE games. I don't like the TV show aspect of this game and especially the "Previously on RE Revelations" cut scenes. I also don't like the fact that it takes you out of the atmospheric settings to do flashback sequences to "previous episodes."The Pros:Very cool atmosphere when you are on the ship. Kind of hard to believe they haven't done a ghost ship setting for RE till this one. Despite what some other reviewers have commented on, this game hasn't been about zombies since RE4 and frankly I like that. Zombies were great back in Raccoon City, but the story has well evolved past the zombie genre over the last several years and this game carries on with the whole mutant flesh creature scenarios. Once again we are dealign with two of the classic characters near and dear to all RE fans, Chris Redfield and Jill Valentine. I kind of feel like they are old friends, and it is nice to see some consistency in their return. This game actually does fill in some of the evolving storyline, and so far has not gone off the rails like RE3 and 4 did. So many RE titles seem to lose something in translation from Asian culture to English, but this one is relatively clear in plot and story. Even the voice acting is superior to some other RE tiltles "looking at you RE 1-3."Conclusion:If you are an RE fan get this game for the simple fact that it is a different setting. I liked RE 4 and 5 for the same reasons, and this one is supposed to take place between those two titles. This game is not, however, worth the list price of $50. That is way too much to spend on something that will more than likely be a trivial moment in passing in your gaming career. I caught it on sale for $12.50 on Steam and I was certainly happy enough with it for that price. I might even go as high as $25 for this game, but no more than that. You'll have some fun with it, cuss at it a lot, and you will remember what it was like when this series first emerged on the PS1 back in the 1990s. Those who are looking for graphics and pinpoint accuracy in shooting should probably look elsewhere as this game is not really a shooter, despite what some of the game propaganda says. I bought it and enjoy it simply for the fact that it is one of those game series I have been playing for about 20 years now, and the fact that RE pretty much set the bar for survival horror. Now, if someone would just bring back Dino Crisis I would feel like a kid again.

												I am a HUGE Resident Evil fan and I can't say enough good things about this game. I picked it up on 3DS, but the controls didn't lend well to the experience. Drop that game on the PC with good ol mouse n keys, and HD graphics...well you get a kick♥♥♥♥♥game!The game oozes atmosphere everywhere, and most importantly Resident Evil atmosphere. The game play is spot on, delivering a fun-filled ooze blasting fest from beginning to end. I wish there were actual zombies in the game, but oh well!The most entertaining part of the game for me is the raid mode, which sets you in certain stages filled with enemies for you to dispatch. You level up and earn cash to buy and upgrade weapons. It's EXTREMELY fun.If you are interested in RE games at all, or though RE4 was pretty great, you will pretty much love this game. It really takes a step in the right direction for Resident Evil games. I can only hope they make another Revelations-esque entry into the franchise.

												A surprisingly commendable port on the technical side, RER is a pretty enjoyable action horror game that is 75% surprisingly tense exploration survival horror in a cruise ship setting as RE1 darling Jill Valentine, and 25% ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t shooty bits in the snowy mountains of northern Finland as some other people.The 3DS roots are obvious in the low-poly models and environments, and M+KB controls make this a tad too easy on Normal, but everything runs silky smooth and that is a big plus.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												First thing first. The only real reason i would recommend this, is because i love the Resident evil universe. If you're not a fan of the series, don't even go there.Starting off with the good parts. The story is rather decent. The characters are as lovely as ever and the not-completely-linier-except-it-is idea is a fun diversion from the regularity in most RE games.I also liked the weapon upgrade system, gives a more changey feel and all choices are not permanent.Now to the bad parts, the *WEAPON UPGRADE SYSTEM* is not permanent and feels weird for a RE game...The *GRAPHICS* are sad, not as in bad but it gives a kindof dead feeling. The lighting is lighting up whole cupboards like it's a semi-budgettey game from the late 2000s. All textures who are about to move are semi-obvious to completely obvious.The game suffers from *EXTREME CONSOLITIES*. The graphics is one of the clues, the other is the aiming. Even though we remove the aim-help, it's still jumpy, You can't aim properly when you're getting close to a monster couse even though it's turned off, the aim-help seems to kick and and prevents any fast or small movements of the aim.THERE ARE NO REAL ZOMBIES! Just lots of weird blobby humanoids who are no fun trying to aim at with their wobbly heads and ♥♥♥♥ed up aiming.There are *NO SCARY SCENES* where you know you're about to get ♥♥♥♥ed but still try to make it out with key-combinations, even though the rest of the game is console-oriented, this part which is usually the more fun, and mostly hated, part of the RE games IMHO, is left out.*IT'S PRACTICALLY IMPOSSIBLE TO DODGE* it makes no sence that you have to time a turnabout to dodge, and you almost always dodge straight into whatever's trying to run into you.But i still played through the whole campaign, and i actually enjoyed it. So the story is a pretty big plus, even though i am quite sure most people will not agree with me on that part. There are quite a few things that does not make sence, RE wise, but i suppose it's still legit. I want to believe.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												I originally played this on 3DS, but I recently decided to check out this version since it was on sale and I'm cheap as heck sometimes. Anyways...Resident Evil Revelations is known for taking the series back to its survival horror roots, which it actually does. Although, I still prefer Resident Evil 4 (which I'll also have to try checking out the PC version of), but this is probably my 2nd favorite in the franchise.There's a bunch of plot twists, the enemies are sometimes decently challenging. I say sometimes since the 3DS version made me so used to standing while shooting, so this version feels like a walk in a park to me, except in that part where you have no weapons. Speaking fo which, I don't remember that B.O.W. being able to get its head out of the TV in the original version. Unless it was always like that and I'm just really fast when it comes to getting out of the room usually, nice touch.The gameplay mainly has a system of primary weapons (guns), secondary weapons (explosives), and a dodge system which is easily abused when you know what you're doing. I'm still a bit rusty at the dodging since I haven't used it in so long, but you can generally just move forward real quick with the right timing and completely avoid all damage.Ammo is scarce and enemies refuse to die, reserve ammo for when you need it. Either that, or just head shot everything. You could also knife everything or use your bombs. Yeah, those bombs have saved my lives many times. Especially the B.O.W. Decoys. Also, some bosses are down-right frightening at first. They aren't as scary the 2nd time through, though.....Except for the Com's Officer, he stops being scary for a while and then he shows you why you were scared with a nice chainsaw to the pelvis while a horde of undead fish people are coming to get you. I hate Com's Officer, but I also love him.

												Capcom is slowly moving back to their roots however this game does have it's modern survival horror aspect, it still has a portion of action into it. The puzzles in this game werent hard but atleast it gave me my quick fix of resident evilish touch. What I hope to see in the next installment:- Make the game alot less linear- leave the action to the end parts of the game but still maintaining the horror- More and harder puzzles (keys, emblems, solving puzzles to open areas and doors, also having to read the memos found in the area to solve a puzzle)- No partner ai in the campaign and atleast a separate campaign with co-op- darker and scarier atmosphere also being able to endure the fear put into the areas- inventory box should make it's return (Good thing it made it's appearance in this game)- bring back the inventory system (Also another good thing that they brought it back to this game)- bring back the save rooms and some form of save manual save system (it doesnt have to be typewriter but I really miss that in the resident evil survival horror)- make ammo and health items scarce and being able to scavenge the area and exploring to find supplies (lowering the amount of item drops when you kill enemies)- being able to investigate the rooms and clicking on places in the room get a dialog of the character telling us of  the area (similar to in this game how you see a dead body and you can investigate it and a little dialog would be on the bottom of the screen)- Memos, journals, and reading goodies that were in most of the resident evil games (really brings up the atmosphere of survival/horror)

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												I had a blast with Revelations. It mixes really well vibe and pace from old REs with shooting moments from recent installments. Keep in mind this game was once a handheld.I won't spoil anything, but don't expect to find an amazing story here. It will keep you're attention, but it will make you roll your eyes in its cheesiness. Aside from Jill and Chris, the rest of the characters seem to come from another game and are very uninspired stereotypes. The controls are similar to RE4, 5 and 6. Dodging is the worse mechanic in this game, it's hard to understand when to use it since there is not in prompt. The scanning mechanic, similar to Metroid Prime, is a nice addition that incentivizes exploration and rewards players with scarce ammo and other items.Revelations mixes the methodical pacing from RE 1,2 and 3 using puzzles, backtracking, closed environments and the horror vibe while having the more precise controls from recent installments. You'll have the occasional shooting, but those are the minority. It's not as intense as the Remake, but it's better than 5 and 6. If nothing else, at least Relevations is a step in the right direction.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												If RE Revelations was released right after RE 4, then this game might have been heavily criticized for its lack of depth in the storytelling department. For a game that supposingly touches on the early days of the BSAA, I wished the game developers had put in more effort in telling the backstories of the main characters we get to play as. Parker comes off as someone who tries too hard to impress others, while Jessica's lines were simply.....unintelligent. I thought Quint and Keith were interesting characters  but their segment was too limited. The least Capcom could do was to give an explanation as to why or how Chris and Jill had joined to BSAA, since they were the most well known characters.Nevertheless, certain elements of your typical survivor horror game are delivered in this installment. The game may look tame on the casual and normal difficulties but start the game on the infernal mode and you may just start to hate this game.In conclusion, Revelations is a much better alternative if you are sick of RE 6's over-the-top plotline and gameplay.  The relatively simplistic game mechanic in Revelations brings out the horror that many gamers experienced from the earlier installments.  Still, don't expect too much of a reward once you finish the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												A straight-up upscaled port of a 3-year-old 3DS game, which retails for $20, sold for $50.The campaign is short, the levels are extremely cramped and linear, and load times (though hidden) are frequent, as befitting the original hardware for which they were designed.All that being said, if you can catch it for the price of the 3DS version or less, it's a far better Resident Evil game than Capcom's latest fiascos, keeping more in line with the gameplay style of RE5, and making an attempt to return to spookiness and atmosphere over explosions and bolo ties. There are even tense underwater sections, and the return of the master of unlocking!The cherry on top is raid mode, an online cooperative mode for two players, where you fight your way through snippets of the campaign, albeit with more aggressive enemy placement. You collect loot, unlock characters and costumes, and attempt to score well to earn points for purchasing and upgrading skills and equipment. It ties into Capcom's bizarre RE.net website, as well, so you can get a little more use out of the damn thing if you made one for RE6.Overall, a pretty great game, and something of a return to form for the Resident Evil series.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2013
												If you enjoyed the classic RE games I'd highly recommend this. It is an upscaled 3DS port so the graphics aren't the best but they've done a decent enough job and you can easilly tweak them with nVidia programs etc. The story is a bit flamboyant at times but the game itself combines the RE4-6 style moving and combat with the more conventional exploration of the classic RE1-3 style: there's puzzles, you hunt for keys, there's areas you can go back too to find guns and upgrades that are off the beaten path and can easilly be missed. Unfortunately the game is let down by it's flamboyancy in places and some of the newer characters (Jessica in particular) are just downright annoying and don't fit the vibe at all. However if you see this game on sale in any of the Steam Sales definitely pick it up - it's much better than the likes of RE6 and RE: Operation Raccoon City and pretty much feels quintessentially Resident Evil.

												Positives+ New system to upgrade weapons is neat, albeit not exactly noticeable+ Different costumes offer stat changes in Raid Mode, not just cosmetic+ Same core gameplay as previous entries, will please existing fans (RE4-6)Negatives- No pop-up message to help you counter attacks (As it is in RE6)- I noticed some odd glitches, like my weapon not lowering after I had fired a shot and let go of the buttonI enjoyed this game because I tend to enjoy all Resident Evil games (except for Operation Raccoon City). I am biased in this regard, and I can overlook some flaws because this series continues to deliver a formula that I enjoy.I am sad there is no Mercenaries Mode, but rather Raid Mode. Raid Mode seems to be a way for people who enjoy speed runs to take the game into small-size bites. This isn't a bad thing, I just don't enjoy Raid Mode as much. It feels like I'm just playing the story over again without cutscenes.
