												Let me make it very clear from the beginning why I'm recommending Resident Evil Revelations at all - Raid Mode. This minigame is what will sap up most of your time, and can take anywhere from 70 to over 100 hours for you to unlock characters and bonuses, find rare weapons and achieve S ranks.On to the campaign.Resident Evil Revelations plops RE mainstays Chris Redfield and Jill Valentine into a 'web of intrigue and conspiracy' (inverted commas because....) with new partners, Parker Luciani and Jessica Sherawat. After Chris and Jessica drop off the grid while investigating a possible terrorist group's revival, Jill and Parker and sent to check on them. Parker and Jill end up at an abandoned ship, the Queen Zenobia, which is where most of the Campaign happens. The plot of Revelations is the cheesiest, lamest, cheapest, worst pulp fiction plot I have ever come across. There is no criminal mastermind in this game, the game IS the criminal mastermind for coming across as utterly cheap and unconvincing.Through the campaign, certain parts and boss fights just drag on and on. Instead of creating tension, you start hoping for the game to just be over and done with. The unconvincing, cheap plot makes this worse because you often just feel like a fool wandering the corridors in search of keys and key items to unlock this and that - but for what? Everything feels like a wild goose chase - and players who have finished this game will know what I mean.The controls are a step up from the uncomfortable, inconvenient 3DS ones. The ability to map your subweapons to specific keys will allow you to toss subweapons (grenades, decoys) quickly, saving your skin in precarious Raid Mode situations. Where the triggers on the 3DS were cramped and caused hand fatigue, you'll of course find no such problem on the PC. The half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥dodging is still here, however. There is no laser sight in this game. Be sure to turn off Acceleration/Auto-Aim and other options in the game's menu, because your crosshairs are going to be 'sticky' otherwise, making it harder to aim.For Mercenaries veterans, Raid Mode is definitely a different flavour. Instead of building combos and adding time, the game offers 20 stages, all mini-maps taken from the main Campaign. In each, your objective is to get to the end point. To get there, you have to make your way through the map, kill enemies for keys, etc. To make Raid Mode challenging for trophy hunters, Trinity Bonuses (achieve No Damage, kill all enemies, play at lower level than recommended) have been added, and will often require a good co-op partner for you to get them all.You choose from a variety of characters, each with different weapon perks, pick 3 weapons from your inventory and then enter the stage. Generally, there are characters for different playing styles. E.g. Morgan Lansdale, with his Rifle and Magnum perk, will be popular with people who like the powerful but slow-reloading weapons.Co-Op has a number of known issues as well, such as horrible lag and failure to find matches. The lag affects gameplay badly, since enemies will regenerate health, enemies might continue walking around despite having 0 HP, enemies (and your partner) 'teleport' across the map, etc.Revelations is a rather weak game. It hasn't got an amazing combat system, it hasn't fully retained the flavour of older RE games, it gets utterly boring at points, the enemies are rehashed zombies, it's not an immersive or convincing game world, etc. But I still recommend it for the co-op experience of bonus-hunting with a partner. Raid Mode is a content-heavy section that stands well on its own and has high replayability. For players who lament that this game is a 'disappointment' and a 'disaster', my reply is to simply play through the game to get your money's worth, then uninstall it from your system and be done with it. This is the new direction the games are taking, and you of course, as a consumer, have the choice not to part with your money and time.Revelations gets a 7/10 from me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												So I am a huge fan of all things RE, but I am sad to say this is starting to be a dying plot and style of game. If you have played all or any of the RE titles you will, if you are like me, want to play this just to satisfy that OCD "I need to play all the RE titles" itch. If you are new to RE, I have to say this one certainly seems to harken back to RE1 in many ways, so you can get that first time "like a virgin" RE experience.  Unfortuantely, the graphics also harken back to RE1.The Cons: They took out typewriters and went to autosave with this title, and I believe 4-5 (but I don't remeber). I miss being able to run back and save whenever I had the typewriter ribbons to do so. The developers are still relying on graphics from ten years ago, complete with hair that doesn't move and looks like it is being held frozen in space and time with a whole vat of hair gel. Fans of shooters of any sort are going to be extremely frustrated with this game because the hit boxes are just flat out off in some sequences. More than a few times I have been shooting point black at something and not hitting, or the real annoyance is when you go through a door fully prepraed to fire at the creature behind it and it lags for no apparent reason. This game was clearly designed for cotnrollers and the lack of kb commands is a little annoying. I swear these are the slowest running characters in any RE game to date. There is no sprint, and dodge is about as clunky as it has always been in RE games. I don't like the TV show aspect of this game and especially the "Previously on RE Revelations" cut scenes. I also don't like the fact that it takes you out of the atmospheric settings to do flashback sequences to "previous episodes."The Pros:Very cool atmosphere when you are on the ship. Kind of hard to believe they haven't done a ghost ship setting for RE till this one. Despite what some other reviewers have commented on, this game hasn't been about zombies since RE4 and frankly I like that. Zombies were great back in Raccoon City, but the story has well evolved past the zombie genre over the last several years and this game carries on with the whole mutant flesh creature scenarios. Once again we are dealign with two of the classic characters near and dear to all RE fans, Chris Redfield and Jill Valentine. I kind of feel like they are old friends, and it is nice to see some consistency in their return. This game actually does fill in some of the evolving storyline, and so far has not gone off the rails like RE3 and 4 did. So many RE titles seem to lose something in translation from Asian culture to English, but this one is relatively clear in plot and story. Even the voice acting is superior to some other RE tiltles "looking at you RE 1-3."Conclusion:If you are an RE fan get this game for the simple fact that it is a different setting. I liked RE 4 and 5 for the same reasons, and this one is supposed to take place between those two titles. This game is not, however, worth the list price of $50. That is way too much to spend on something that will more than likely be a trivial moment in passing in your gaming career. I caught it on sale for $12.50 on Steam and I was certainly happy enough with it for that price. I might even go as high as $25 for this game, but no more than that. You'll have some fun with it, cuss at it a lot, and you will remember what it was like when this series first emerged on the PS1 back in the 1990s. Those who are looking for graphics and pinpoint accuracy in shooting should probably look elsewhere as this game is not really a shooter, despite what some of the game propaganda says. I bought it and enjoy it simply for the fact that it is one of those game series I have been playing for about 20 years now, and the fact that RE pretty much set the bar for survival horror. Now, if someone would just bring back Dino Crisis I would feel like a kid again.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2013
												While RE6 was a guilty pleasure, I can safely say this is a genuinely good Resident Evil game. There are a number of artifacts that remind you of this being a handheld port -- the episodic format mainly, but poor textures as well -- but this a step back towards RE4; less action, more survival horror.  Well, maybe not horror.  Nothing in this is scary, per se.  The weapon customization is excellent, and this game's arcade/mercenaries mode (called raid mode) is suprisingly good, being what I can only describe as a mini-campaign.  Raid mode is multiplayer if you want, the campaign is single player with an AI partner you'll barely notice because he does nothing and I'm pretty sure can't die at all.  The story is awful, but that's Resident Evil for you.  If you can get it on sale and liked RE4, you literally can't go wrong with this.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												A surprisingly creepy iteration of Resident Evil; this game tries to return to the horror roots. The story is in episodic format, and gets a bit convoluted with constant switching between characters/time periods. It's also slightly uninspired but the atmosphere and small degree of exploration allowed makes up for it. Enemies are horrifying and resource management is more important than it was in RE4 or RE5 (I actually ran out of ammo a few times). Despite originally being for the Nintendo DS, the HD version really improves the graphics, being as good as RE5 on medium settings.Raid mode is a fun time-waster but gets repetitive after a few hours. Recommended but I'd wait for a sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												With no pulled punches for the fact this game was made for 3DS because it's the story that's at fault here.  It's a good game otherwise.I played on PC with and Xbox360 controller and the game worked just fine.  it seems well made: there are no bugs that I can think of and no real problems with the controls beyond my own failings; however, the game betrayed me as a lover of the Resident Evil series.  The game goesn't respect its enemies and it doesn't respect its own story.On multiple occasions this game goes out of its way to trivialze the enemies presented by either not acknowledging them  various trash, shield boss, giant tentacle B.O.W.  or by resuing bosses as common fodder.  The combat is in no way difficult and the hardest difficulty makes up for it by being extremely bullet spongey.Story wise, it's a complete drama bomb.  I'm surprise that Jill didn't reveal that she was having Parker's alien baby via virgin birth, but there's always next time.  Half of it makes sense, half of it if I"m being generous.  It just dropped conspiracy on top of me and expected me to roll with it, well good try but no.Characters know things that they shouldn't.  Example:  Chris/Jessica RUSH to Jill's location (that you the player know but not them) during a time of great urgency (that you the player know about but not them).  It's an attempt to build suspense without a real effort.  It's lazy writing and the game does it repeatedly.Characters are overly obvious about their intentions.  Example:  Jessica asks out of nowhere if you trust her.  Raymond reveals himself to Jill/Parker on the ship.   Serious, lazy writing like this makes me feel like I'm watching Dora the Explorer.Character actions do not match their intended results.  I cannot stress this one enough.  The absolute laziness of this one is close to hurting my brain.  It's a cheap attempt at a dramatic plot twist.  Examples:  Raymond reveals Jessica as the mole, but he's actually on her side.  Raymond starts to give a very vague speech and Jessica shoots him in the bulletproof vest to stop him revealing information... it's obviously planed but WHY?!  O'brain puts BSAA on infected ship for evidence on Lansdale but Raymond is already there.  Lansdale wants to eliminate ALL evidence but does so by sinking one of three ships.   There's so much more, it's everywhere seriously.The point: a game can drama bomb all it wants to but if it doesn't make an effort to make those bombs meaningful then I might as well have been shooting Spongebob zombies while riding a My little Pony only to be surprise to find out the Spongebob zombies were made by Dr. Gero all in an effort to make Vegeta's heart grow three sizes that day.  The My little Pony? It's obviously because of the new T-C-A-Veronica-Abyss-Dante's-Naruto virus.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2013
												An elegant game that fully embraces the idea that less is more. Despite being a 3DS port, Resident Evil: Revelations manages to surpass the big-budget Resident Evil 6. Though the story is the standard Resident Evil bio-terrorism/global conspiracy nonsense, Revelations introduces some new and likable characters and thanks to excellent pacing and a tighter scope, it never outstays its welcome. The game also features excellent gunplay, combined with the best upgrade system in the series. In addition to the single-player campaign, the game also features a score-attack mode called 'Raid', which is easily as compelling. It throws in some ARPG features, such as drops of various rarity and special enemies, and can be played alone or with a friend.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												Surprisingly entertaining and fairly fleshed out game, considering it was originally made for the 3ds. The story itself stands on its own, and could probably work even without any links to the other games. In fact, the only real big links to the other games are a couple of series name drops, and of course Chris and Jill, who return for this installment, but could easily be substituted with any new protagonists. On that note, while at first kind of cringing at some of the new characters introduced, many of them grow on you as the game continues. I think that this could be in part to do with the fact that they are so heavily involved in the plot of the game, which is how it should work. A good comparison for this is Sheva from Resident evil 5. Sheva, apart from existing to allow a coop option, is given no real reason to be there, yeah Chris is her partner, but that's all, and that's a big reson why she is very forgettable. Parker (Jill's partner in this game), on the other hand, begins this whay as we are introduced to him, but as we see in flashbacks and in encounters with Raymond, he has a reason to be there, which makes him, as a character, a lot more interesting. In terms of inventory, I myself prefer the organisational layout of the attaché case in RE4, but I consider this layout of limiting to 3 weapons on hand at any one time, not bad. The return of item chests is very welcome, and complements this otherwise, very restrictive inventory, by allowing items, such as rocket launchers and magnums to be put away until needed without having to wait until a chapter end.Gameplay itself is very much the same as previous installments, however you can now shoot/reload while walking, which I found hard to get used to, just out of habit, but once gotten used to, it's incredibly useful. One thing, I never really got the hang of was dodging which seems useful, but also seems to only work sometimes, I don't know, I may just be doing it wrong. I will say though, that ally AI is still broken as hell. They fire at enemies, but they seem to make very little actual difference in combat, which is sad to say, considering that it worked better in previous games.Enemywise, there weren't many types of enemies, but it didn't bother me because they each had a very different style. I was however, very disappointed in the boss battles within the game. They seemed very awkward and out of place, to the point that they didn't really need to exist.Overall, I found the game very entertaining and suspenseful, with a few minor quirks, which can easily be overlooked. The game felt more "actiony" than classic games in the series, but I think it needs a certain amount of that to not make people feel too uncomfortable while playing, while still remaining within the survival horror genre.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												Pros: 1. Learn how the BSAA was created in a story featuring Chris & Jill.2. Raid mode with lots of unlockables as per RE tradition.3. Creepy (but dorky) effects, esp. the comms officer. Cringe!4. Keyboard & mouse works well in this game, I'd recommend for aiming alone.5. End boss is a really fun fight. The RE designers know their boss fights.Cons:1. Graphics are subpar by 2015 standards, but still plenty atmospheric.2. Offline campaign co-op was removed from this version, which is really stupid.3. FOV is bad, I highly recommend the widescreen fixer solution. See guides.4. Terragrigia levels seemed bad/rushed, looks like a ps2 game in those levels.5. There is nobody online playing raid mode :(Overall: 8/10, main thing holding it back is its graphics but this is a good new-ish direction for the RE franchise. The PC version is probably the best version, after trying the PS3 version I noticed the huge performance gap especially in rainy scenes where the PS3 drops frames bad.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												An HD Port of an early 3DS release, Resident Evil Revelations ended up being a much more faithful representation of the franchise as a whole than it's widely panned console brethren Resident Evil 6.While RE: Revelations was originally advertised as a sort of prequel to Resident Evil 5, about all is shares with the previous title is it's main protagonists, Jill Valentine and Chris Redfield, and their current positions as field agents of the counter bioterrorism NGO BSAA.Revelations brings subtle improvements to RE5's controls, in particular the oft requested ability to strafe, and includes new functionality such as equipment tuning.  Weapons are now socketed equipment able to hold a number of custom components that augment their performance, these components effects range from higher magazine capacity to greater damage output and faster firing rates, among other more unique effects I'll let you discover.Revelations also features the Genesis system.  The Genesis is a handheld scanner not far off from Metroid Prime's scan visor, and quickly proves to be just as useful, allowing the player to locate easter eggs, hidden items, research dead enemies for healing items, and so forth.  The downside is you'll end up spending quite a bit of time behind the Genesis HUD, which can deflate the horror athmosphere for some.The story of Revelations brings the series back to it's zany horror roots, this time mixed with a bit of old school Ace Combat crazy.  Some time after the fictional island utopia of Terragrigia is laid waste by solar sattelite weapons, Jill and Chris find themselves on opposite sides of the globe following the trail of a bioterrorism organization named Veltro, with Jill's search bringing her to an abandoned cruise liner named the Queen Zenobia.  In Resident Evil tradition things quickly go off the rails for both, and the story becomes a globetrotting race against time to unearth the plans of whomever, or whatever, has taken residence on the doomed ship.The story also spends a significant amount of time fleshing out the BSAA and the people who work there,  and the game occasionally puts the player in control of a few of Jill and Chris' fellow agents following up on leads the former have discovered.  It provides an interesting look at an organization that has become the series sucessor to the ill fated S.T.A.R.S. unit of the first game.Graphically the HD upgrade makes the game somewhat above average in visual polish, and a few bland environment textures notwithstanding it looks pretty good for an uprezzed 3DS game.  The character models can be slightly off, Jill's being the most noticable, it would have been nice if the character models and full motion video cutscenes had an upgrade pass as well.Revelations has several other flaws, the transition to PC has led to some glaring omissions such as the lack of the laser sight present on it's handheld counterpart.  It would have also been nice if the PC upgrade could have had an increase in enemy variety, as most of the undead creatures you'll be facing on the Zeonbia share the same general design.  None of these issues are gamebreaking, however.  And while the game does feature on rails sequences, they're nowhere near the frequency and general unplayability found in those of Resident Evil 6.Bottom line, this is an incredibly successful if somewhat flawed transition from handheld to PC.  And even for those who can't agree on whether Resident Evil 2 or Resident Evil 4 are the pinnacle of the series, there's something for everyone to enjoy.  So if you're a fan of Resident Evil or Survival Horror, you can't go wrong with Resident Evil Revelations.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Resident Evil Revelations / Biohazard Revelations seems like a new game but it was released in 2012 on the Portable gaming platform that is the 3DS and then, a year later, on the XB360, PS3, Wii U and naturally, PC. The game itself was surprisingly decent. I had a whole lot of fun with it and a little piece of advice, the game plays way better with the Keyboard + Mouse scheme (a word of advice though, disable the mouse acceleration though!). With the XB360 gamepad, the aiming was all jerky and you end up missing so many shots.As for the game itself, it was so much superior to the pathetic Resident Evil 6 which in my opinion was one of the worse RE game ever made. But this one, RE: Revelations, redeemed itself well enough in its atmosphere setting, the gameplay mechanics, voice acting and even the music department.To make it short, this is the game RE6 should have been but wasn't unfortunately!For a ported game, the only big noticeable CON would be the graphical and visual side of the game.PROS: +Ghost ship horror atmosphere.+Decent campaign length.+Neat characters models (well modelized, especialy Jill's Azz!).+"Auto-sufficient" A.I. (partner manage itself so no need to run at him/her to heal).+Nice soundtrack.+Replay value with the Raid Mode or if you seek achievements completion.CONS:-Awful textures.-Weak controls with XB360 gamepad.-Messy story.-Weak A.I. but helpful at times as it brings the enemies to itself.-Limited enemy variety (same monsters that you see all game long).-No chapter replay option in the main campaign.-You cannot run... like, what the hell is that?-No puzzles.-This is no "survival horror" game like we used to play on the early RE games and keeps the game into the "action horror shooter" mode.RECOMMENDATION:Decent port to say the least! If you're a Resident Evil fan, you'll enjoy this game for sure! If you're a new comer, you may want to play earlier titles since you'll be really lost in this game, story speaking!PS. The extra DLC doesn't add much to the gameplay. If you can skip it, do so! It is not really worth it in my opinion!RATING:7.5 / 10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												This game is actually a decent game, but it resembles perfectly what the Resident Evil franchise morphed into over the years, and what Capcom actually wanted it to be: a game that appeals to new comers, while keeping the fan base happy. They wanted to play it safe, rather than attempt to make the masterpiece 10/10 game they once used to do. It brought some elements from the original Resident Evil, such as using the tanker as an analogue to the Spencer mansion of the first game, and elements from Resident Evil 4, such as using few parts of the games as battle arenas to shoot waves of zombies and go through near death experiences, and they got some Call of Duty elements from the inferior Resident Evil 6 game, such as Chris and Jill fighting hordes of enemies while finding easily accessible ammos and health when needed.The tone of the game is not horror, like the Resident Evil Remake, nor is it camp, like the second half of Resident Evil 4, but rather it was mostly like watching a T.V. action series such as 24. And just like T.V action series, they replay highlights of the earlier chapters to stay updated on the overall plot when playing the next chapter or when returning to the game later. They really wanted to take the story seriously, when the canon of Resident Evil really wasn't great to begin with. They could've had a basic story to create a scenario, rather than attempt to make the story the central theme of the game. At least this games had a better story than all of the other Resident Evil games (I am serious), but it is still not great, though.The game is fun when playing the Jill segments in the tanker. It looks like the traditional survival horror Resident Evil game that Capcom could've made if they wanted to go back to the original Resident Evil formula. Unfortunately, there are many times when the game cuts away to another character in another location, turning into a pure action segment, breaking the immersion immediately for me.My other problem is that the game is too easy. I know there is a hard mode, but I started the game out with Normal, and thought that Normal would have a bit of challenge. I didn't die as much as I thought I would. I died 12 times, and of the 12 times, I think six or seven of them are either cheap deaths or because of dumb mistakes.I recommend playing this game, especially if you want to take the taste of Resident Evil 6 out of your mouth, and hope for a better Resident Evil. As for me hoping for a better Resident Evil, this game showed me what Capcom is going to do with the franchise: play it safe, and don't make something spectacular like the remake or RE 4.

Posted: October 18, 2013
												First - There is no story coop mode like in RE5 and RE6. I was a bit disappointed in that. Raid mode is the only thing that is coop and it plays through the exact same levels as the single player  just with the story stripped out and more enemies tossed in. But in order to play Raid mode in the fullest, you have to complete the single player - both players.... Normally I would be fine with that, but not all my friends have the time to play the single player and just want to play coop. Besides that as my major complaint, the game is pretty good. I think RE6 is a better buy for coop though. This game has RPG elements that add a lot of replay value. Your character levels up as you progress in Raid mode. Even as you level up, the stages will level with you keeping the challenge all the way up to level 50. If you enjoy coop, zombies that really are not zombies, and RPG games, grab this. Just be aware if you want to play coop, you have to beat the campaign first.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												With no pulled punches for the fact this game was made for 3DS because it's the story that's at fault here.  It's a good game otherwise.I played on PC with and Xbox360 controller and the game worked just fine.  it seems well made: there are no bugs that I can think of and no real problems with the controls beyond my own failings; however, the game betrayed me as a lover of the Resident Evil series.  The game goesn't respect its enemies and it doesn't respect its own story.On multiple occasions this game goes out of its way to trivialze the enemies presented by either not acknowledging them  various trash, shield boss, giant tentacle B.O.W.  or by resuing bosses as common fodder.  The combat is in no way difficult and the hardest difficulty makes up for it by being extremely bullet spongey.Story wise, it's a complete drama bomb.  I'm surprise that Jill didn't reveal that she was having Parker's alien baby via virgin birth, but there's always next time.  Half of it makes sense, half of it if I"m being generous.  It just dropped conspiracy on top of me and expected me to roll with it, well good try but no.Characters know things that they shouldn't.  Example:  Chris/Jessica RUSH to Jill's location (that you the player know but not them) during a time of great urgency (that you the player know about but not them).  It's an attempt to build suspense without a real effort.  It's lazy writing and the game does it repeatedly.Characters are overly obvious about their intentions.  Example:  Jessica asks out of nowhere if you trust her.  Raymond reveals himself to Jill/Parker on the ship.   Serious, lazy writing like this makes me feel like I'm watching Dora the Explorer.Character actions do not match their intended results.  I cannot stress this one enough.  The absolute laziness of this one is close to hurting my brain.  It's a cheap attempt at a dramatic plot twist.  Examples:  Raymond reveals Jessica as the mole, but he's actually on her side.  Raymond starts to give a very vague speech and Jessica shoots him in the bulletproof vest to stop him revealing information... it's obviously planed but WHY?!  O'brain puts BSAA on infected ship for evidence on Lansdale but Raymond is already there.  Lansdale wants to eliminate ALL evidence but does so by sinking one of three ships.   There's so much more, it's everywhere seriously.The point: a game can drama bomb all it wants to but if it doesn't make an effort to make those bombs meaningful then I might as well have been shooting Spongebob zombies while riding a My little Pony only to be surprise to find out the Spongebob zombies were made by Dr. Gero all in an effort to make Vegeta's heart grow three sizes that day.  The My little Pony? It's obviously because of the new T-C-A-Veronica-Abyss-Dante's-Naruto virus.

												With this game I have to say that Capcom made some progress to return the series to it's former glory. I hope this was a wake up call for them, it's a small step in the right direction. It makes me exited to see what will happen to Resident evil in the future because it seems to look a little brighter. Anyhow the game is good and older RE fans will feel more at home with this one than the most recent installments. But there were some things that could have been better gameplay wise but it's understandable since it is a port of a 3ds game. Another thing I want to mention is that the game is pretty short for being a RE game, took me about 6-7 hours to finish while RE 4 took me like 14+ hours to finish. I think it's a good resident evil game and definetly shows that Resident Evil has potential to become perhaps the best survival horror series again even if it might take some time for it to happen.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Resident Evil Revelations is a great port from the 3DS version. Each level is played in episodes, with 1-3 levels per episode. A customization engine is added in for each gun you acquire that is implemented in both the story and raid modes. Speaking of Raid Mode, it is a great feature in this game. With 1-2 to players, the heroes trek through levels and fight off against foes with set levels, and extra buffs (ie. stronger attacks, take less damage, etc.) You will level up, unlocking more weapons, mods, and upgrades for yourself. I highly reccomend this game as it really does well in bringing back that claustrophobic feel from Resident Evil 1 while maintaining the over the shoulder perspective. I also reccommend finding a friend for raid mode as you'll want someone who's got your back, as well as someone you can communicate with.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												If you are a fan of RE 4 and 5 then I would I highly recommend you pick up this game, when its on sale for $20 or less. Revelations mostly takes place on a ship,which makes the game feel claustrophobic with its small corridors. Since the ship has few space, a dodge mechanic is in place which lets you dodge an enemy by moving forward or back right before they attack. It takes some time getting used to, but it is incredibly useful once you mastered it. A scanner is introduced as well, and lets you scan your surroundings for herbs, ammo, custom parts, and fingerprints(collectible that unlock the PSG-1 sniper for Campaign use). As for the gun/upgrade/inventory/system you can find custom parts,which upgrade your guns like 10% increased damage,15% increased fire rate, and some more exotic ones like charged shot, or do more damage the lower your health is. You can carry up to 3 weapons and have up to 25-30 weapons in your inventory. However you can’t purchase any guns in campaign, you have to find them so this encourages the player to explore for better weapons. One change I noticed was in movement, in previous resident evil games you have to stay in one position to reload, while in revelations you can reload on the go. The movement also appears to be slower than in previous games, probably because the devs want you to dodge instead of running away. As for the story theres nothing really exceptional here, and the dialogue is mostly bearable to cheesy at times.It took me about 10 hours to beat the campaign, and when you do theres a new game plus mode which can also carry over your weapons to the next difficulty. Theres an additional mode called Raid mode, which makes the game way more fun. You play on stages, which are unlocked in the campaign, as JIll, Chris,Parker, and other characters you unlock. The objective is simple you get from point A to B,look for a key, or beat a Boss. Enemies characteristics are more varied here than in the campaign. You'll face the same type of enemies except some will be more faster,  stronger, bigger, do more damage, have a bigger hit radius, or just have more health. Combine that with rpg elements like gun drops, rare weapons, and a leveling up system and you have an addicting and incredibly fun mode. Characters you unlock also have specific focuses, like Jill reloads handguns and Machine guns faster and has a faster fire rate,While Rachel regenerates health, and reloads faster with shotguns and magnums. When you complete a stage you get BP which you can use to purchase weapons, ammo, herps, custom parts, and ammo capacity in the raid store . Selling weapons you no longer need for BP is also a nice option.You can get even more BP if you finish a level without taking damage, defeating all the enemies, and being under the recommended level. I've had so much fun with it I would recommend the game solely on Raid mode. I would also recommend a gamepad for this game 360 worked just fine for me. As for performance I have an i5 3230m,8 g of RAM, and an Intel HD 4000 card and it ran very smoothly (except when you’re on elevators the frame rate drops for some reason) besides that no crashes or problems whatsoever.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												You may of heard that the Resident Evil Series is dead. In some degree that is true but after playing this game I have a different opinion. Resident Evil Revalations was actually my first 3DS game and I was hooked. The Graphics were mind blowing, the action was fun and the game was actually pretty damn scary. There were times where I would close my 3DS so that I can catch my breath after a terrifying scare. When I had beaten the game I gave an applause to Capcom for making this astounding game. The problems I had with this game was the lack of character development and horrible controls. Because I didn't have the dual stick attachment for my 3DS, my rules of engagment was to stop and shoot. Even though all Resident Evil games before Resident Evil 6 had this sort of control scheme, the game was sometimes really hard because you were surrounded by fast moving enemies.However thanks to this port I can now play the game with modern controls with very little trouble. While the port is a bit buggy (much like every other Japenese ports) Capcom really gave it their best with more content, a well done reskin and of course new and improved controls.While game could still be better in a lot ways in terms of its horror mechanics, you can tell that Capcom has started to listen to their true fans and are on the right path to resurect the series to its undead roots.

The game runs at a smooth 60fps. Revelations is the best Resident evil since 4; It scary in some parts, but campy most of the time (which is still enjoyable and funny). number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												The short of it: Not as good as RE4The main gripe I have with this game compared to RE4 is that RE4 had a great combat system, everything was very deliberate and it was very clear what the enemies attacks were, as well as what your capabilities were, and RE4 also had an amazing locational damage system, enemies reacted in heaps of different ways depending on where you shot. In this one, however, all these slimy-looking piranha people all react pretty much the same way when shot; they don't (with the exception of looking like they're tired for a bit so you can go up and kick them in the face, but triggering that is unreliable). There are positives though, the movement system is much more fluid and the weapon upgrade system (in my opinion) is better, in RE4 you had to spend money to upgrade your weapons but in this you find weapon parts and can swap them out. Raid mode is pretty fun, however having to play through the story by yourself to unlock the stages for raid mode so you can play them with a partner is a bit stupid. Overall, it's worth playing, but not worth paying $50 for.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												So I am a huge fan of all things RE, but I am sad to say this is starting to be a dying plot and style of game. If you have played all or any of the RE titles you will, if you are like me, want to play this just to satisfy that OCD "I need to play all the RE titles" itch. If you are new to RE, I have to say this one certainly seems to harken back to RE1 in many ways, so you can get that first time "like a virgin" RE experience.  Unfortuantely, the graphics also harken back to RE1.The Cons: They took out typewriters and went to autosave with this title, and I believe 4-5 (but I don't remeber). I miss being able to run back and save whenever I had the typewriter ribbons to do so. The developers are still relying on graphics from ten years ago, complete with hair that doesn't move and looks like it is being held frozen in space and time with a whole vat of hair gel. Fans of shooters of any sort are going to be extremely frustrated with this game because the hit boxes are just flat out off in some sequences. More than a few times I have been shooting point black at something and not hitting, or the real annoyance is when you go through a door fully prepraed to fire at the creature behind it and it lags for no apparent reason. This game was clearly designed for cotnrollers and the lack of kb commands is a little annoying. I swear these are the slowest running characters in any RE game to date. There is no sprint, and dodge is about as clunky as it has always been in RE games. I don't like the TV show aspect of this game and especially the "Previously on RE Revelations" cut scenes. I also don't like the fact that it takes you out of the atmospheric settings to do flashback sequences to "previous episodes."The Pros:Very cool atmosphere when you are on the ship. Kind of hard to believe they haven't done a ghost ship setting for RE till this one. Despite what some other reviewers have commented on, this game hasn't been about zombies since RE4 and frankly I like that. Zombies were great back in Raccoon City, but the story has well evolved past the zombie genre over the last several years and this game carries on with the whole mutant flesh creature scenarios. Once again we are dealign with two of the classic characters near and dear to all RE fans, Chris Redfield and Jill Valentine. I kind of feel like they are old friends, and it is nice to see some consistency in their return. This game actually does fill in some of the evolving storyline, and so far has not gone off the rails like RE3 and 4 did. So many RE titles seem to lose something in translation from Asian culture to English, but this one is relatively clear in plot and story. Even the voice acting is superior to some other RE tiltles "looking at you RE 1-3."Conclusion:If you are an RE fan get this game for the simple fact that it is a different setting. I liked RE 4 and 5 for the same reasons, and this one is supposed to take place between those two titles. This game is not, however, worth the list price of $50. That is way too much to spend on something that will more than likely be a trivial moment in passing in your gaming career. I caught it on sale for $12.50 on Steam and I was certainly happy enough with it for that price. I might even go as high as $25 for this game, but no more than that. You'll have some fun with it, cuss at it a lot, and you will remember what it was like when this series first emerged on the PS1 back in the 1990s. Those who are looking for graphics and pinpoint accuracy in shooting should probably look elsewhere as this game is not really a shooter, despite what some of the game propaganda says. I bought it and enjoy it simply for the fact that it is one of those game series I have been playing for about 20 years now, and the fact that RE pretty much set the bar for survival horror. Now, if someone would just bring back Dino Crisis I would feel like a kid again.

												A solid entry in the series, Reveleations starts off great and evokes the survival horror aspects of earlier RE games. However, those looking for pure survival horror (as I was) be warned: the game ditches the atmospheric scares half way through in favor of modern RE's fast-paced, action focused gameplay.While RE's modern approach is not necessarily a bad thing, it would be better contained to the game's fun and arcade-y Raid Mode. Ultimately Revelations' campaign should have remained methodical and atmospheric. Still, you can't go wrong picking this up. Despite its shortcomings in the second half it is one of the better (modern) RE games. I just wish the whole game let me play as Jill alone on a big scary ship.

												Ahh Revelations. This game is especially perfect for the people like myself who have only played RE 4-6. This game is very much mostly old school survival horror from the days of RE1-3 and very little emphasis on action, just mostly on throwbacks or on the side characters. Now to those who loved RE5-6 only for the co-op, you will not get co-op in the story but only in its other part, Raid Mode, which is very different to The Mercenaries in the recent entries. This game has a lot more weapon customization than RE6. Also be wise with your ammo as much as you can since you won't be able to melee as easy in this game compared to RE4-6. However, the story is on par to RE4-6 if not better since there is more common sense in the situations and to reasoning compared to RE6 especially. Well Raid Mode, all I'm gona say is that its really fun. If the game was 40 I would give the immediate recommendation and 8.5. but since its not the case, it gets an 8 from me, Well hope RE7 can be on point with this game and the upcoming survival horror game, The Evil Within, :).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												First thing first. The only real reason i would recommend this, is because i love the Resident evil universe. If you're not a fan of the series, don't even go there.Starting off with the good parts. The story is rather decent. The characters are as lovely as ever and the not-completely-linier-except-it-is idea is a fun diversion from the regularity in most RE games.I also liked the weapon upgrade system, gives a more changey feel and all choices are not permanent.Now to the bad parts, the *WEAPON UPGRADE SYSTEM* is not permanent and feels weird for a RE game...The *GRAPHICS* are sad, not as in bad but it gives a kindof dead feeling. The lighting is lighting up whole cupboards like it's a semi-budgettey game from the late 2000s. All textures who are about to move are semi-obvious to completely obvious.The game suffers from *EXTREME CONSOLITIES*. The graphics is one of the clues, the other is the aiming. Even though we remove the aim-help, it's still jumpy, You can't aim properly when you're getting close to a monster couse even though it's turned off, the aim-help seems to kick and and prevents any fast or small movements of the aim.THERE ARE NO REAL ZOMBIES! Just lots of weird blobby humanoids who are no fun trying to aim at with their wobbly heads and ♥♥♥♥ed up aiming.There are *NO SCARY SCENES* where you know you're about to get ♥♥♥♥ed but still try to make it out with key-combinations, even though the rest of the game is console-oriented, this part which is usually the more fun, and mostly hated, part of the RE games IMHO, is left out.*IT'S PRACTICALLY IMPOSSIBLE TO DODGE* it makes no sence that you have to time a turnabout to dodge, and you almost always dodge straight into whatever's trying to run into you.But i still played through the whole campaign, and i actually enjoyed it. So the story is a pretty big plus, even though i am quite sure most people will not agree with me on that part. There are quite a few things that does not make sence, RE wise, but i suppose it's still legit. I want to believe.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												I originally played this on 3DS, but I recently decided to check out this version since it was on sale and I'm cheap as heck sometimes. Anyways...Resident Evil Revelations is known for taking the series back to its survival horror roots, which it actually does. Although, I still prefer Resident Evil 4 (which I'll also have to try checking out the PC version of), but this is probably my 2nd favorite in the franchise.There's a bunch of plot twists, the enemies are sometimes decently challenging. I say sometimes since the 3DS version made me so used to standing while shooting, so this version feels like a walk in a park to me, except in that part where you have no weapons. Speaking fo which, I don't remember that B.O.W. being able to get its head out of the TV in the original version. Unless it was always like that and I'm just really fast when it comes to getting out of the room usually, nice touch.The gameplay mainly has a system of primary weapons (guns), secondary weapons (explosives), and a dodge system which is easily abused when you know what you're doing. I'm still a bit rusty at the dodging since I haven't used it in so long, but you can generally just move forward real quick with the right timing and completely avoid all damage.Ammo is scarce and enemies refuse to die, reserve ammo for when you need it. Either that, or just head shot everything. You could also knife everything or use your bombs. Yeah, those bombs have saved my lives many times. Especially the B.O.W. Decoys. Also, some bosses are down-right frightening at first. They aren't as scary the 2nd time through, though.....Except for the Com's Officer, he stops being scary for a while and then he shows you why you were scared with a nice chainsaw to the pelvis while a horde of undead fish people are coming to get you. I hate Com's Officer, but I also love him.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2013
												A pleasant little callback to the older school of resident evil games before 4 came along and fully actionized them. The fact that this is a port from a 3DS release is actually kind of surprising because aside from some oft-repeated lines and animations the game looks quite good and gameplay is generally quite enjoyable. In classic resident evil style the story and characters are stupid as hell with some of the new characters being some of the most annoying I've ever seen in a video game (Parker's a cool guy, though). The combat relies heavily upon a dodge mechanic that's poorly explained and very, VERY fickle and the final boss is damn near impossible if you don't enter the fight with enough ammo. The game's real high point, however is the bonus "Raid" mode which is a neat little mix of mercenaries from the other games and a kind of time attack mode in which you speed through various sections of the story blasting away at a far larger assortment of enemies. It's challenging and highly varied and actually a real blast to play through, even though you have to suffer through the main storyline to fully unlock it. It combines a nice bit of skill, money management and what I guess could be called RPG elements. I can honestly say that I've put 10-15x more time into raid mode than into the main story and enjoyed it far more. If it wasn't included in the game this review would probably be a great deal more negative. One thing to note is that raid mode has a multiplayer component that makes it a great deal more enjoyable and is pretty much essential on the highest difficulty setting but unfortunately it seems to be more or less devoid of random public players so you may need to find a buddy who owns the game or check at the community hub. Overall the game is fairly enjoyable and inoffensive. The story mode is a great way to kill a few afternoons and raid mode is a great way to kill a few WEEKS if you get as addicted to it as I have but I absolutely don't recommend paying full price, I honestly can't say it's worth that much. Wait for it to be on sale for at least 50% off, even if you are really itching to play it.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I was thoroughly surprised by this title. I picked it up while it was on sale after trying the demo, wasn't sure how much mileage I would get out of my purchase. But RESIDENT EVIL REVELATIONS is a solid title in the franchise.Though the gameplay is a bit hindered somewhat by the clunky dodge mechanic, it plays quite well; it's not as complicated as Resident Evil 6's gameplay mechanics, but is just as smooth, allowing you to strafe and move while aiming, and completely eliminates the need to menu surf for items. However, as I previously mentioned, the new dodge mechanic is clunky at best; to dodge an attack you have to move forward or back at a precise time to duck under a swing. It wouldn't be such a problem if a couple major bosses didn't rely so heavily on dodging. Otherwise you might find yourself crushed into a Jill sandwich.Gameplay aside, the story is entertaining albeit predictable. Roughly half the characters are well written and performed, but several new characters are quite badly done and can grate against the player's nerves. The atmosphere, though, is harrowing and claustrophobic, and the musical score is great.Several episodes in the game come up a little short, but I finished the game feeling satisfied.I recommend to survival horror and Resident Evil fans to give RESIDENT EVIL REVELATIONS a try.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												Resident Evil: Revelations is a departure from where the main, numbered series has been going, and the game works and is a fun, scary blast despite a few disappointments. The game takes place in between RE4 and RE5, but the storyline has nothing to do with the main series at all. Aside from a few characters (Jill, and Chris) and a few organizations mentioned (BSAA, Umbrella), everything is wholly original making this game a good standalone for those curious about the franchise. The story is all about spies, bio-terrorism, counter-terrorism, and attempts to go into some interesting psychology behind the villain's motivations but it falls a little flat. The story is told with that same goofy, almost-not-b-movie quality that has become the staple flavor for the series, and for a tale spanning countries with some really fun twists and turns that tone works surprisingly well. Couple that with the game's episodic chapters and it feels like you're watching a low-budget TV show from the 90s, and it's great.The gameplay really isn't anything too different than the rest of the series. It has an over the shoulder, third person perspective, shooting certain points on enemies will weaken them and allow you to melee them to great effect (I still think that Chris's fists are more powerful than shotgun blasts). For the majority of the campaign you have an AI partner following you around, ala RE5, except this partner doesn't need your healing items or ammo and can't be controlled by another player, which is actually an improvement for this game. Despite it's similarities to 5, the game actually made me frightened, which only the first game (the Gamecube remake) managed to do. The atmosphere is very well set up, and one of the main locations in the game requires back tracking, but it's done so well you feel like you're running hopelessly in circles. The most frightening, and challenging, part of the game actually has you search for a dead comrade, only to find she has been resurrected as a disgusted squid-mutant-lady, and you then have to hunt her throughout the games main setting, which is a creepy, derelict boat that sways slowly beneath your feet. This moment is when the game really, truly shines as you never know when she's going to pop out and scream in a girlish voice, "found you!" Unfortunately the rest of the game is nowhere near as scary, but it is a lot more tense than any of the resident evil games after the REmake and RE0. My disappointments in the game are minor, but still important. After defeating the squid-mutant-lady, non of the game's bosses are particularly challenging, but they are still fun to overcome. However the final boss made me so mad, because he requires almost no strategy to overcome, just a bit of quick timing, he has way too much health, and the fight just drags on. It was not fun for me, some people may enjoy it, but I didn't. Another complaint is that the game is a port from the Nintendo 3DS, which is actually quite amazing the 3DS could handle this game, but it shows. It's supposed to be an HD remake, and some textures are bumped up to a higher quality, but a lot aren't, and some of the level geometry gets blocky, and the "hidden" loading screens consist of doors with spinning wheels, you try to open the door, the wheel spins, and boom you go through. It sounds like a quick and easy way to get the game into small, bite sized chunks and remove loading screens, but I once had a door refuse to open for nearly five minutes (yes, I timed it) and ever since then I would groan when I realized my objective was on the other side of one of those blasted doors.Overall, this game is really good. I had a ton of fun with it, and despite it's few shortcomings it really is a fun game, I would recommend to anyone who wants a scary Resident Evil, and I would recommend for people curious about the series. On a scale of:  1) Avoid like the plague 2) Maybe you'll like it? 3) Not bad 4) Good 5) AmazeballsThis game would be a: 4) Good.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												An HD Port of an early 3DS release, Resident Evil Revelations ended up being a much more faithful representation of the franchise as a whole than it's widely panned console brethren Resident Evil 6.While RE: Revelations was originally advertised as a sort of prequel to Resident Evil 5, about all is shares with the previous title is it's main protagonists, Jill Valentine and Chris Redfield, and their current positions as field agents of the counter bioterrorism NGO BSAA.Revelations brings subtle improvements to RE5's controls, in particular the oft requested ability to strafe, and includes new functionality such as equipment tuning.  Weapons are now socketed equipment able to hold a number of custom components that augment their performance, these components effects range from higher magazine capacity to greater damage output and faster firing rates, among other more unique effects I'll let you discover.Revelations also features the Genesis system.  The Genesis is a handheld scanner not far off from Metroid Prime's scan visor, and quickly proves to be just as useful, allowing the player to locate easter eggs, hidden items, research dead enemies for healing items, and so forth.  The downside is you'll end up spending quite a bit of time behind the Genesis HUD, which can deflate the horror athmosphere for some.The story of Revelations brings the series back to it's zany horror roots, this time mixed with a bit of old school Ace Combat crazy.  Some time after the fictional island utopia of Terragrigia is laid waste by solar sattelite weapons, Jill and Chris find themselves on opposite sides of the globe following the trail of a bioterrorism organization named Veltro, with Jill's search bringing her to an abandoned cruise liner named the Queen Zenobia.  In Resident Evil tradition things quickly go off the rails for both, and the story becomes a globetrotting race against time to unearth the plans of whomever, or whatever, has taken residence on the doomed ship.The story also spends a significant amount of time fleshing out the BSAA and the people who work there,  and the game occasionally puts the player in control of a few of Jill and Chris' fellow agents following up on leads the former have discovered.  It provides an interesting look at an organization that has become the series sucessor to the ill fated S.T.A.R.S. unit of the first game.Graphically the HD upgrade makes the game somewhat above average in visual polish, and a few bland environment textures notwithstanding it looks pretty good for an uprezzed 3DS game.  The character models can be slightly off, Jill's being the most noticable, it would have been nice if the character models and full motion video cutscenes had an upgrade pass as well.Revelations has several other flaws, the transition to PC has led to some glaring omissions such as the lack of the laser sight present on it's handheld counterpart.  It would have also been nice if the PC upgrade could have had an increase in enemy variety, as most of the undead creatures you'll be facing on the Zeonbia share the same general design.  None of these issues are gamebreaking, however.  And while the game does feature on rails sequences, they're nowhere near the frequency and general unplayability found in those of Resident Evil 6.Bottom line, this is an incredibly successful if somewhat flawed transition from handheld to PC.  And even for those who can't agree on whether Resident Evil 2 or Resident Evil 4 are the pinnacle of the series, there's something for everyone to enjoy.  So if you're a fan of Resident Evil or Survival Horror, you can't go wrong with Resident Evil Revelations.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Resident Evil Revelations / Biohazard Revelations seems like a new game but it was released in 2012 on the Portable gaming platform that is the 3DS and then, a year later, on the XB360, PS3, Wii U and naturally, PC. The game itself was surprisingly decent. I had a whole lot of fun with it and a little piece of advice, the game plays way better with the Keyboard + Mouse scheme (a word of advice though, disable the mouse acceleration though!). With the XB360 gamepad, the aiming was all jerky and you end up missing so many shots.As for the game itself, it was so much superior to the pathetic Resident Evil 6 which in my opinion was one of the worse RE game ever made. But this one, RE: Revelations, redeemed itself well enough in its atmosphere setting, the gameplay mechanics, voice acting and even the music department.To make it short, this is the game RE6 should have been but wasn't unfortunately!For a ported game, the only big noticeable CON would be the graphical and visual side of the game.PROS: +Ghost ship horror atmosphere.+Decent campaign length.+Neat characters models (well modelized, especialy Jill's Azz!).+"Auto-sufficient" A.I. (partner manage itself so no need to run at him/her to heal).+Nice soundtrack.+Replay value with the Raid Mode or if you seek achievements completion.CONS:-Awful textures.-Weak controls with XB360 gamepad.-Messy story.-Weak A.I. but helpful at times as it brings the enemies to itself.-Limited enemy variety (same monsters that you see all game long).-No chapter replay option in the main campaign.-You cannot run... like, what the hell is that?-No puzzles.-This is no "survival horror" game like we used to play on the early RE games and keeps the game into the "action horror shooter" mode.RECOMMENDATION:Decent port to say the least! If you're a Resident Evil fan, you'll enjoy this game for sure! If you're a new comer, you may want to play earlier titles since you'll be really lost in this game, story speaking!PS. The extra DLC doesn't add much to the gameplay. If you can skip it, do so! It is not really worth it in my opinion!RATING:7.5 / 10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Resident Evil has long been a franchise close to my heart, which is why when i saw what capcom had done with 6 i felt horror of an entirely different kind. However after seeing revelations i knew all was not lost. It's far from perfect and doesnt make any attempts to reach for the lofty heights that 4 did. What it does is present an interesting mix between old and new, a collaboration of sorts between what it used to be and what it wants to become. Overall i still enjoyed the game for what it is now, alongside RAID mode (which is awesome) they bring back the replayability with extra unlocks for NG+ which is a welcome bonus. Any true fan owes it to themselves to play this game, as for the not so hardcore, if you had to pick beteween this and 6, this game wins everytime.

												Good game, not worth the stupidly high full price i got hit with.  Especially since 10 minutes after i bought it, it went on 75% off sale.  Talk about feeling stupid. Anything less that 49$ would have made this game worth it.  I also beat it in one sitting so, yea, its not very challenging either.  Puzzles are nothing like what I remember for the earlier games.  Too easy, no challenge and certainly nothing even resembling a puzzle.That said, it is a good game.  Its well crafted, well built and has its fun moments.  If you have to pay full price, forget it.  If you can get it cheap, worth a play through.  Most certainly start on hard, normal is too easy.  Its kinda sad really, i used to love the tense slow character of these games.  I liked the viewpoint from the older games and the tense quality the game used to bring to the table.  This was just a graphically nice FPS game with slower fire rates.

												This game was... okay. I'd never gotten into the older RE games, and as I understand it this is sort of a call back to those. As a point of reference, I really enjoyed RE5. From a modern standpoint, this game gets a bit tedius due to lots of backtracking and running down the same hallways looking for keys and whatnot. content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												Campaign      really linear almost droll, but if you take your time it can be suspensful. The characters are the classic Jill cardboard and Chris cardboard. there are other characters they introduce into the story of resident evil such as parker, quint, keith, o'neal, veltro, jessica, rachel (barely), red hair dude (conan o'brian ripoff), and some other characters. The only one you atcually really care about is parker. parker is like a shadow of barry he acts like him. all in all the campaign was ok at best.Multiplayer       What do you get when you combine diablo 2 and gears of war. you get the multiplayer that is what revelations brings you. you and a friend or other player play through scenarios from the campaign while bumrushing through hoards of enemies. all to progress and make you guy better. there are different rarity's of weapons red being uber rare. also you are given the chance of upgrading weapons to a make of 30. the multiplayer is what this  game was made for. i will say this at the very least if you do not like grinding to make your character better, then i wouldn't suggest to get this game for multiplayer. please note after grinding sooo much you will see just how much of a difference you have made in your progress.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I am a HUGE Resident Evil fan and I can't say enough good things about this game. I picked it up on 3DS, but the controls didn't lend well to the experience. Drop that game on the PC with good ol mouse n keys, and HD graphics...well you get a kick♥♥♥♥♥game!The game oozes atmosphere everywhere, and most importantly Resident Evil atmosphere. The game play is spot on, delivering a fun-filled ooze blasting fest from beginning to end. I wish there were actual zombies in the game, but oh well!The most entertaining part of the game for me is the raid mode, which sets you in certain stages filled with enemies for you to dispatch. You level up and earn cash to buy and upgrade weapons. It's EXTREMELY fun.If you are interested in RE games at all, or though RE4 was pretty great, you will pretty much love this game. It really takes a step in the right direction for Resident Evil games. I can only hope they make another Revelations-esque entry into the franchise.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 1, 2013
												While RE6 was a guilty pleasure, I can safely say this is a genuinely good Resident Evil game. There are a number of artifacts that remind you of this being a handheld port -- the episodic format mainly, but poor textures as well -- but this a step back towards RE4; less action, more survival horror.  Well, maybe not horror.  Nothing in this is scary, per se.  The weapon customization is excellent, and this game's arcade/mercenaries mode (called raid mode) is suprisingly good, being what I can only describe as a mini-campaign.  Raid mode is multiplayer if you want, the campaign is single player with an AI partner you'll barely notice because he does nothing and I'm pretty sure can't die at all.  The story is awful, but that's Resident Evil for you.  If you can get it on sale and liked RE4, you literally can't go wrong with this.

												Fan might know before playing, that revelations told series of event before Resident Evil 5 took place in africa.Yet, Unlike RE5 that emphasize action, capcom's revelations clearly accentuate their ability to combine classic gameplay with modern 3rd person shooting.If you are a big fan of RE previous installments and you like to feel alone in confined space. This game will be your bread and butter.And for people who already complete the campaign, capcom provide additional challenges through raid mode.For me, raid mode probably the most valuable gem this game had to offer. You can play multiplayer, collect weapon a la borderlands, add mods to enhance them, and many more. I spent 8/10 of my gameplay time on raid and i must say it is REALLY satisfying.In the end, i recommend this game for anyone who never played RE before. You are not going to regret buying this game.And for you fan of RE ? I dont think this review matter for you guys. You probably already "add to cart" this game a minutes ago.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												When I heard that this game was getting a PC port I was extremely excited, since it was branded as a survival horror game that was true to the Resident Evil's of old, and frankly, the only Resident Evil games that I 100% enjoyed. This is somewhat true. The gameplay is a mix of what you find in Resident Evil 5 and 6, and what you find in the classic Resident Evil games. The over the shoulder camera is fine, boss fights are difficult, and ammo conservation exists, but only to the extent of Resident Evil 4, in the sense that conserving ammo never becomes a major problem because you always have more weapons. Backtracking, puzzles, and non-linear gameplay is also present, however the disappointment is the fact that all of this is present only in small amounts. There aren't many puzzles or doors that you can backtrack to, and when you do, you typically find that the contents inside are completely optional anyways. It was kind of a tease for me, but still better than the crap show that was Resident Evil 6.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												Fans who disliked Resident Evil 5 and 6 will find much more to like in Revelations, though it's still not the return to survival horror that many have been hoping for.   The game plays like a hybrid between Resident Evil 5 and the original Resident Evil, pairing the modern combat system with the cramped, atmospheric indoor settings of the older games; think of what the GameCube remake of RE1 would feel like with an over-the-shoulder camera and you're halfway there. The combination works so well that it makes one wonder why Resident Evil 4 abandoned so much of the classic gameplay in the first place.   The Queen Zenobia and its enemies are actually frightening (even if there aren't many of them) and the game often manages to build up genuine dread about the scenarios the player is in, something newer titles sorely lacked.  Ammo and health are also more limited, but not to the point of making Revelations a true survival horror game.   Unfortunately, the exploration still feels watered down compared to the older games with less backtracking and fewer puzzles to solve, but it's still far less linear than 4, 5, or 6.  Capcom can't seem to let go of action and Revelations is packed with a few over the top sequences, most of them occuring in chapters that jump to other characters outside of the Queen Zenobia.    These chapters break the immersion in the ship setting and feel like obligatory diversions from Jill's more interesting campaign, but they're brief enough to be excusable.   In general, the game feels like a broken up collection of moments from all across the series history, in both a good way and bad way- the dumbed down action rears its head once again, but the horror of the older games resurfaces to counter it, sometimes within the same chapter.   The campaign can be beaten in about 5-8 hours, a far cry from RE6's 40 hour duration.  Unlike most entries, Revelations does not include the Mercenaries mode to fill out the package, instead offering a new take called Raid mode.  Raid mode has much more in common with the original RE3 incarnation of Mercenaries in which the player would travel across a large, linear stretch of the single player game rather than fighting enemies in a closed arena.  It's generally fun and serves as a welcome break from tradition, but there are many odd choices that hinder the experience.For one, each weapon has its own level.  As the player collects xp from matches, they will be able to purchase higher and higher level weapons, which forces one to keep purchasing the same guns over and over each time they level up while simply discarding their old weapons (they can't be sold back).  This is already tedious, but the fact that the store randomly displays only a few guns at a time makes the process that much worse.  Trying to do something as simple as upgrade your pistol from a level 41 to 42 may require opening the shop 4 or 5 times until your handgun is displayed, and even then it may actually be a lower level than your current gun or it may inexplicably lack any item slots to equip perks to, forcing you to repeat the process until you find one that does.  Why in god's name they didn't use the system from RE4 and 5, letting the player keep and upgrade the same gun over time, is beyond me.  Online play is also tedious in that a level 50 player will have guns capable of killing enemies in single shot while a level 5 player will have to empty several clips to get the same effect.  To avoid a wild mismatch of power, high level players have to lower their level manually.   Considering that this must be done every time you play with a lower level player, it's hard to miss the straightforward simplicity of dropping into a Mercenaries match.  In terms of what's different from the 3DS release, there's not much worth mentioning- it's 95% the same and the few alterations are meaningless.  Even when maxed out, the game doesn't look good enough to make the 3DS version any less impressive, and the loss of 3D may even give the original  the advantage.  To put it bluntly, it's absolutely not worth upgrading if one already has the 3DS version. Revelations isn't perfect, but it's hard to complain when the game gets so much closer to the classic RE gameplay than the newer installments.  It's certainly worth picking up, but don't expect it to solve all of the series' problems and don't forget it's origins as a more limited handheld game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												Resident Evil: Revelations is a departure from where the main, numbered series has been going, and the game works and is a fun, scary blast despite a few disappointments. The game takes place in between RE4 and RE5, but the storyline has nothing to do with the main series at all. Aside from a few characters (Jill, and Chris) and a few organizations mentioned (BSAA, Umbrella), everything is wholly original making this game a good standalone for those curious about the franchise. The story is all about spies, bio-terrorism, counter-terrorism, and attempts to go into some interesting psychology behind the villain's motivations but it falls a little flat. The story is told with that same goofy, almost-not-b-movie quality that has become the staple flavor for the series, and for a tale spanning countries with some really fun twists and turns that tone works surprisingly well. Couple that with the game's episodic chapters and it feels like you're watching a low-budget TV show from the 90s, and it's great.The gameplay really isn't anything too different than the rest of the series. It has an over the shoulder, third person perspective, shooting certain points on enemies will weaken them and allow you to melee them to great effect (I still think that Chris's fists are more powerful than shotgun blasts). For the majority of the campaign you have an AI partner following you around, ala RE5, except this partner doesn't need your healing items or ammo and can't be controlled by another player, which is actually an improvement for this game. Despite it's similarities to 5, the game actually made me frightened, which only the first game (the Gamecube remake) managed to do. The atmosphere is very well set up, and one of the main locations in the game requires back tracking, but it's done so well you feel like you're running hopelessly in circles. The most frightening, and challenging, part of the game actually has you search for a dead comrade, only to find she has been resurrected as a disgusted squid-mutant-lady, and you then have to hunt her throughout the games main setting, which is a creepy, derelict boat that sways slowly beneath your feet. This moment is when the game really, truly shines as you never know when she's going to pop out and scream in a girlish voice, "found you!" Unfortunately the rest of the game is nowhere near as scary, but it is a lot more tense than any of the resident evil games after the REmake and RE0. My disappointments in the game are minor, but still important. After defeating the squid-mutant-lady, non of the game's bosses are particularly challenging, but they are still fun to overcome. However the final boss made me so mad, because he requires almost no strategy to overcome, just a bit of quick timing, he has way too much health, and the fight just drags on. It was not fun for me, some people may enjoy it, but I didn't. Another complaint is that the game is a port from the Nintendo 3DS, which is actually quite amazing the 3DS could handle this game, but it shows. It's supposed to be an HD remake, and some textures are bumped up to a higher quality, but a lot aren't, and some of the level geometry gets blocky, and the "hidden" loading screens consist of doors with spinning wheels, you try to open the door, the wheel spins, and boom you go through. It sounds like a quick and easy way to get the game into small, bite sized chunks and remove loading screens, but I once had a door refuse to open for nearly five minutes (yes, I timed it) and ever since then I would groan when I realized my objective was on the other side of one of those blasted doors.Overall, this game is really good. I had a ton of fun with it, and despite it's few shortcomings it really is a fun game, I would recommend to anyone who wants a scary Resident Evil, and I would recommend for people curious about the series. On a scale of:  1) Avoid like the plague 2) Maybe you'll like it? 3) Not bad 4) Good 5) AmazeballsThis game would be a: 4) Good.

												A mixed bag of a game. While the setting and atmosphere are infinitely better than Resident Evil 4,5 or 6, the game has numerous problems, raging from "who cares" plot and annoying shooter gallery segments. Some episodes are absolutely pointless and exist only to provide some mindless shooting and prolong the game play time. The entire thing also suffers thanks to the game being the obvious handheld port... small, bland areas, minimal inventory etc. However, despite all this, I had a blast playing Revelations from start to finish... even if it goes out with a whimper. This is probably the best we will get as far as injecting "classic" Resident Evil elements to modern RE goes. Recommended but be wary.
