number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 11, 2013
												Let me make it very clear from the beginning why I'm recommending Resident Evil Revelations at all - Raid Mode. This minigame is what will sap up most of your time, and can take anywhere from 70 to over 100 hours for you to unlock characters and bonuses, find rare weapons and achieve S ranks.On to the campaign.Resident Evil Revelations plops RE mainstays Chris Redfield and Jill Valentine into a 'web of intrigue and conspiracy' (inverted commas because....) with new partners, Parker Luciani and Jessica Sherawat. After Chris and Jessica drop off the grid while investigating a possible terrorist group's revival, Jill and Parker and sent to check on them. Parker and Jill end up at an abandoned ship, the Queen Zenobia, which is where most of the Campaign happens. The plot of Revelations is the cheesiest, lamest, cheapest, worst pulp fiction plot I have ever come across. There is no criminal mastermind in this game, the game IS the criminal mastermind for coming across as utterly cheap and unconvincing.Through the campaign, certain parts and boss fights just drag on and on. Instead of creating tension, you start hoping for the game to just be over and done with. The unconvincing, cheap plot makes this worse because you often just feel like a fool wandering the corridors in search of keys and key items to unlock this and that - but for what? Everything feels like a wild goose chase - and players who have finished this game will know what I mean.The controls are a step up from the uncomfortable, inconvenient 3DS ones. The ability to map your subweapons to specific keys will allow you to toss subweapons (grenades, decoys) quickly, saving your skin in precarious Raid Mode situations. Where the triggers on the 3DS were cramped and caused hand fatigue, you'll of course find no such problem on the PC. The half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥dodging is still here, however. There is no laser sight in this game. Be sure to turn off Acceleration/Auto-Aim and other options in the game's menu, because your crosshairs are going to be 'sticky' otherwise, making it harder to aim.For Mercenaries veterans, Raid Mode is definitely a different flavour. Instead of building combos and adding time, the game offers 20 stages, all mini-maps taken from the main Campaign. In each, your objective is to get to the end point. To get there, you have to make your way through the map, kill enemies for keys, etc. To make Raid Mode challenging for trophy hunters, Trinity Bonuses (achieve No Damage, kill all enemies, play at lower level than recommended) have been added, and will often require a good co-op partner for you to get them all.You choose from a variety of characters, each with different weapon perks, pick 3 weapons from your inventory and then enter the stage. Generally, there are characters for different playing styles. E.g. Morgan Lansdale, with his Rifle and Magnum perk, will be popular with people who like the powerful but slow-reloading weapons.Co-Op has a number of known issues as well, such as horrible lag and failure to find matches. The lag affects gameplay badly, since enemies will regenerate health, enemies might continue walking around despite having 0 HP, enemies (and your partner) 'teleport' across the map, etc.Revelations is a rather weak game. It hasn't got an amazing combat system, it hasn't fully retained the flavour of older RE games, it gets utterly boring at points, the enemies are rehashed zombies, it's not an immersive or convincing game world, etc. But I still recommend it for the co-op experience of bonus-hunting with a partner. Raid Mode is a content-heavy section that stands well on its own and has high replayability. For players who lament that this game is a 'disappointment' and a 'disaster', my reply is to simply play through the game to get your money's worth, then uninstall it from your system and be done with it. This is the new direction the games are taking, and you of course, as a consumer, have the choice not to part with your money and time.Revelations gets a 7/10 from me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												A worthy successor to RE4, which does much to try to reconnect the series to its roots, emphazing a careful use of resources and juking over blasting wildly and hoping your target will stagger. Puzzles are simple, but present again, after a two game absence. The shifting narrative is a bit obnoxious, as many of the characters are less likeable than Jill or Chris (the creepy hacker Jackass comes to mind), but sticking with it will yield good results.The real draw is Raid Mode, a seemingly endless grindfest which puts you at odds with lifebar sporting enemies, featuring an item shop, which lets you buy weapons and upgrade plug-ins with your hard earned points, and a multitude of playable characters.The Genesis scanner, a carry over from the DS version, seems a bit tedious, but becomes less obtrusive as unlockables are found and the player develops a sense for where items might be hidden.Female characters are designed to be eye candy, which is a bit creepy, particularly in the case of Rachel, and Jessica's fashion sense is bound to make some cringe (her one-legged wetsuit comes to mind.) Worth considering if that sort of thing bothers you.Otherwise, a very solid RE game in an era of not-so-solid RE games.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												I've never played a Resident Evil game before, and for my first one, Revelations did a great job keeping me on my toes. It was constantly dancing the line between survival horror and traditional third-person shooter, and I never felt like I had enough ammo to feel fully comfortable. The Genesis device was used to its full potential due to the myriad of hidden objects, invisible/difficult-to-spot enemies, and the storyline was full of cliffhangars and drove me insane because my work only gave me enough time to finish a single chapter every night. I have two major criticisms: the dodge mechanic is unreliable at best, I never used it because it didn't seem to do anything. On occasion my character would dodge an attack but it felt completely divorced from whatever buttons I was pressing at the time. This meant that I mostly shot my way out of situations, which necessitated heavy usage of the Genesis device and my AI partner to keep my limited ammo stocked up. But complaint number two is that your AI partner is almost useless. The doors in this game only allow one charcter through at a time, meaning your partner shows up late to every fight, never seems to bother shooting anything and can't seem to hit anything with the few shots they take. But all in all, the game is well worth playing. The swimming mechanics are some of the smoothest I've seen in this sort of game and the arsenal of weapons and enemies is diverse and keeps things interesting. Wish more PC ports were like this one.

												It's one of the best Resident Evils since 4, but it does suffer from the same pitfall that Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker does-- they are simpler (for instance, there's very little enemy variation) games because of their original handheld exclusivity, which is fine on the 3DS, but suffers on a dedicated platform. It certainly does try to create some kind of atmosphere (though the ever-present co-op partner doesn't help) and to bring back the campiness of the pre-RE4 days and it deserves some recognition for that. It's no RE4, but it does trump RE5 and in some regards, RE6.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												If you are in for a good-old school resident evil experience you are in for a disappointment. While many people talk about RE going back to its roots with the revelation series the honest truth for RE veterans is that Capcom is very far from it. For me RE last root installment was Code Veronica everything afterward is closer to being a shooter than a survival horror.Let me start with what I look for when talking about "root RE experience":- Teasing, mysterious, cold, intriguing and uneasy atmosphere and level design- Limited resources that forces you to strive for any items/ammunition you can find and think once, twice and five times before firing a bullet- Narrative driven enemies that you are both annoy and scare the S#$t out of you and yet compel you to respect their presence- Music that defines the installment and propels the atmosphere and level design.- Puzzles, locked doors, some positive back tracking to find out what's behind that door or corridor that you couldn't explore beforeNow back to Revelations. Apart from the "Resident Evil" title and the presence of known characters from the franchise it has non of the elements that defines a root RE experience for me.- The game is basically a shooter. The main value of the game if running around shooting creatures.- Narrative is laughable and reminds me of RE arcade shooters. I think resident evil survivor has a storyline way better then this game. You can barely relate to any event or character in here- Atmosphere and nostalgia is a thing of the past. Here you will be going through various shooting galleries where you walk in shoot a bunch of enemies and scan stuff and move on to the next gallery- The game episodic design makes the pacing of the game absolutely horrendous- Unless you are shooting blindly, resources are almost unlimited. Healing items, ammunition and other items are everywhere and the game will baby you if you run shortTLDR: If you are looking for an original Resident Evil experience (pre Code Veronica experience) this game is not for you. If you are looking for a horror shooter garbage (Resident Evil 4 onward) this game will be OK

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												Campaign is pretty lame, but Raid mode is fun, especially with co-op. Poor story/writing/pacing, poor graphics. Mechanically the game feels like a mix of different parts of the RE timeline. The mixture really doesn't work well with the bad partner AI, but it works alright in raid mode. It feels like it was supposed to be like RE4 + elements from old RE games, but then randomly added RE5 elements to it. I actually LIKED RE5 (as an action co-op game), but they took the worst parts of RE5 (AI controller partner), made them worse and shoved them into this game. Raid mode is the only part worth playing because they remove the AI partner completely or replace it with a human. Only buy this game for dirt cheap.Pros:- The beginning of the game, is decent. Playing as Jill alone on the ship is the best part of the game and really should have been the entire game.- Some light puzzle/key/backtracking that feels like old school RE games.- Somewhat limited ammo can feel a little like old RE games, but there's usually more than enough ammo (except for maybe 1 part of the game that spikes in difficulty randomly).- Raid mode. Removes your annoying partner and optionally replaces him with a human controller character.Cons:- The rest of the game you are given a partner. This is probably one of the worst aspects of the game. People complained about the RE5 partner AI, but this AI is pretty much non-existent. Your partner never does anything to help you, even if you're getting smothered to death right in front of him. He occasionally shoots, but that's all. The monsters walk past him, completely focused on you. Thankfully you don't have to worry about him dying, since he can't die. But The fact that you have this invincible person with you at all times who really doesn't help you at all ruins the experience a lot. It ruins the immersion a lot, they don't add anything to the game. Would have been much better if they weren't there.- Stupid/annoying characters. For a game with so many characters, there aren't really any likable ones. One of them is one of the ugliest characters I've ever seen in a game. There's also a lot of random partial female nudity for a people who are supposed to be in these important serious organizations. It makes it hard to tell if the game wants you to take it seriously. - Writing/Acting. The plot itself might be ok, but it couldn't hold my attention because of really poor line delivery of really bad lines. The game also tries to be funny at times, but any attempt at a joke just comes off as awkward and cringey. A lot of dialogue boils down to:Person A: "We have to go there." Person B: "Ok, let's go there."Nothing ever sounds like two humans talking. It sounds like people reading lines in different rooms from eachother. For comparison, I've been playing Metal Gear Rising which has much better conversations that sound like real people interacting, I've sat for hours just listening to the people talk in MGR. Can capcom not afford decent writers after so many games?- Wonky game mechanics. The dodge mechanic is unreliable. Sometimes it works but I only got it to work consistently by mashing Up when I was about to get hit, it's never obvious when you're supposed to do it. The game also wants you to aim at certain parts of enemies, but it isn't always obvious what's the best place to hit. I didn't find out until after the campaign that shooting both arms of the monsters stunned them, I thought it was occuring randomly.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												Sooo... This game is from Resident Evil series, but it's less of a survival horror, filled with puzzles and secrets and more of a shoot-the-zombies kind of game. I won't tell you about the story, since there will be spoilers and some reviews already covered that part of the game. I will tell you my impressions instead.-The first thing I noticed is awkward movement of the main character. It does not go smoothly, but I suppose it's because the game is designed to be played on a console on some sort with a joystick.-Cheap scares. Like, moviement in the ducts, an unexpected corpse falling from nowhere with scary music on the background. Or you are all like "It's a zombie" and nope, those are rats... Stuff like that, to keep you tense on the transition of the story... In theory. This one is an old formula from scary movies and games.-The game itself is pretty much has been made to connect the dots between the story lines of previos and next game. It's made to fill the gap holes in the main story of the Resident Evil games. So, if you are more interested in action game and you want to know a little bit more about the Series and why the ♥♥♥♥ zombies suddently become parasitic worms, infrecting the host and such... This game is made to supposingly explain it to you.-The characters are looking a little bit weird. But maybe it's just me.-Also, you get to scan stuff. Which would be allright as an optional game dinamic, but it's mandatory one and sometimes the game become a sort of "Scan them all" kind of game. Which is exactly as fun as it sounds.-The inventory is weird, different from the previous games. So, you just go there... Scan some♥♥♥♥♥♥ kill some bad guys, look for ammo, medkits and grenades... Which is okay for shooter game but kind of dissapoining for resident evil series.-There aren't much puzzles, it's more like the 4th and 5th RE, but here it's more of a "Go and find the item X to activate thing Y". So... Yeah. That sucks too.-The game itself is pretty short and it feels more like a series of short interactive movies, rather than a RE game.So, in short. If you are interested for a Resident Evil series main story, you should get this game. But it's pretty much just that. A series of short episodes made to close some story gaps and connect the games between themselves. So... Yeah. It's not entirelly bad, but it's not a big deal.5/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												When I heard that this game was getting a PC port I was extremely excited, since it was branded as a survival horror game that was true to the Resident Evil's of old, and frankly, the only Resident Evil games that I 100% enjoyed. This is somewhat true. The gameplay is a mix of what you find in Resident Evil 5 and 6, and what you find in the classic Resident Evil games. The over the shoulder camera is fine, boss fights are difficult, and ammo conservation exists, but only to the extent of Resident Evil 4, in the sense that conserving ammo never becomes a major problem because you always have more weapons. Backtracking, puzzles, and non-linear gameplay is also present, however the disappointment is the fact that all of this is present only in small amounts. There aren't many puzzles or doors that you can backtrack to, and when you do, you typically find that the contents inside are completely optional anyways. It was kind of a tease for me, but still better than the crap show that was Resident Evil 6.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 20, 2013
												This is definitely one of the lesser RE games. The visuals, combat, and enemies all seem watered down from proper numbered entries in the series. This one has a lot of the same problems as RE5. Most of the action takes place on a cruise ship, that's shiny, sterile, and empty. A cruise ship is a very unscary place. Don't make me go to the casino, NO! There's also a LOT of tight corridors to fight and run through. And there's only really one room in the entire game that has creepy monster stuff adorning the walls and floor. It's the only room with an ounce of atmosphere and there weren't even any enemies in the room. Everywhere else could be a part of any other cookie-cutter action game. Put a freaking spider web up somewhere! There are not a lot of different enemy types. A lot of them look like slight variations of each other. What I did like was that the game kind of has the format of the older style RE games where searching around and solving puzzles is necessary to advance. The map does has an objective marker at some points, but it's a good compromise between the more difficult, slower-paced original RE games and newer action-oriented entries. The story is classic RE rubbish. You know all the words to that song so feel free to sing along while you're playing. The campaign takes around 11 hours. When comparing this to RE6 which came out around the same time, there really is no comparison. RE6 is better in every way. It's baffling that Capcom is charging more for this than the much superior RE6. Do not under any circumstances pay full price for this 3DS port. Wait for a severe discount if you really must play this.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												After Resident Evil 3: Nemesis I find it very hard to enjoy any subsequent Resident Evil game. But Resident Evil Revelations was the first one I managed to play through its end. Dividing story into chapters keeps the dynamic flow. And even though the story isn't anything special seeing it from different perspectives and timelines creates the illusion which makes it less dull and fun to watch. Despite the fact that majority of the game takes place at one ship, I had hard time remember where I want to come back, the map (basically location layout) in these situations isn't very helpful.Everything is plentyful, ammo, herbs, grenades. I believe the transition towards more action oriented experience happend with Resident Evil 5, so no big surprise here. Weapons aren't very fun to use and some of them are basically useless (sniper rifle?). And while the ship chapters have some atmosphere it's immidietly killed with goofy intermezzos with Keith and Quint. The biggest positive is probably that's really good port unlike Resident Evil 4 Ultimate HD. I hadn't encountered anything annoying or uncomfortable. It is OK game, it won't offend you but it won't blow you off either.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												This game is definitely for diehard fans of the Resident Evil franchise. I wouldn't say I suffered through the game, however, I did not enjoy it as much as I think I could have. That may be because even for an RE story, this game has one of the worst narratives. There are worse so...Anyway, I won't be too negative since this is a port of a game that was originally released for the Nintendo 3DS. Instead I'll  plus/minus the highs and lows. Easier to digest the point of the review.+ Hi-res texture upgrades are very welcome+ Music and sound effects are excellent+ If you're a diehard RE fan, it's more RE- Story is uber boring- Weapon upgrade system is lacking- Movement is horrible considering the agility of some of the enemies and bosses- $50 price tag. This is a $20 game at mostAn Ok side story that I will probably not revisit, but did not hate. I can recommend this game but only if it's on sale and if you're an RE fan like myself, even though the writing in this series has entered comedy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												It's been a while since the last time I played the RE that could completely gratify me.Some day, after being disappointed by the RE6, I heard that the RE R excluded by the 3DS would be released on the PC platform, I felt excited but also confused, because I didn't know whether this new RE could express the true meaning of the RE. However, as a fan of the RE, I still pre-purchased it before the day it was released. Thank god, I felt really satisfied by the first time I played the game. The atmosphere it created in the story mode was similar to the one in the old RE , suddenly, it reminded me of the day I play RE 3 with my best friend in Primary school....Tears really burst out at that moment.....The story of this RER is also good and reasonable, it perfectly complements the blank between RE4 and RE5, so we can know about the origin of the anti-Bioterrorism organinzation BSAA. Although this game's story mode is awsome, it still has some shortages. It doesn't inherit the Gun-carrying system from the RE5 and I take that as a great pity. Because it will make the game more realistic when the characters carry the gun they don't use on their back. It feels weird when i see the characters grap their gun from the air. But this is just a small shortage, I still recommend this game to you guys.

												With this game I have to say that Capcom made some progress to return the series to it's former glory. I hope this was a wake up call for them, it's a small step in the right direction. It makes me exited to see what will happen to Resident evil in the future because it seems to look a little brighter. Anyhow the game is good and older RE fans will feel more at home with this one than the most recent installments. But there were some things that could have been better gameplay wise but it's understandable since it is a port of a 3ds game. Another thing I want to mention is that the game is pretty short for being a RE game, took me about 6-7 hours to finish while RE 4 took me like 14+ hours to finish. I think it's a good resident evil game and definetly shows that Resident Evil has potential to become perhaps the best survival horror series again even if it might take some time for it to happen.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												A mixed bag of a game. While the setting and atmosphere are infinitely better than Resident Evil 4,5 or 6, the game has numerous problems, raging from "who cares" plot and annoying shooter gallery segments. Some episodes are absolutely pointless and exist only to provide some mindless shooting and prolong the game play time. The entire thing also suffers thanks to the game being the obvious handheld port... small, bland areas, minimal inventory etc. However, despite all this, I had a blast playing Revelations from start to finish... even if it goes out with a whimper. This is probably the best we will get as far as injecting "classic" Resident Evil elements to modern RE goes. Recommended but be wary.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												There is a rediculous amount of lore when it comes to the Biohazard/RE series but I'd consider Revelations a pretty important part of that lore. I wasn't sure exactly what to expect, right off finishing RE4, I started this and I was first impressed how fluid it ran on my PC. Secondly, the pace of the story and gameplay was great, the only problem I had was the episodic delivery, I guess not all that bad but the chapters really only take 20-40 mins to finish, that's a plus and a negative, it keeps the pace going but short...depending on how you like your games. Me personally, I was glued, the story was a little hard to follow to start but makes sense at the end. Much more fun with a play through but I didn't bother finishing a new game +, I was only in it for the story. As for the Raid mode, I didn't even play much but it seemed a bit like a skirmish mode, adds nothing to story but a nice little side game.I any RE fan could appreciate this game.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												My first initial thought on the Resident Evil Series was 'Hell No, I ain't playing that crap." I decided to try one of them and someone recommended This one. Let me tell you that I coudn't have started with a better game. The claustraphobic hallways and rooms provide eery environments which always had me on my toes. The game doesn't use any jump scares, the cheapest of all scares, even though it had countless amount of times to do so. The acting ofsome of the Characters is a bit dry (Especially Chris and Jill, Jill sometimes is okay but Chris is awful) but, it's not very important considering the dialogue is at a minimal. You have to make every bullet count as some enemies can take lots of hits and you run out of ammo hella fast. They Ported this game super well from the 3ds(used to be 3DS exclusive). Controls are super smooth and real easy to get used to. If you want to start the Resident Evil Series, I recommend this one to the end because of the presentation that it has provided, that being really good. They Ported this game super well from the 3ds(used to be 3DS exclusive). Controls are super smooth and real easy to get used to.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												This game is a bad joke by every definition. While the graphics aren't completely outmoded, prepare yourself for visuals that would feel right at home during 2008. Literally. Voice acting is God-awful. Characters are creepy automotons with some stalker-ish characters like CreepyJessica asking if you like her rear end while she takes her time to save you from a pack of zombie-wolves (yes, zombie wolves --- wth?)The game maps are horrendously linear and absurdly small. Weapon ammunition is limited in order to amp the feeling of powerlessness but the weapons themselves feel underpowered and worthless compared to...get this... a karate kick. There is no dedicated dodge key and instead you have to time the forward movement keys to avoid some attacks. Puzzles are brutally stupid and often make no sense.Oh and the story...where do I start. The story is nonsensical and designed for morons. You spend a good 10 minutes collecting "data samples" with a magical device that can analyze ANYTHING from giant mutants on a beach about a quarter of a city block in length, while your boss stands 50 feet away demanding what's taking so long. You reach into mutated, infected biomatter with your bare hands without fear of contamination but apparently everyone else is infected by the merest scratch.A terrorist group leaks information of a secret base in an arctic location...so they can lure Chris Redfield and CreepyJessica to a radio-silenced area. Redfield and Jessica find the base but it turns out it was all an elaborate ruse to actually lure Jill Valentine and some pudgy Redshirt into a derelict ship...how exactly? How was Redfield's signal drawn there? Why not just capture Redfield and bring him to the ship? I mean, you're going to build a BASE in the ARCTIC so you can trick two different agents onto a ship thousands of miles away. Wait, what? And that's just the first quarter of the short, uninspired, ridiculously-plotted game.People will argue that this game was a DS/Gameboy game and that its limitations are born from that. My rebuttal is that iOS has plenty of full-fledged games with better graphics (Infinity Blade III), better gameplay (Implosion) and better voice acting/plot (Republique) than this normally 30 dollar crapshow.  I suppose if the game was priced like an iOS title, at 5-10 dollars, it might be worth it but not at that price. What a ripoff.AVOID.4/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												I've never played a Resident Evil game before, and for my first one, Revelations did a great job keeping me on my toes. It was constantly dancing the line between survival horror and traditional third-person shooter, and I never felt like I had enough ammo to feel fully comfortable. The Genesis device was used to its full potential due to the myriad of hidden objects, invisible/difficult-to-spot enemies, and the storyline was full of cliffhangars and drove me insane because my work only gave me enough time to finish a single chapter every night. I have two major criticisms: the dodge mechanic is unreliable at best, I never used it because it didn't seem to do anything. On occasion my character would dodge an attack but it felt completely divorced from whatever buttons I was pressing at the time. This meant that I mostly shot my way out of situations, which necessitated heavy usage of the Genesis device and my AI partner to keep my limited ammo stocked up. But complaint number two is that your AI partner is almost useless. The doors in this game only allow one charcter through at a time, meaning your partner shows up late to every fight, never seems to bother shooting anything and can't seem to hit anything with the few shots they take. But all in all, the game is well worth playing. The swimming mechanics are some of the smoothest I've seen in this sort of game and the arsenal of weapons and enemies is diverse and keeps things interesting. Wish more PC ports were like this one.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2013
												Ahh Revelations. This game is especially perfect for the people like myself who have only played RE 4-6. This game is very much mostly old school survival horror from the days of RE1-3 and very little emphasis on action, just mostly on throwbacks or on the side characters. Now to those who loved RE5-6 only for the co-op, you will not get co-op in the story but only in its other part, Raid Mode, which is very different to The Mercenaries in the recent entries. This game has a lot more weapon customization than RE6. Also be wise with your ammo as much as you can since you won't be able to melee as easy in this game compared to RE4-6. However, the story is on par to RE4-6 if not better since there is more common sense in the situations and to reasoning compared to RE6 especially. Well Raid Mode, all I'm gona say is that its really fun. If the game was 40 I would give the immediate recommendation and 8.5. but since its not the case, it gets an 8 from me, Well hope RE7 can be on point with this game and the upcoming survival horror game, The Evil Within, :).

content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												Alright, let's cut through the BS you read in other reviews and get down to it.The good,The writing, yes, the writing, it's succinct , punchy, and entertaining. The character known as Parker really tugs on the heart strings, and is genuinely relatable. Anyone complaining about the plot obviously never played RE1. It's always been hokey and awkwardly paced. This game is no different.Level design and art direction, everything feels creepy and alive.Overall flow, fun and easy to get through, with new game plus options.The BadGone are series stables such as, complex puzzles, green/blue herbs, inventory management, ammo scarcity, and most of all, areas to explore that function as open area puzzles, like the mansion, or police station.While I was most disappointed in how linear it was, it's still fun to play and has some eerie moments. It is slight, being a handheld port, on unique interactions with the environment, I find it still scratches the RE itch.The shooting, you basically just dump ammo into to things. Once you get and upgrade your auto-matic weapon of choice, that'll be your main stay anytime you have ammo. The reason being is that combat is just too fast paced over short distances to try and use you're rifle (which will miss) or handgun (goes in the trash asap), or magnum (three enemies later, no more ammo). It's pretty much smg/shotgun all day once you get the ammo capacity upgrades.The cut-scenes, we are talking MGS levels here. Cut those out and your playtime will he halved.in conclusion. It's a good game, just not the return to roots people have been saying it is. Just solid all around, while being just two shades away from borderlands. If Capcom just (they won't) slowed it down, made ammo scarce, and made the protagnist not a super solider, we'd be right back to our roots. P.S. please bring back Carlos and HUNK.

It works, it  still feels a lot like the old once even though you can now move and shot at the same time.Story: A Decent story  with at least two  good twists that caught me off guard.Horror/Survival: A great survival game and far more horror in this game then Resident evil 4, a bit less then Re 2/ code veronica, re zero etc. And you cant just spray bullets out or you will have a hard time.Music: A great soundtrackDecent: Characters: could be better but some of them that is intruced is alright.Graphics/Atmosphere: The Graphics is alright , but the amostphere is great and you real feel close to being alone on the ship ( Minor Spoiler, you have a partner).Cons:Lenght: You could argue that it is a bit shortDifficulity: You could argue despite playing on normal that it is very easyReplaybilites : They are really no reason to play trough this game more then onceShort summary before the score compared to other re games, worse then of those i have completed is worse then Re 2, 4 and 5. But its far batter then re 6. I wouldnt say despite i havent completeded re  zero or 3 that its better then those two games.Overall score:  8/10 N.B : Most of the time my steam reviews get written right afteri have completed the game . Specially after my completion of Deux Ex. but since i remember alot from this game even if is a 2 or so years since i completed i decided to write a qucik review.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												A very underrated Resident Evil game. I would say it's the best recent Resident Evil game. It is actually scary with amazing environments unlike the more recent games. The gameplay adds to the game as it keeps ammo scarce making you feel like you are in danger at all times. The enemies, especially the bosses are terrifying.The graphics are decent, especially given that this is a port from the 3DS. Everything runs smoothly at over 144 fps on my setup.The story is decent. You switch between different perspectives and areas which does affect the pacing a bit, however it is an enjoyable story. It is a bit over the top and some of its twists are very predictable, however there are no major flaws.Raid mode is dead, but if you can find a game it is fun to do with friends. You can also play it solo but it gets very hard to do in the later levels.Overall, this game is worth it when it's on sale. I wouldn't pay full price for it. The campaign took me about 10 hours on the hardest difficulty, but it is important to note that I had played the game before on the 3DS so it should take you longer to complete.EDIT: Raid mode is the best game within a game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												This game... is awful.  It takes all the worst parts of Resident Evil and then manages to try and break it up into chapters as a DLC sales model?  They had the opportunity to make an interesting game like Resident Evil 1-3 but zombies drop "random loot" and the disjointed story makes almost no sense.  The supporting characters are sacks of uninteresting trash, and just retract from the game at large.  The one good thing I can say about the game is that they managed to find a good setting and atmosphere.  The rooms feel like they did in RE1/2.  They hit the perfect combination of regal and claustrophobic which could have been interesting, had you not been handed a bucket of ammo, and had waves of zombies thrown ineffectually against you.

Posted: February 26
												A very solid game, but with a weak story that doesnt really captivate the players exept a few times far and betwen,  does have a little exploration through the levels with the normal backtracking RE games have, satisfying shooting mechanics and simple puzzles to cativate the more casual gamers. The campaing is nicely split into episodes, and can go from 8h to 15h depending your playstyle, sometimes it requires a little too much backtracking, but if you arent explorer much of it can be avoided, the graphics are good for its time and in some ocasions, you have the RE feeling, but Revelations grounds, is more a of shooter that anything else.The story isnt great, but voice actors do a good job making it belivable, the sound is also good and help keep up the pace of the game and provide the creepy feeling on some ocasions.Besides the story, you have the raid mode, that can be played solo or coop, and there is where revelations really shine, you can add hours of fun with your friends or just muckaround in pub to get company for the horde mode, it have 3 stages and many things to unlock.Overall, revelations is solid experience, and a must for any RE fan that like the world around the franchise, even being more action oriented, still keep some old traces to destinguish himself from other shooters.

Well worth the couple of bucks I paid to score this one.
